{{multiple issues|{{Notability|Web|date=November 2008}} {{refimprove|date=November 2008}} {{advert|date=November 2008}} }} {{Infobox Podcast |width = 23em |title = Edtechtalk.com |image = |caption = |host = [[Jeff Lebow]] and 20+ others |url = [http://www.edtechtalk.com www.edtechtalk.com] |status = 8-12 weekly |length = 20 to 120 minutes |picture format = |video format = |audio format = [[MP3]] |rss = [http://edtechtalk.com/feed http://edtechtalk.com/feed] |atom = |began = June 5, 2005 |ended = |genre = Educational Technology |language = [[English language|English]] |ratings = |network = worldbridges.net }} '''Edtechtalk''' is an award-winning<ref>http://incsub.org/awards/the-edublog-awards-2005/#audio</ref> community of educators interested in discussing and learning about the uses of [[educational technology]]. Part of the [[Worldbridges]] network of homegrown [[webcasting]], several live shows are webcast each week.
==Format== During shows, listeners can use any common media player (i.e. [[Windows Media Player]], [[RealPlayer]], or [[iTunes]]) to listen to the discussion and use the chat room to make comments and ask questions. It is also possible to join in the discussion using [[Skype]] or (sometimes) a U.S. based teleconference.
==Goals==
Edtechtalk is a community of people interested in the use of technology to improve teaching and learning at all levels of education throughout the world. As a Worldbridges community, it embraces the values of collaboration and inclusiveness.
The community fosters the development of networks of educators who come together to collaborate, debate policies and practices, and support one another in their professional and personal use of educational technology.<ref>EdTechTalk [http://edtechtalk.com/node/1492 "EdTechTalk Policies & Standards"] Retrieved November 28, 2008.</ref>
Edtechtalk "collate the work of a variety of professionals to create snapshots of the knowledge of a particular field as it is seen at a given time" <ref>In [http://innovateonline.info/index.php?view=article&id=550&action=synopsis ''Innovate] - Journal of Online Education'', Vol. 4, issue 5, June/July 2008.</ref>
== List of current Edtechtalk shows ==
'''Edtech Weekly''' The 'main' show, hosted by Dave Cormier, John Schinker, [[Jeff Lebow]], and Jennifer Maddrell features the latest news from the world of [[edtech]] and the [[edublogosphere]].
'''21st Century Learning Webcast''' Independent School educators, Alex Ragone, Arvind Grover, and Vinnie Vrotney explore the intersection of education and technology on this weekly show. .
'''Women of Web 2.0''' Women of Web 2.0 began webcasting weekly internet radio shows in October 2006. Its intended audience is for educators who are interested in using web technologies in innovative ways. The webcasts are live events held on Tuesday evenings at 9 PM EST and are archived on the Edtechtalk.com site as podcasts. The show's hosts are Jennifer Wagner, Sharon Peters and friends, who are educators at all levels of education.
'''Teachers Teaching Teachers''' Teachers Paul Allison and Susan Ettenheim are mainly responsible for this blog, podcast, and webcast. Every Wednesday evening at 9:00 EST (Americas) we get together and talk about our teaching. These conversations are archived as a podcast on this blog. Objectives include searching for the most effective practices in technology, studying research, and improving knowledge of new media by using it. There are two purposes: developing teacher knowledge and leadership in schools and districts and putting this knowledge and leadership to work to improve student online reading and writing through the use of blogs, wikis, podcasts and webcasts.
'''EdTech Brainstorms''' Hosted by Doug Symington. Free-form discussions where educators [[Skype]] in (or call in) to discuss what they're working on and thinking about. The Edtech cyber faculty lounge.
'''Conversations''' This weekly show, hosted by Lisa Parisi and Maria Knee, focuses on an educational topic each week. Each Sunday morning at 11:30 AM EST (Americas), Parisi and Knee are joined by a variety of educators around the world to discuss such issues as improving the education system, homework, and parents in the classroom.
'''Teachers are Talking''' Lisa Parisi, Susan van Gelder, and Cheryl Lykowski host this monthly show. For each show, they are joined by a guest who discusses his or her specialty in the educational field.
'''Parents as Partners'''
This bi-weekly show is focused on how to connect parents and teachers in ways that benefit students and build effective working relationships. The show is hosted by Lorna Costantini, Matt Montagne, Cindy Seibel and Cindy Zautcke. On the 1st and 3rd Monday of each month parents and teachers share their experiences on how to use web 2.0 tools and other good practices to connect parents and teachers.
==Awards and recognition== Winner of 2008 Edublog award for best use of audio in education.<ref>http://edublogawards.com/and-the-2008-winners-are/ List of Edublog award winners</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://edtechtalk.com/ EdTechTalk]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Edtechtalk}} [[Category:Educational technology academic and professional associations]] [[Category:Audio podcasts]] [[Category:Technology podcasts]]

{{for|Academic policies regarding a silent period before publication|News embargo#On articles in scientific journals}}
In [[academic publishing]], an '''embargo''' is a period during which access to academic journals is not allowed to users who have not paid for access (or have access through their institution). The purpose of this is to ensure publishers have revenue to support their activities,<ref>{{cite web |title=Open Access: Springer tightens rules on self-archiving [Interview with Springer's Eric Merkel-Sobota] |url=http://poynder.blogspot.com/2013_06_01_archive.html |website=poynder.blogspot.com |accessdate=2015-12-10}}{{self-published inline|date=September 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Publication embargo « SPARC Europe |url=http://sparceurope.org/embargoes/ |website=sparceurope.org |accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref> although the impact of embargoes on publishers is hotly debated, with some studies finding no impact<ref>{{cite web |title=The evidence fails to justify publishers' demand for longer embargo periods on publicly-funded research. |url=http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/impactofsocialsciences/2014/01/14/suber-embargoes-on-publicly-funded-research/ |website=Impact of Social Sciences |accessdate=2015-10-19 |date=2014-01-14T11:30:22+00:00 |publisher=2014|Academic publishing |last2=Comments |first2=Open Access|2 }}{{self-published inline|date=September 2018}}</ref> while publisher experience suggests otherwise.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Is Free Affordable |journal=Nature |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/focus/accessdebate/14.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1136/bmj.327.7409.241 |title=Paying for bmj.com |journal=BMJ |volume=327 |issue=7409 |pages=241–242 |year=2003 |last1=Delamothe |first1=T. }}</ref> A 2012 survey of libraries by the Association of Learned, Professional, and Society Publishers on the likelihood of journal cancellations in cases where most of the content was made freely accessible after six months suggests there would be a major negative impact on subscriptions,<ref>{{cite web |title=ALPSP Survey on Journal Cancelations |url=http://www.publishingresearch.net/documents/ALPSPPApo,tentialresultsofsixmonthembargofv.pdf |accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref> but this result has been debated.
Various types exist: * A 'moving wall' is a fixed period of months or years. * A fixed date is a particular time point that does not change. * A current year (or other period) is setting a time point on Jan. 1 of the current year, so that all material earlier than that is available. Although fixed during the year, it will change each year.
== Purpose == There are various purposes: * For [[delayed open access journal]]s, the embargo separates the most recent period, for which a subscription is needed, from an older period, where a subscription is not needed and anyone may access the article. This can range from a few months to several years.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi=10.1002/asi.22856 |title=Delayed open access: An overlooked high-impact category of openly available scientific literature |journal=Journal of the American Society for Information Science and Technology |volume=64 |issue=7 |pages=1323–1329 |year=2013 |last1=Laakso |first1=Mikael |last2=Björk |first2=Bo-Christer }}</ref> * For [[self-archiving]], the embargo is a period of time set by the publisher in the [[copyright transfer agreement]] where access to the archived version of the article in a digital [[Repository (publishing)|repository]] is restricted until the embargo period expires. Typical embargo periods range from 6 to 24 months, though some publishers may require an embargo of up to 48 months.<ref>{{Cite web|title = SHERPA/RoMEO – Publisher copyright policies & self-archiving|url = http://www.sherpa.ac.uk/romeo/index.php?la=en&fIDnum=%7C&mode=simple|website = www.sherpa.ac.uk|accessdate = 2015-10-19}}</ref> * In full-text databases, such as those of [[EBSCO Publishing]] or [[ProQuest]], it separates the most recent period, where only a title or abstract is available, from an older one, which is openly accessible.<ref>{{Cite web|title = EBSCO Support: What are Publication Embargoes?|url = http://support.ebscohost.com/knowledge_base/detail.php?id=866|website = support.ebscohost.com|accessdate = 2015-10-19|date = 2016-06-13T19:07:45Z}}</ref>
== Moving wall == In academic publishing, a moving wall is the time period between the last issue of an [[academic journal]] available in a given [[online]] [[Bibliographic database|database]] and the most recently published print issue of a journal. It is specified by publishers in their [[license agreement]]s with databases (like [[JSTOR]]), and generally ranges from several months to several years.<ref>{{cite web|title = What is a moving wall?|url = http://about.jstor.org/librarians-faq-archival-journals#What_is_a_moving_wall|work = JSTOR|accessdate = 19 October 2015}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Academic publishing]] [[Category:Open access (publishing)]] [[Category:Publishing]]

<!----> '''Facila''' is a training program, in Southern Europe, for adults with short primary schooling. The objective is to prepare students for validation processes and secondary education. Many participants are [[entrepreneurs]], owners or employees of small and medium enterprises, [[Small and medium enterprises|SME]]:s. In these cases the program provides opportunity for training in [[entrepreneurship]] and "[[continuous improvement]]" to enhance the participant's [[employability]].
The program started in 2007 as a cooperation between [[Sweden]] and [[Portugal]]. It is based on the Swedish program "Kunskapslyftet" and adapted to Southern European conditions on an initiative by Johan Frisk.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.evta.net/evta_tube/facila.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723122815/http://www.evta.net/evta_tube/facila.html |archivedate=2011-07-23 |df= }} Presentation, European Vocational Training Federation</ref><ref>http://www.dn.se/nyheter/varlden/utbildning-ska-radda-portugal-1.1221990 Dagens Nyheter (Swedish Newspaper)</ref><ref>http://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=3304&artikel=3497424 Sveriges Radio (Swedish public radio)</ref><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://ww1.rtp.pt/multimedia/progVideo.php?tvprog=24786&idpod=37314 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101130202412/http://ww1.rtp.pt/multimedia/progVideo.php?tvprog=24786 |archivedate=2010-11-30 |df= }} "Iniciativa", min 37:30-41:30 RTP2 (Portuguese public television)</ref><ref>http://www.euractiv.com/en/enterprise-jobs/can-entrepreneurship-be-taught-news-494547 Interview "EuroActiv"</ref><ref>Coaching World June 2010 p12</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://tsf.sapo.pt/PaginaInicial/AudioeVideo.aspx?content_id=1599197 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100809030549/http://tsf.sapo.pt/paginainicial/AudioeVideo.aspx?content_id=1599197 |archivedate=2010-08-09 |df= }} "Qualificar a população adulta activa" TSF (Portuguese radio)</ref><ref>http://www.theopenmanager.com {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110207234933/http://www.theopenmanager.com/ |date=2011-02-07 }} Blog "The Open Manager"</ref>
==Continuous improvement projects== Apart from basic training, the main objective of the [http://www.facila.eu/english/ Facila] program is to teach students how to prepare improvement projects.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://tsf.sapo.pt/PaginaInicial/AudioeVideo.aspx?content_id=1603152 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100810050714/http://tsf.sapo.pt/paginainicial/AudioeVideo.aspx?content_id=1603152 |archivedate=2010-08-10 |df= }} radio program in Portuguese, "Mãos à Obra" (TSF) interview with the training coordinator</ref> The students review their work,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iefp.pt/iefp/publicacoes/Formar/Paginas/Formar2008.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20110529080619/http://www.iefp.pt/iefp/publicacoes/Formar/Paginas/Formar2008.aspx |archivedate=2011-05-29 |df= }} "Formar"- Portuguese magazine for educators, nº65, p11-14 (IEFP)</ref> both task and physical space, then look for patterns and flaws which are expressed using a mathematical analysis. The process, which increases the students [[employability]], is fundamental to finding clues for improvements in productivity and decrease in work related injuries.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.iefp.pt/iefp/publicacoes/Formar/Documents/Formar_2011/Formar_75.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20131116001741/http://www.iefp.pt/iefp/publicacoes/Formar/Documents/Formar_2011/Formar_75.pdf |archivedate=2013-11-16 |df= }} Interview in Portuguese with Carlos Capela in "Formar" pp 22-23</ref> {{details|continuous improvement}}
==References== <references/>
<!--
==Projectos de melhoria contínua== O ponto fulcral do processo formativo são os projectos de melhoria.<ref>https://tsf.sapo.pt/PaginaInicial/AudioeVideo.aspx?content_id=1603152 programa rádio, "Mãos à Obra" (TSF) entrevista com a coordenadora da formação</ref> Cada formando é convidado an analisar o seu posto de trabalho,<ref>http://www.iefp.pt/iefp/publicacoes/Formar/Paginas/Formar2008.aspx Formar-revista para formadores nº65, p11-14 (IEFP)</ref> aplicar componentes da Matemática para a Vida, procurar padrões e traduzi-los para a linguagem matemática. O procedimento permite aumento de produtividade e assim o aumento da [[empregabilidade]] do formando. Se a mesma metodologia é aplicada por donos de pequenas empresas, o resultado do processo leva an aumentos do [[empreendedorismo]].<ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Método formativo== A metodologia contempla duas vertentes fundamentais, individual e social. O processo de orientar adultos, a [[Andragogia|andragogia]], serve de base para depois construir sobre os conhecimentos existentes de cada participante. O processo social constitui a pedra angular na [[Capacitação|capacitação]] de formandos adultos, a convicção de ser capaz, o [[Teoria da atribuição#Locus de causalidade|"locus interno"]], an inter-ajuda inspirada na pesquisa do Professor [[Sugata Mitra]], são todos componentes do importante "coaching de grupos" que caracteriza o programa Facila.
==Financiamento== Este projecto é apoiado pelo [http://www.poph.qren.pt/ Programa Operacional de Potencial Humano (POPH)] na medida 2.3, formações modulares certificadas. Como em muitos programas comunitários, o POPH é financiado com verbas oriundas do [[Fundo Social Europeu]] (75%) e o Orçamento do Estado Português (25%).
==Quadro Nacional de Qualificações== Como consequência da [[Estratégia de Lisboa]] há uma nova visão sobre conhecimento, uma visão mais preocupada com as evidências do que propriamente com o percurso da sua obtenção. Em Portugal, o [http://www.catalogo.anq.gov.pt/Home/QNQ Quadro Nacional de Qualificações] pretende regularizar e valorizar os conhecimentos obtidos por vias não formais e informais.
O programa Facila, com a sua função na preparação de formandos para o processo de [[Rvcc|reconhecimento e validação]] da iniciativa [[Novas Oportunidades]], pretende contribuir para a qualificação de adultos europeus.
{{Referências}}
== {{Ligações externas}} == * {{Link||2=http://www.camaralusosueca.pt/formacao.asp |3=Página da Câmara de Comércio e Indústria Luso-Sueca, referência ao programa Facila}} * {{Link||2=http://www.facila.eu |3=Programa Facila, página official}} * {{Link||2=http://www.iefp.pt |3=Instituto de Emprego e Formação Profissional, página official}} * {{Link||2=http://www.catalogo.anq.gov.pt |3=Agência Nacional para a Qualificação, catálogo de qualificações}} * {{Link||2=http://www.poph.qren.pt |3=Programa Operacional de Potential Humano (POPH)}} * {{Link||2=http://www.catalogo.anq.gov.pt/Home/QNQ |3=Quadro Nacional de Qualificações (QNQ)}}
[[Categoria:Ensino]] -->
[[Category:Training]]

Some [[prison]]s have sought to limit inmates' abilities to communicate in [[foreign language]]s, such as send or receive correspondence in these languages, or receive printed publications in these languages. This is often justified on the grounds that it might enable inmates to plan escapes or other crimes, or may contain material encouraging disorder in the prison, but that prison officials would not recognise them due to their inability to understand what was written or said.
Inmates and [[human rights]] activists have argued that this policy is discriminatory against minority groups who speak a different language, especially when they do not have good command of the mainstream language, and hence have difficulty communicating in it, when they wish to correspond with family members who do not speak the mainstream or [[national language]] (especially with foreign national prisoners), and where their language is an important part of their cultural or religious identity. (For example, [[Arabic language|Arabic]] is an important part of the religious identity of many [[Muslim]]s, and [[Hebrew (language)|Hebrew]] is an important part of the religious identity of [[Jew]]s.)
==Foreign languages in prisons in the United States==
The US [[Court of Appeals]], Seventh Circuit, ruled in Kikumura v. Turner 28 F.3d 592 C.A.7(Ill).1994. (see [http://www.leagle.com/xmlResult.aspx?xmldoc=199462028F3d592_1526.xml&docbase=CSLWAR2-1986-2006]), that a blanket refusal to permit inmates to communicate or receive publications in a language other than English is unconstitutional. However, their ruling implies that the prison may still refuse to do so, if they have made a good faith effort to translate the materials or have they reviewed by a prison official who speaks the language, and found that such translation or review is not possible or too costly. But such an investigation of possibilities of review or translation must be made on a case-by-case basis, rather than a blanket prohibition without conducting such an analysis.
==See also== *[[Language policy]] ==External links== *M. Volz [http://www.therepublic.com/view/story/f856eb7d80bf4429bfdd4c3c74474720/MT--English-Only-Prison/ Montana prison changes inmate mail policy after lawsuit claimed 'English-only' discrimination] [[The Republic (Columbus)|The Republic]] 2011 *[http://www.ekurd.net/mismas/articles/misc2011/1/turkey3106.htm EU court: Turkey violated privacy of Kurdish prisoners] 2011
[[Category:Penal imprisonment]] [[Category:Language policy]]

{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}} {{Infobox writer |name = Fred D'Aguiar |image= | image_size= |alt= |caption= |pseudonym= |birth_name= |birth_date= {{Birth date and age|1960|02|02|df=y}} |birth_place= [[London, England]] |death_date= |death_place= |resting_place= |occupation = Poet, novelist, playwright, Professor of English at [[Virginia Tech]] |language = |nationality= |ethnicity= |citizenship= |education= |alma_mater= [[University of Kent]] (1985) |period= |genre= [[Fiction]], [[poetry]], [[stage plays]] |subject= |movement= |notableworks= Poetry:
''Mama Dot''
''Airy Hall''
Novels:
''[[The Longest Memory]]'' |spouse= | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = {{Plainlist | * Guyana Poetry Prize (1989) * David Higham Prize for Fiction (1994) * Whitbread First Novel Award (1994) }} | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | portaldisp = }} '''Fred D'Aguiar''' (born 2 February 1960) is a [[Guyanese in the United Kingdom|British-Guyanese]] poet, novelist and playwright. He is currently Professor of English at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]. == Life == Fred D'Aguiar was born in [[London]] in 1960 to Guyanese parents, Malcolm Frederick D'Aguiar and Kathleen Agatha Messiah.{{cite book|last=Stade|first=George|title=Encyclopaedia of British Writers, 1800 to the Present (Vol. II)|year=2003|publisher=[[Facts on File]]|location=[[New York City|New York]]|pages=127–8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T7pVTz46T3cC&pg=PA127&lpg=PA127&dq=fred+d'aguiar+mama+dot&source=bl&ots=nfCm79ZCRT&sig=QI9nXSr3QeD4J30EATi4VP7phFU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rknTT_zQKou88AO8vumWAw&ved=0CF0Q6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q=fred%20d'aguiar%20mama%20dot&f=false|author2=Karen Karbiener}} In 1962 he was taken to [[Guyana]] where he lived with his grandmother until 1972 when he returned, at the age of twelve, to England.{{cite journal|last=Hyppolite|first=Joanne|title=Interview with Fred D'Aguiar|journal=Anthurium|year=2004|volume=2|issue=1|url=http://scholarlyrepository.miami.edu/anthurium/vol2/iss1/6/|accessdate=6 June 2012}}{{cite journal|last=Birbalsingh|first=Frank|title=An Interview with Fred D'Aguiar|journal=ARIEL|year=1993|volume=24|issue=1|pages=133–145}}{{cite web|title=Fred D'Aguiar|url=http://literature.britishcouncil.org/fred-daguiar|work=British Council Writers Profiles|publisher=[[British Council]]|accessdate=6 June 2012}} D'Aguiar trained as a [[psychiatric nurse]] before reading African and Caribbean Studies at the [[University of Kent]], [[Canterbury]], graduating in 1985. On graduating he applied for a [[PhD]] on the Guyanese author [[Wilson Harris]] at the [[University of Warwick]], but - after winning two writers-in-residency positions, at [[Birmingham University]] and the [[University of Cambridge]] (where he was the Judith E. Wilson Fellow from 1989 to 1990) - his PhD studies "recededed from [his] mind" and he began to focus all of his energies on creative writing. In 1994, D'Aguiar moved to the United States to take up a Visiting Writer position at [[Amherst College]], [[Amherst, Massachusetts]] (1992–94). Since then, he has taught at [[Bates College]], [[Lewiston, Maine]] (Assistant Professor, 1994–95) and the [[University of Miami]] where he held the position of Professor of English and [[Creative Writing]]. In 2003 he took up the position of Professor of English and Co-Director of the [[Master of Fine Arts]] in [[Creative Writing]] at [[Virginia Tech]]. In Fall 2015, he became a Professor of English and Director of Creative Writing at [[UCLA]].http://dailybruin.com/2015/04/22/english-department-hires-two-new-creative-writing-professors/ == Poetry, novels and plays == === Poetry === D'Aguiar's first collection of poetry, ''Mama Dot'' (1985), was published to much acclaim. It centres on an "[[archetype|archetypal]]" grandmother figure, Mama Dot, and was notable for its fusion of standard English and [[Nation language]].{{cite journal|last=O'Brien|first=Sean|title=A Necessary Gospel|journal=[[London Review of Books]]|year=1996|volume=11|issue=6|pages=24–5|url=http://www.lrb.co.uk/v18/n11/sean-obrien/a-necessary-gospel|accessdate=9 June 2012}} Along with his 1989 collection ''Airy Hall'' (named after the village in Guyana where D'Aguiar spent his childhood), ''Mama Dot'' won the [[Literature of Guyana|Guyana Poetry Prize]]. Where D'Aguiar's first two poetry collections were set in Guyana, his third - ''British Subjects'' (1989) - explores the experiences of peoples of the West Indian diaspora in London.{{cite journal|last=Salkey|first=Andrew|authorlink=Andrew Salkey|title=British Subjects by Fred D'Aguiar|journal=[[World Literature Today]]|year=1994|volume=68|issue=4|pages=864–5|doi=10.2307/40150782}} London was also the focus of another long poem, ''Sweet Thames'', which was broadcast as part of the [[BBC]] "Worlds on Film" series on 3 July 1992 and won the [[Commission for Racial Equality]] Race in the Media Award.{{cite journal|last=Barfield|first=Stephen|title='Post-Face': Reflections on the Literary Thames|journal=The Literary London Journal|date=March 2007|volume=5|issue=1|url=http://www.literarylondon.org/london-journal/march2007/Barfield.html|accessdate=8 June 2012|issn=1744-0807}} After turning to writing novels rather than poetry for a period of time, D'Aguiar returned to the poetic mode in 1998, publishing ''Bill of Rights'' (1998): a long narrative poem about the [[Jonestown]] massacre in Guyana in 1979, which is told in Guyanese versions of English, fusing patois, Creole and nation language with the standard vernacular.{{cite book|last=Maes-Jelinek|first=Hena|authorlink=Hena Maes-Jelinek|title=The Labyrinth of Universality: Wilson Harris's Visionary Art of Fiction|year=2006|publisher=Rodopi|location=Amsterdam|pages=419–437 [421]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tCoknaliOUMC&pg=PA421&lpg=PA421&dq=fred+d'aguiar+bill+of+rights+jonestown&source=bl&ots=PfShFRdiY3&sig=-juJ_j9uCNMbeCKpOtesObg5jUw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=eWjTT6nQE8rB8gOfxfSdAw&ved=0CGAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=fred%20d'aguiar%20bill%20of%20rights%20jonestown&f=false|accessdate=12 June 2012|chapter=Chapter 22: "Tricksters of Heaven" Visions of Holocaust in ''Jonestown'' and Fred D'Aguiar's ''Bill of Rights''}} It was shortlisted for the 1998 [[T. S. Eliot Prize]]. ''Bill of Rights'' was followed by another narrative poem, ''Bloodlines'' (2000), which tells the story of a black slave and her white lover. His 2009 collection of poetry, ''Continental Shelf'', centres on a response to the [[Virginia Tech Massacre]] in which 32 people were killed by a student in 2007.{{cite news|last=Bainbridge|first=Charles|title=Continental Shelf by Fred D'Aguiar|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/sep/19/continental-shelf-fred-daguiar|accessdate=10 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Guardian]] (Review Section)|date=19 September 2009|pages=19}} It was a finalist for the 2009 [[T. S. Eliot Prize]].{{cite news|last=Flood|first=Alison|title=T. S. Eliot Prize Shortlists Poets 'Who Have Dreamed and Who Have Dared'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2009/oct/22/ts-eliot-prize-shortlist|accessdate=2 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=22 October 2009}} === Novels === D'Aguiar's first novel, ''The Longest Memory'' (1994), tells the story of Whitechapel, a slave on an eighteenth-century Virginia plantation. The book won both the [[David Higham Prize for Fiction]] and the [[Whitbread Awards|Whitbread First Novel Award]].{{cite news|last=Edemariam|first=Aida|title=A Child Out of Time|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/jan/18/featuresreviews.guardianreview15|accessdate=7 June 2012|newspaper=The Guardian|date=18 January 2003}}{{cite journal|last=Frias|first=Maria|title=The Erotics of Slavery (A Review of Bloodlines)|journal=[[Callaloo (journal)|Callaloo]]|year=2002|volume=25|issue=2|pages=679–685, p. 684 (n.4)|doi=10.1353/cal.2002.0069}}{{cite news|last=Gurnah|first=Abdulrazak|authorlink=Abdulrazak Gurnah|title=Resisting Ignorance|newspaper=[[Times Literary Supplement]]|date=15 July 1994|pages=22}} It was adapted for television and televised by [[Channel 4]] in the UK. Returning to themes he had earlier developed in ''British Subjects'', D'Aguiar's 1996 novel, ''Dear Future'', explores the history of the West Indian diaspora through a fictional account of the lives of one extended family.{{cite journal|last=King|first=Bruce|title=Dear Future by Fred D'Aguiar|journal=World Literature Today|year=1997|volume=71|issue=1|pages=206|doi=10.2307/40152753}}{{cite journal|last=Hathaway|first=Heather|title=Dear Future by Fred D'Aguiar|journal=[[African American Review]]|year=1998|volume=32|issue=3|pages=506–8|doi=10.2307/3042256}} D'Aguiar's third novel, ''Feeding the Ghosts'' (1997), was inspired by a visit D'Aguiar made to the [[Merseyside Maritime Museum]] in Liverpool and is based on the true story of the [[Zong Massacre|''Zong'' massacre]] in which 132 slaves were thrown from a [[slave ship]] into the Atlantic for insurance purposes.{{cite journal|last=Frias|first=Maria|title=Building Bridges Back to the Past: An Interview with Fred D'Aguiar|journal=Callaloo|year=2002|volume=25|issue=2|pages=418–425 [421]|doi=10.1353/cal.2002.0068}} According to historical accounts, one slave survived and climbed back onto the ship; and in D'Aguiar's narrative this slave - about whom there is next to no historical information - is developed as the fictional character Mintah. His fourth novel, ''Bethany Bettany'' (2003), centres on a five-year-old Guyanese girl, Bethany, whose suffering has been read by some as symbolising that of a nation (Guyana) seeking to make itself whole again.{{cite news|last=Jays|first=David|title=You can take the boy out of Guyana...|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2003/jan/05/fiction.features5|accessdate=9 June 2012|newspaper=[[The Observer]]|date=5 January 2003}} His 2014 novel ''Children of Paradise'' is a fictional reimagining of the [[Jonestown]] massacre told through the perspective of a mother and child living at the commune.https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/09/books/review/children-of-paradise-by-fred-daguiar.html === Plays === D'Aguiar's plays include ''High Life'', which was first produced at the [[Albany Theatre|Albany Empire]] in London in 1987, and ''A Jamaican Airman Foresees His Death'', performed at the [[Royal Court Theatre]], London, in 1991. His radio play ''Mr Reasonable'' – about a freed black slave, a skilled silk weaver, who is engaged by [[Shakespeare]] to make theatreical costumes – was broadcast on [[BBC Radio 4]] on 10 April 2015.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b05prkhb "Mr Reasonable by Fred D'Aguiar"], BBC Radio 4. ==Bibliography== *1985. ''Mama Dot''. London: [[Chatto & Windus]]. *1988. ''[[The New British Poetry]]'' 1968–88. Edited with [[Gillian Allnutt]], [[Ken Edwards]] and [[Eric Mottram]]. *1989. ''[[Airy Hall]]''. London: Chatto & Windus. *1993. ''British Subjects''. London: [[Bloodaxe Books|Bloodaxe]]. *1994. ''[[The Longest Memory]]''. London: Chatto & Windus. *1995. ''[[A Jamaican Airman Foresees His Death]]'' (play). London: [[Methuen Publishing|Methuen]]. *1996. ''Dear Future''. London: Chatto & Windus. *1997. ''Feeding the Ghosts''. London: Chatto & Windus. *1998. ''Bill of Rights''. London: Chatto & Windus. *2000. ''Bloodlines''. London: Chatto & Windus. *2001. ''An English Sampler: New and Selected Poems''. *2004. ''Bethany Bettany'', 2003. London: Chatto & Windus. *2009. ''Continental Shelf''. Oxford: [[Carcanet Press|Carcanet]]. *2014. ''Children of Paradise''. New York: [[Harper (publisher)]] ==Prizes and awards== *1983 Minority Rights Group Award *1984 University of Kent T. S. Eliot Prize (for University of Kent students) *1985 GLC Literature Award *1985 Malcolm X Prize for Poetry (for ''Mama Dot'') *1989 [[Literature of Guyana|Guyana Poetry Prize]] (for ''Mama Dot'' and ''Airy Hall'') *1993 [[Commission for Racial Equality]] [[Race in the Media Award]] (for ''Sweet Thames'') *1994 [[David Higham Prize for Fiction]] (for ''The Longest Memory'') *1994 [[Whitbread Awards|Whitbread First Novel Award]] (for ''The Longest Memory'') *1996 [[Literature of Guyana|Guyana Prize for Literature]] (for ''Dear Future'') *1997 Shortlisted for the [[James Tait Black Memorial Prize|James Tait Black Memorial Prize (for fiction)]] (for ''Feeding the Ghosts'') *2009 T.S. Eliot Prize (Shortlist) == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{British council|id=fred-daguiar|name=Fred D'Aguiar}} *[http://www.poetryarchive.org/poetryarchive/singlePoet.do?poetId=137 Fred D'Aguiar at The Poetry Archive] *[http://www.poetrykit.org/iv/daguiar.htm The Poetry Kit Interviews Fred D'Aguiar] *[http://www.poetrykit.org/magazine/poems2.htm#daguiar "The Peacock" (poem)] *[http://thisibelieve.org/essay/8447/ Fred D'Aguiar at This I Believe: "Dance Is Life", as heard on ''The Bob Edwards Show'', 30 March 2012.] * [http://www.raintaxi.com/the-story-in-history-an-interview-with-fred-daguiar/ The Story in History: An Interview with Fred D'Aguiar] at [[Rain Taxi]] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:D'Aguiar, Fred}} [[Category:1960 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century British novelists]] [[Category:21st-century British novelists]] [[Category:Academics of Durham University]] [[Category:Academics of Newcastle University]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Cambridge]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Birmingham]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Kent]] [[Category:Bates College faculty]] [[Category:Black British writers]] [[Category:British dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:British male dramatists and playwrights]] [[Category:British male novelists]] [[Category:British male poets]] [[Category:British poets]] [[Category:English people of Guyanese descent]] [[Category:English teachers]] [[Category:Guyanese novelists]] [[Category:Guyanese writers]] [[Category:University of Miami faculty]] [[Category:Virginia Tech faculty]] [[Category:Writing teachers]] [[Category:20th-century British male writers]] [[Category:21st-century British male writers]]

{{Infobox school |name = General Assembly |logo = General Assembly logo.svg |city = {{hlist|[[San Francisco|San Francisco, California]]|[[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]]|[[New York City|New York City, New York]]|[[Austin|Austin, Texas]]|[[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]]|[[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]]|[[Los Angeles|Los Angeles, California]]|[[Washington DC|Washington, DC]]|[[London|London, England]]|[[Hong Kong|Hong Kong, China]]|[[Sydney|Sydney, Australia]]}} |type = [[Private school|Private]] |established = 2011 |faculty = |website= {{url|https://generalassemb.ly}} |founders = Jake Schwartz, Adam Pritzker, Matthew Brimer, and Brad Hargreaves |campus = [[urban area|Urban]] }}
'''General Assembly''' is a private, for-profit education organization founded by CEO Jake Schwartz, [[Adam Pritzker]], Matthew Brimer, and Brad Hargreaves in early 2011. It maintains campuses in numerous countries throughout the world to teach entrepreneurs and business professionals practical technology skills.<ref name="Forbes">{{cite news | last=Pozin| first=Ilya| title =20 Entrepreneurs Shaking Up New York's Tech Scene| newspaper =| location = | pages = | language = | publisher = ''[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]''| date =13 November 2014 | url =https://www.forbes.com/sites/ilyapozin/2014/09/13/20-entrepreneurs-shaking-up-new-yorks-tech-scene/#30d008dc2260| accessdate =10 November 2016}}</ref> It provides courses in mobile and web development, data science, product management, and other digital-related courses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.coursereport.com/schools/general-assembly#/courses|title=Course Report: General Assembly|last=|first=|date=|website=Course Report|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=February 14, 2017}}</ref>
== History == General Assembly began in early 2011 as a [[co-working]] space in [[Midtown Manhattan]], and evolved into a private school.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/01/24/nyc-general-assembly-200k-grant/|title=General Assemb.ly Scores $200,000 Grant To School Big Apple Entrepreneurs – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> It built its first campus in the [[Flatiron District]] with a grant from the [[New York City Economic Development Corporation]]. <ref>Donna Fenn, [http://www.inc.com/30under30/donna-fenn/adam-pritzker-matthew-brimer-brad-hargreaves-founders-general-assembly.html "30 Under 30 2012: Where Entrepreneurs Teach & Students Learn Skills"], ''[[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]]'', July 2, 2012.</ref> In 2015 the company raised $70 million in [[venture capital]] funding. <ref>Douglas MacMillan, [https://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2015/09/30/boom-time-bet-tech-school-general-assembly-raises-70-million/ "Tech-Boom Bet: Coding School General Assembly Raises $70 Million"], blog, ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'', September 30, 2015.</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/09/30/general-assembly-raises-70-million-closing-in-on-25000-alumni-worldwide/|title=General Assembly Raises $70 Million, Closing In On 25,000 Alumni Worldwide – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> {{As of|2016|09}}, General Assembly has 15 campus locations on 4 continents <ref>[https://generalassemb.ly/locations General Assembly locations]</ref> and planned to expand in [[Silicon Valley]] or near [[San Jose, California|San Jose]]<ref name="Chron" /> and possibly in [[Miami]].<ref>Brian Bandell, [http://www.bizjournals.com/southflorida/news/2016/09/29/exclusive-coding-school-seeks-incentives-to-create.html "Coding school seeks incentives to create 46 jobs in Miami"], ''[[The Business Journals|South Florida Business Journal]]'', September 29, 2016.</ref>
In April 2018, human resources services company [[The Adecco Group|Adecco Group]] announced they were acquiring General Assembly for $413 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2018/04/15/new-yorks-programming-ed-tech-startup-general-assembly-sells-to-adecco-for-413-million/|title=New York’s programming ed tech startup, General Assembly, sells to Adecco for $413 million – TechCrunch|website=techcrunch.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>
==Course Offerings== General Assembly focuses on offering short courses, online classes (including overnight courses and free short online courses), and immersive 10- and 12- week '[[boot-camp]]' style courses in computer programming, data science, and product management, with an emphasis on [[web development]] and [[user experience design]].<ref>Nick Toscano, [http://www.skilledup.com/articles/the-ultimate-guide-to-coding-bootcamps-the-exhaustive-list/ The Ultimate Guide to Coding Bootcamps: The Exhaustive List], [[SkilledUp]], September 6, 2013.</ref><ref>Jordan Minor, [https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2493691,00.asp "General Assembly Dash"], ''[[PC magazine]]'', October 27, 2015.</ref> Approximately 20% of its courses are offered through companies to their employees.<ref name=Chron>Kathleen Pender, [http://www.sfchronicle.com/business/networth/article/General-Assembly-trims-staff-plans-Silicon-8411911.php "General Assembly trims staff, plans Silicon Valley campus"], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', July 25, 2016.</ref> In 2016 it worked with accounting firms to develop a framework for assessing student outcomes that it itends to market to other private educational institutions.<ref>Marguerite McNeal, [https://www.edsurge.com/news/2016-05-03-general-assembly-releases-framework-for-reporting-student-outcomes "General Assembly Releases Framework for Reporting Student Outcomes"], ''[[EdSurge]]'', May 3, 2016.</ref>
General Assembly is not accredited but has been approved by the [[California Bureau for Private Postsecondary Education]].<ref name="Chron" /> The organization was last ranked on [[SwitchUp.org]], a third-party verified review site, with an alumni score of 4.2 out of 5 stars<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.switchup.org/bootcamps/general-assembly|title=General Assembly|last=SwitchUp|website=www.switchup.org|access-date=2018-04-16}}</ref>.
Local General Assembly branches have participated in training the homeless.<ref>Monica Nickelsburg, [http://www.geekwire.com/2016/street-software-non-profit-helps-previously-homeless-men-women-start-coding-careers/ "From street to software: This non-profit helps previously homeless men and women start coding careers"], ''[[GeekWire]]'', September 27, 2016.</ref> On [[Women's Equality Day]] in 2016 the company launched a [[hashtag]] campaign, #ilooklikeadeveloper, and scheduled events around the world focusing on women in computing.<ref>Tajha Chappellet-Lanier, [http://technical.ly/dc/2016/09/01/general-assembly-show-developers-really-look-like/ "General Assembly is out to show you what developers really look like"], Technical.ly DC, September 1, 2016.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://generalassemb.ly/ General Assembly official website]
[[Category:Coding schools]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Manhattan]] [[Category:Organizations based in New York City]]

revision.text:
'''Grace de Laguna''' (28 September 1878 – 17 February 1978<ref>{{Cite journal|title=De Laguna, Grace Mead (1878-1978), philosopher {{!}} American National Biography|url=http://www.anb.org/view/10.1093/anb/9780198606697.001.0001/anb-9780198606697-e-2001773|language=en|doi=10.1093/anb/9780198606697.001.0001/anb-9780198606697-e-2001773}}</ref>) was an American philosopher who taught at [[Bryn Mawr College]] in [[Pennsylvania]].
Grace Mead Andrus, as she was born, was of [[Connecticut]] ancestry, her father Wallace R. Andrus, having served in the 17th Connecticut Volunteers in the [[American Civil War|Civil War]]; he was later a land agent for the [[Northern Pacific Railway]]. Her mother was Annis Mead. She was raised in the [[Oregon Territory]].
She attended the [[Sage School of Philosophy]] at [[Cornell University]], where she received her Ph.D. and met [[Theodore de Laguna]], an instructor there, whom she married.
Grace and Theodore both taught philosophy for many years at Bryn Mawr, starting in 1907. She became chair of philosophy at Bryn Mawr after Theodore's death in 1930.
In the 1940s, she accompanied her daughter, the anthropologist [[Frederica de Laguna]], on anthropological field trips in [[Arizona]] and among the [[Salish people|Salish]] people of the Pacific Northwest.
==Bibliography== * de Laguna, Frederica (2004) "Becoming an Anthropologist: My Debt to European and Other Scholars Who Influenced Me." In: ''Coming to Shore: Northwest Coast Ethnology, Traditions, and Visions,'' ed. by Marie Mauzé, Michael E. Harkin, and Sergei Kan, pp. 23–52. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. * de Laguna, Grace (1966) ''On Existence and the Human World.'' New Haven: Yale University Press. * Stearns, Isabel S., 'Grace Andrus de Laguna 1878-1978', ''Proceedings and Addresses of the American Philosophical Association'' 51:5 (1978), 577-578
== References == <references /> == External Links ==
* ''[https://www.nytimes.com/1978/02/25/archives/obituary-4-no-title.html GRACE MEAD ANDRUS DE LAGUNA] [[The New York Times|New York Times]] obituary, 25 February 1978''

{{For|the English journalist|Helen Lewis (journalist)}} {{Use British English|date=November 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Helen Lewis | image = Helen Lewis.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Helena Katz | birth_date = 22 June 1916{{cite news | url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/dance-obituaries/6998609/Helen-Lewis.html | title=Obituary: Helen Lewis | work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] | date=15 January 2010 | accessdate=23 January 2013 | location=London}} | birth_place = [[Trutnov]], [[Bohemia]] | death_date ={{Death date and age|2009|12|31|1916|06|22}} | death_place = [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland | nationality = | other_names = Helena Hermann | spouse = Paul Hermann (1938–45; his death)
Harry Lewis (1947–91; his death) |children = Two sons:
Michael Lewis
Robin Lewis | occupation = [[dance teacher]], [[choreographer]] | known_for = ''A Time to Speak'', [[autobiography]] }} '''Helen Lewis''' [[MBE]] (''née'' Katz, [[Trutnov]], [[Bohemia]], 22 June 1916 – [[Belfast]], Northern Ireland, 31 December 2009) was a pioneer of [[modern dance]] in [[Northern Ireland]], and made her name as a dance teacher and [[Choreography (dance)|choreographer]]. A [[List of Holocaust survivors|survivor of the Holocaust]], she was also known for her [[memoir]] of her experiences during the [[Second World War]]. ==Early life== Helena Katz was born in 1916 into a [[German language|German-speaking]] Jewish family in [[Trutnov]] in [[Bohemia]] (later in [[Czechoslovakia]], now in the [[Czech Republic]]). After she completed study at the [[Realgymnasium]] of Trutnov in 1935, she and her mother moved to [[Prague]]; her father had died in the previous year.{{r|jstor}} There she studied [[ballet|dance]] with {{Interlanguage link multi|Milča Mayerová|cz}}, who had trained with [[Rudolf Laban]]. Katz also studied philosophy at the [[German University of Prague]], and took private lessons in French. In about 1936 she met Paul Hermann, a [[Czech people|Czech]] from a Jewish family, and in 1938, after she had finished her dance training and her university exams, they were married. She taught as an assistant at Mayerová's dance school, and experimented with [[choreography]].{{r|jstor}} ==War years== Following the [[German occupation of Czechoslovakia|invasion of Czechoslovakia]] in 1939, [[deportation]]s of Jewish families began in August 1941. The Hermanns were sent in 1942 to [[Theresienstadt concentration camp|Terezín]]; in 1944 they were transferred to [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]] and separated. Paul Hermann died in 1945 on a [[forced march]], not long before the end of the Second World War.{{r|jstor}} Helen, who survived two "selections" by Dr [[Josef Mengele]],{{cite news | url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/survivor-of-auschwitz-death-camp-helen-lewis-dies-at-93-28509130.html | title=Survivor of Auschwitz death camp Helen Lewis dies at 93 | work=[[Belfast Telegraph]] | date=2 January 2010 | accessdate=7 January 2016 | author=Henry, Lesley-Anne}} was later sent to [[Stutthof concentration camp]] in northern [[Poland]]. When the war ended, she returned to Prague, where she learnt of her husband's death; her mother, who had been deported early in 1942,{{r|jstor}} had died at [[Sobibór extermination camp]]. Helen began to correspond with Harry Lewis, a Czech with British nationality whom she had known at school and with whom she had had a brief romance before she met Hermann.{{r|jstor}} She married Lewis in Prague in the summer of 1947 and in October moved to [[Belfast]]. ==Belfast== After the birth of her two sons, Michael and Robin, in 1949 and 1954,{{r|jstor}} Lewis began to work as a choreographer. In 1956, she created the choreography for the productions ''[[The Bartered Bride]]'' of [[Smetana]] at [[Grosvenor High School]] in Belfast, for a performance of [[Dvořák]]'s ''[[The Golden Spinning Wheel (Dvořák)|The Golden Spinning Wheel]]'' at the [[Belfast Ballet Club]], and for a ''[[Macbeth]]'' at the [[Lyric Theatre, Belfast]]. Lewis also taught modern dance, and in 1962 started the Belfast Modern Dance Group.{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2010/mar/17/helen-lewis-obituary | title=Helen Lewis obituary | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=17 March 2010 | accessdate=22 April 2015 | author=Johnston, Philip}} Her book ''A Time to Speak'', about her experiences before and during the war, was published in 1992{{r|helen}} and was translated into several languages.{{cite web | url=http://www.culturenorthernireland.org/features/performing-arts/helen-lewis-1916-2009 | title=Helen Lewis, 1916–2009 | publisher=[[Culture Northern Ireland]] | date=January 2010 | accessdate=20 February 2016}} It was adapted for the theatre by [[Sam McCready (actor)|Sam McCready]] and performed at the Lyric Theatre during the [[Belfast Festival at Queen's|Belfast Festival]] in 2009.{{cite web | url=http://www.culturenorthernireland.org/features/performing-arts/belfast-festival-time-speak | title=Belfast Festival: A Time To Speak | publisher=[[Culture Northern Ireland]] | work=Performing Arts | date=8 September 2009 | accessdate=22 April 2015 | author=Coyle, Jane}} It was also performed at [[Exeter Synagogue]] in 2010.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/devon/hi/people_and_places/religion_and_ethics/newsid_8612000/8612422.stm | title=Exeter Synagogue stages Holocaust survival story | work=[[BBC News]] | date=13 April 2010 | accessdate=27 May 2016 | author=Lawrence, Danny}} She died in Belfast on 31 December 2009, aged 93.{{cite news | url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/2010/helen-lewis/ | title=Helen Lewis | work=[[The Stage]] | date=11 January 2010 | accessdate=10 April 2016 | author=Coyle, Jane}}{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/northern_ireland/8436948.stm | title=Belfast Auschwitz survivor Helen Lewis dies aged 93 | work=[[BBC News]] | date=1 January 2010 | accessdate=23 January 2013}} A [[dance studio]] at the [[Crescent Arts Centre]] in Belfast is named after her.{{cite web | url=http://www.crescentarts.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3&Itemid=104 | title=Helen Lewis Dance Studio | publisher=[[Crescent Arts Centre]] | work=Room hire | accessdate=15 September 2016}} ==Awards== In the [[2001 Birthday Honours]], Helen Lewis was awarded an [[Order of the British Empire|MBE]] for her services to [[contemporary dance]].{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/northern_ireland/1390386.stm | title=Knighthood for 'golden' flautist (Northern Ireland's Queen's birthday honours list)| work=[[BBC News]] | date=16 June 2011 | accessdate=23 January 2013}} She was awarded [[honorary doctorates]] by Queen's University, Belfast and by [[Ulster University]]. ==References== {{Reflist|refs= Lewis, Helen (1992). ''A Time To Speak''. Belfast: [[Blackstaff Press]]. {{ISBN|978-0-8564-0491-7}}. Lewis, Helen (2002). [https://www.jstor.org/stable/30057194 An Irish Epilogue]. ''Irish Pages'' '''1''' (1): 25–30. {{subscription required}} }} ==Further reading== * [[Dermot Keogh|Keogh, Dermot]] (1998). ''Jews in Twentieth-Century Ireland: Refugees, Anti-Semitism and the Holocaust''. [[Cork University Press]], 336 pp. {{ISBN|1-85918-150-3}} * Lewis, Helen (1992). ''A Time To Speak''. Belfast: [[Blackstaff Press]], 132 pp. {{ISBN|978-0-8564-0491-7}} ==External links== *[http://archive.northernvisions.org/related/women/i-remember-the-holocaust-helen-lews/ Lewis, Helen. ''I Remember the Holocaust'' (video made in 2000 by MediaAble Productions). Northern Visions Archive] *[http://hmd.org.uk/resources/books-for-adults/time-speak-helen-lewis/ For educators: ''A Time to Speak'' – Helen Lewis. Holocaust Memorial Day Trust] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lewis, Helen}} [[Category:1916 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Auschwitz concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:British choreographers]] [[Category:Czech female dancers]] [[Category:Czech Jews]] [[Category:Dance teachers]] [[Category:Members of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Modern dancers]] [[Category:People associated with Queen's University Belfast]] [[Category:People associated with Ulster University]] [[Category:People from Trutnov]] [[Category:Stutthof concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Theresienstadt concentration camp survivors]] [[Category:Women choreographers]] [[Category:Women in World War II]]

{{for|the British Olympic cross-country skier|Jean Watson (cross-country skier)}} '''Jean Watson''' is an American [[nurse]] [[nursing theory|theorist]] and nursing professor who is best known for her '''Theory of human caring'''. She is the author of numerous texts, including ''Nursing: The Philosophy and Science of Caring.'' Watson's research on caring has been incorporated into education and patient care at hundreds of nursing schools and healthcare facilities across the world.{{cite web | last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title = Global Caring Connections| work =| publisher = CU College of Nursing| date =| url = http://www.ucdenver.edu/about/newsroom/newsreleases/Pages/Former-CU-College-of-Nursing-Dean-Jean-Watson-honored.aspx | format =| doi = | accessdate = June 22, 2012}} ==Early life== Watson was born on June 10, 1940 in Williamson, [[West Virginia]]. ==Education== Jean Watson graduated from the Lewis Gale School of Nursing in [[Roanoke, Virginia]], in 1961. She continued her nursing studies at the [[University of Colorado at Boulder]], earning a B.S. in 1964, an M.S. in [[psychiatric and mental health nursing]] in 1966, and a Ph.D. in educational psychology and counseling in 1973. She has been awarded nine honorary doctoral degrees in six countries.{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Jean Watson, PhD, RN, AHN-BC, FAAN |work= |publisher=Watson Caring Science Institute |date= |url=http://www.watsoncaringscience.org/index.cfm/feature/278_34/jean-watson-phd-rn-ahn-bc-faan.cfm |format= |doi= |accessdate=June 22, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Caring Theory== Watson developed the Theory of Human Caring. She founded the non-profit [http://www.watsoncaringscience.org Watson Caring Science Institute] in 2008. Theory of Human Caring defined..... ==Academic appointments== Watson is a Distinguished Professor of Nursing at the [[University of Colorado]],{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=14th International IONS Conference |work= |publisher=Institute of Noetic Sciences |date= |url=http://noetic.org/conference/presenters/jean-watson/ |format= |doi= |accessdate=June 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120512104401/http://noetic.org/conference/presenters/jean-watson/ |archivedate=May 12, 2012 |df= }} where she formerly served as Dean of Nursing. ==Leadership achievements== She is a past president of the [[National League for Nursing]]. ==Honors and awards== * 1999: Norman Cousins Award, Fetzer Institute ==Works== {{cite book | last = Watson | first = Jean | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Inside Stories: Tales of Change and Growth | publisher = Lion UK| series = | volume = | edition = | date = 2003 | location = | pages = | language = | url = https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Inside_Stories.html?id=dgwJAAAACAAJ| doi =| id =| isbn = 0745948162| mr =| zbl =| jfm = }}
{{cite book | last = Bevis | first = Em Olivia | last2 = Watson | first2 = Jean | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Toward a Caring Curriculum: A New Pedagogy for Nursing | publisher = Jones and Bartlett | series = | volume = | edition = | date = 2000 | location = | pages = | language =| url = https://books.google.com/books?id=lA0IAAAACAAJ&dq=toward+a+caring+curriculum&hl=en&sa=X&ei=HyLkT42yIeLc0QH0gKGRCg&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA | doi =| id =| isbn = 0745948162| mr =| zbl =| jfm = }}
{{cite book | last= Watson | first = Jean | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Nursing: The Philosophy and Science of Caring|publisher = Little, Brown and Co. | series = | volume = | edition = | date = 1979 | location = | pages = | language = | url = https://books.google.com/books/about/Nursing.html?id=awZtAAAAMAAJ| doi =| id =| isbn = 0316924644| mr =| zbl =| jfm = }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Watson, Jean}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1940s births]] [[Category:American nurses]] [[Category:American women nurses]] [[Category:Nursing school deans]] [[Category:Nursing educators]] [[Category:Nursing researchers]] [[Category:Psychiatric nurses]] [[Category:Nursing theorists]] [[Category:University of Colorado Boulder alumni]] [[Category:University of Colorado faculty]] [[Category:American academic administrators]]

{{Infobox scientist |name = Jerome Bruner |image=Jerome Bruner 1936.png |image_size=170px |caption=Bruner pictured in the ''Chanticleer'' 1936, as a junior at Duke University |birth_name=Jerome Seymour Bruner |birth_date = October 1, 1915 |birth_place = [[New York City, New York]], [[United States]] |death_date = June 5, 2016 (aged 100) |death_place = Manhattan, [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] |residence = [[New York City]], [[United States]] |citizenship = | thesis_title = A psychological analysis of international radio broadcasts of belligerent nations | thesis_url = http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/003824672/catalog | thesis_year =1941 | doctoral_advisor=[[Gordon Allport]] | alma_mater = {{Plainlist| * [[Duke University]] * [[Harvard University]]}} | workplaces = {{Plainlist| * [[Harvard University]] * [[New York University]] * [[University of Oxford]]}} |doctoral_students = [[Susan Carey]]
[[Howard Gardner]]
[[Edward E. Jones]]
[[Alan M. Leslie]]
[[Dan Slobin]]
[[Roy Pea]]
[[Molly Potter]]
[[Andrew N. Meltzoff]]
[[Alison Gopnik]] |nationality = [[United States|American]] |ethnicity = |field = [[Psychology]] |known_for = Contributions to [[cognitive psychology]] and [[educational psychology]]
Coining the term "[[Instructional scaffolding|scaffolding]]" |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Balzan Prize]] (1987), CIBA Gold Medal for Distinguished Research Distinguished Scientific Award of the American Psychological Association |religion = |footnotes = |signature = | website = {{URL|http://www.psych.nyu.edu/bruner/}} }} '''Jerome Seymour Bruner''' (October 1, 1915 – June 5, 2016) was an American [[psychologist]] who made significant contributions to human [[cognitive psychology]] and [[cognitive]] [[learning theory (education)|learning theory]] in [[educational psychology]]. Bruner was a senior research fellow at the [[New York University School of Law]].{{cite web|url=http://www.law.nyu.edu/news/in-memoriam-jerome-bruner|title=In Memoriam: Jerome Bruner, 1915–2016|website=nyu.edu}} He received a [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in 1937 from [[Duke University]] and a [[Ph.D.]] from [[Harvard University]] in 1941.{{cite web|last=President and Fellows of Harvard College|title=About the Department|url=http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k3007&pageid=icb.page19708&pageContentId=icb.pagecontent44003&view=view.do&viewParam_name=bruner.html|year=2007|publisher=The Department of Psychology, Harvard University|accessdate=15 December 2011}}{{cite journal|last1=Greenfield|first1=Patricia Marks|title=Jerome Bruner (1915–2016) Psychologist who shaped ideas about perception, cognition and education|journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]]|volume=535|issue=7611|year=2016|pages=232–232|publisher=[[Springer Nature]]|doi=10.1038/535232a|location=London}}{{cite web|url=http://www.psych.nyu.edu/bruner|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305013706/http://www.psych.nyu.edu/bruner/|archivedate=2016-03-05|title=NYU Psychology, Jerome Bruner, Research Professor of Psychology|publisher=New York University|website=nyu.edu}} A ''[[Review of General Psychology]]'' survey, published in 2002, ranked Bruner as the 28th most cited psychologist of the 20th century.{{cite journal |last=Haggbloom |first=Steven J. |last2=''et al.'' |title=The 100 most eminent psychologists of the 20th century |journal=Review of General Psychology |volume=6 |issue=2 |year=2002 |pages=139–152 |doi=10.1037/1089-2680.6.2.139 |url=http://www.apa.org/monitor/julaug02/eminent.aspx |first2=Renee |last3=Warnick |first3=Jason E. |last4=Jones |first4=Vinessa K. |last5=Yarbrough |first5=Gary L. |last6=Russell |first6=Tenea M. |last7=Borecky |first7=Chris M. |last8=McGahhey |first8=Reagan |last9=Powell |first9=John L., III| displayauthors = 8 }} == Education and early life == Bruner was born blind (due to cataracts) on October 1, 1915, in [[New York City]], to Herman and Rose Bruner, who were [[Poles|Polish]] Jewish immigrants.{{cite book|last=Bourgoin|first=Suzan Michele|title=Encyclopedia of World Biography|year=1997|publisher=Gale|isbn=0-7876-2549-3}}Schudel, Matt (2016). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/jerome-s-bruner-influential-psychologist-of-perception-dies-at-100/2016/06/07/033e5870-2cc3-11e6-9b37-42985f6a265c_story.html Jerome S. Bruner, influential psychologist of perception, dies at 100]. The Washington Post, June 7, 2016 An operation at age 2 restored his vision. He received a bachelor's of arts degree in Psychology, in 1937 from Duke University, and went on to earn a master's degree in Psychology in 1939 and then a doctorate in Psychology in 1941 from Harvard University.{{cite thesis |degree=PhD |first=Jerome Seymour |last=Bruner |title=A psychological analysis of international radio broadcasts of belligerent nations. |publisher=Harvard University |date=1941 |url=http://id.lib.harvard.edu/aleph/003824672/catalog |oclc=83325571}} In 1939, Bruner published his first psychological article on the effect of [[thymus]] extract on the sexual behavior of the female [[rat]].{{cite book|last=Palmer|first=Joy|title=Fifty Modern Thinkers on Education: From Piaget to the Present|year=2001|publisher=Taylor & Francis Inc.|isbn=0-415-22409-8}} During World War II, Bruner served on the [[Psychological Warfare Division]] of the [[Supreme Headquarters Allied Expeditionary Force]] committee under General [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], researching social psychological phenomena.{{YouTube|xxn6IpAJEz8|Bruner in Inside the Psychologist's Studio}} (interview March 2, 2013) == Career and research == In 1945, Bruner returned to Harvard as a psychology professor and was heavily involved in research relating to cognitive psychology and educational psychology. In 1970, Bruner left Harvard to teach at the [[University of Oxford]] in the [[United Kingdom]]. He returned to the United States in 1980, to continue his research in developmental psychology. In 1991, Bruner joined the faculty at New York University (NYU), where he taught primarily in the School of Law.{{Cite journal|last=Bruner|first=Jerome|date=Winter 2004|title=A Short History of Psychological Theories of Learning|jstor=20027892|journal=Daedalus|publisher=[[MIT Press]] on behalf of American Academy of Arts & Sciences|volume=133| issue = 1|pages=13–20S}} As an adjunct professor at NYU School of Law, Bruner studied how psychology affects legal practice. During his career, Bruner was awarded honorary doctorates from [[Yale University]], [[Columbia University]], [[The New School]], the [[Sorbonne]], the ISPA Instituto Universitário, as well as colleges and universities in such locations as [[Berlin]] and [[Rome]], and was a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]. He [[centenarian|turned 100]] in October 2015{{cite web|last = Popova|first = Maria|authorlink = Maria Popova|title = Pioneering Psychologist Jerome Bruner on the Act of Discovery and the Key to True Learning|website = BrainPickings.org|date = 2015-10-01|url = https://www.brainpickings.org/2015/10/01/jerome-bruner-act-of-discovery/|accessdate = 2015-10-03}} and died on June 5, 2016.Benedict Carey. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/06/09/science/jerome-s-bruner-who-shaped-understanding-of-the-young-mind-dies-at-100.html Jerome S. Bruner, Who Shaped Understanding of the Young Mind, Dies at 100]", ''The New York Times'', June 8, 2016. Accessed June 9, 2016. === Cognitive psychology === {{Main|Cognitive psychology}} Bruner is one of the pioneers of [[Cognitive revolution|cognitive psychology]] in the United States, which began through his own early research on [[sense|sensation]] and [[perception]] as being active, rather than passive processes. In 1947, Bruner published his study ''Value and Need as Organizing Factors in Perception'', in which poor and rich children were asked to estimate the size of coins or wooden disks the size of American [[penny (United States coin)|pennies]], [[nickel (United States coin)|nickels]], [[dime (United States coin)|dimes]], [[quarter (United States coin)|quarters]] and [[half dollar (United States coin)|half-dollars]]. The results showed that the value and need the poor and rich children associated with coins caused them to significantly overestimate the size of the coins, especially when compared to their more accurate estimations of the same size disks.{{cite journal|last=Bruner|first=Jerome|author2=Goodman, Cecile|title=Value and Need as Organizing Factors in Percepton|journal=Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology|year=1947|volume=42|pages=33–44|doi=10.1037/h0058484}} Similarly, another study conducted by Bruner and Leo Postman showed slower [[reaction time]]s and less accurate answers when a deck of [[playing cards]] reversed the color of the [[Suit (cards)|suit]] symbol for some cards (e.g. red spades and black hearts)."[http://psychclassics.yorku.ca/Bruner/Cards/ On the Perception of Incongruity: A Paradigm]" by Jerome S. Bruner and Leo Postman. ''Journal of Personality'', 18, pp. 206–223. 1949. These series of [[experiments]] issued in what some called the 'New Look' psychology, which challenged psychologists to study not just an organism's response to a stimulus, but also its internal interpretation. After these experiments on perception, Bruner turned his attention to the actual cognitions that he had indirectly studied in his perception studies. In 1956, Bruner published the book ''A Study of Thinking'', which formally initiated the study of cognitive psychology. Soon afterward Bruner helped found the Harvard Center of Cognitive Studies. After a time, Bruner began to research other topics in psychology, but in 1990 he returned to the subject and gave a series of lectures, later compiled into the book ''Acts of Meaning''. In these lectures, Bruner refuted the computer model for studying the [[mind]], advocating a more [[holistic]] understanding of the mind and its cognitions. === Developmental psychology === {{Main|Developmental psychology}} Beginning around 1967, Bruner turned his attention to the subject of developmental psychology and studied the way children learn. He coined the term "scaffolding" to describe the way children often build on the information they have already mastered. In his research on the development of children (1966) Bruner proposed three modes of representation: enactive representation (action-based), iconic representation (image-based), and symbolic representation (language-based). Rather than neatly delineated stages, the modes of representation are integrated and only loosely sequential as they "translate" into each other. Symbolic representation remains the ultimate mode, for it "is clearly the most mysterious of the three." Bruner's theory suggests it is efficacious, when faced with new material, to follow a progression from enactive to iconic to symbolic representation; this holds true even for adult learners. A true [[instructional design]]er, Bruner's work also suggests that a learner (even of a very young age) is capable of learning any material so long as the instruction is organized appropriately, in sharp contrast to the beliefs of [[Jean Piaget|Piaget]] and other stage theorists. (Driscoll, Marcy). Like [[Bloom's Taxonomy]], Bruner suggests a system of coding in which people form a [[hierarchical]] arrangement of related categories. Each successively higher level of categories becomes more specific, echoing [[Benjamin Bloom]]'s understanding of knowledge acquisition as well as the related idea of [[instructional scaffolding]]. In accordance with this understanding of learning, Bruner proposed the [[spiral curriculum]], a teaching approach in which each subject or skill area is revisited at intervals, at a more sophisticated level each time. First there is basic knowledge of a subject, then more sophistication is added, reinforcing principles that were first discussed. This system is used in China and India. Bruner's spiral curriculum, however, draws heavily from evolution to explain how to learn better and thus it drew criticism from conservatives. In the United States classes are split by grade—life sciences in 9th grade, chemistry in 10th, physics in 11th. The spiral teaches life sciences, chemistry, physics all in one year, then two subjects, then one, then all three again to understand how they mold together.{{cite web|url=http://gearup.ous.edu/sites/default/files/Research-Briefs/ResearchBriefSpiralCurriculum.pdf|title=The Spiral Curriculum|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221223911/http://gearup.ous.edu/sites/default/files/Research-Briefs/ResearchBriefSpiralCurriculum.pdf|archivedate=2014-02-21|df=}} Bruner also believes learning should be spurred by interest in the material rather than tests or punishment, since one learns best when one finds the acquired knowledge appealing. === Educational psychology === {{Main|Educational psychology}} While Bruner was at Harvard he published a series of works about his assessment of current educational systems and ways that education could be improved. In 1961, he published the book ''Process of Education''. Bruner also served as a member of the Educational Panel of the President's Science Advisory Committee during the presidencies of John F. Kennedy and Lyndon Johnson. Referencing his overall view that education should not focus merely on memorizing facts, Bruner wrote in ''Process of Education'' that "knowing how something is put together is worth a thousand facts about it." From 1964–1996 Bruner sought to develop a complete curriculum for the educational system that would meet the needs of students in three main areas which he called [[Man: A Course of Study]]. Bruner wanted to create an educational environment that would focus on (1) what was uniquely human about human beings, (2) how humans got that way and (3) how humans could become more so. In 1966, Bruner published another book relevant to education, ''Towards a Theory of Instruction,'' and then in 1973, another book, ''The Relevance of Education.'' Finally, in 1996, in ''The Culture of Education,'' Bruner reassessed the state of educational practices three decades after he had begun his educational research. Bruner was also credited with helping found the Head Start early childcare program.{{cite web|last=Bruner|first=Jerome|title=NYU Faculty Page|url=https://its.law.nyu.edu/facultyprofiles/profile.cfm?section=bio&personID=19807|accessdate=2 December 2011}} Bruner was deeply impressed by his 1995 visit to the preschools of [[Reggio Emilia]] and has established a collaborative relationship with them to improve educational systems internationally. Equally important was the relationship with the Italian Ministry of Education which officially recognized the value of this innovative experience. === Language development === {{Main|Language development}} In 1972, Bruner was appointed Watts Professor of Experimental Psychology at the [[University of Oxford]], where he remained until 1980. In his Oxford years, Bruner focused on early [[language development]]. Rejecting the [[Universal grammar|nativist]] account of [[language acquisition]] proposed by [[Noam Chomsky]], Bruner offered an alternative in the form of an [[interactionist]] or [[social interactionist theory]] of language development. In this approach, the social and interpersonal nature of language was emphasized, appealing to the work of philosophers such as [[Ludwig Wittgenstein]], [[John L. Austin]] and [[John Searle]] for theoretical grounding.{{citation needed|date=November 2014}} Following [[Lev Vygotsky]] the Russian theoretician of socio-cultural development, Bruner proposed that social interaction plays a fundamental role in the development of cognition in general and of language in particular. He emphasized that children learn language in order to communicate, and, at the same time, they also learn the linguistic code. Meaningful language is acquired in the context of meaningful parent-infant interaction, learning "scaffolded" or supported by the child's language acquisition support system (LASS). At Oxford Bruner worked with a large group of graduate students and post-doctoral fellows to understand how young children manage to crack the linguistic code, among them Alison Garton, [[Alison Gopnik]], Magda Kalmar ([[:hu:Kalmár Magda (pszichológus)|Kalmár Magda]]), [[Alan Leslie]], [[Andrew Meltzoff]], [[Anat Ninio]], [[Roy Pea]], Susan Sugarman,{{cite web |url=http://psych.princeton.edu/psychology/research/sugarman/cv.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130107055216/http://psych.princeton.edu/psychology/research/sugarman/cv.php |archivedate=2013-01-07 |df= }} Michael Scaife, Marian Sigman,{{cite web|url=http://portal.ctrl.ucla.edu/npi/institution/personnel?personnel_id=9737|title=Faculty Database – David Geffen School of Medicine at UCLA|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121215032055/http://portal.ctrl.ucla.edu/npi/institution/personnel?personnel_id=9737|archivedate=2012-12-15|df=}} Kathy Sylva and many others. Much emphasis was placed on employing the then-revolutionary method of videotaped home-observations, Bruner showing the way to a new wave of researchers to get out of the laboratory and take on the complexities of naturally occurring events in a child's life. This work was published in a large number of journal articles, and in 1983 Bruner published a summary in the book ''Child's talk: Learning to Use Language''. This decade of research established Bruner at the helm of the interactionist approach to language development, exploring such themes as the acquisition of communicative intents and the development of their linguistic expression, the interactive context of language use in early childhood, and the role of parental input and scaffolding behavior in the acquisition of linguistic forms. This work rests on the assumptions of a [[social constructivist]] theory of meaning according to which meaningful participation in the social life of a group as well as meaningful use of language involve an interpersonal, intersubjective, collaborative process of creating shared meaning. The elucidation of this process became the focus of Bruner's next period of work. === Narrative construction of reality === In 1980, Bruner returned to the United States, taking up the position of professor at the [[New School for Social Research]] in [[New York City]] in 1981. For the next decade, he worked on the development of a theory of the narrative construction of reality, culminating in several seminal publications. His book ''Actual Minds, Possible Worlds'' has been cited by over 16,100 scholarly publications, making it one of the most influential works of the 20th century. === Legal psychology === {{Main|Legal psychology}} In 1991, Bruner arrived at NYU as a visiting professor to do research and to found the Colloquium on the Theory of Legal Practice. The goal of this institution is to "study how law is practiced and how its practice can be understood by using tools developed in anthropology, psychology, linguistics, and literary theory."{{cite web|last=Bruner|first=Jerome|title=Jerome Bruner:Biography|url=https://its.law.nyu.edu/facultyprofiles/profile.cfm?section=bio&personID=19807|accessdate=2 December 2011}} == Publications == === Books === {{div col|colwidth=35em}} *{{cite book |title=A Study of Thinking |year=1956}} *{{cite book |title=The Process of Education |year=1960 |isbn=978-0-674-71001-6}} *{{cite book |title=Studies in Cognitive Growth |year=1966}} *{{cite book |title=Toward a Theory of Instruction |year=1966 |isbn=978-0-674-89701-4}} *{{cite book |title=Processes of Cognitive Growth: Infancy |year=1968}} *{{cite book |title=Beyond the Information Given: Studies in the Psychology of Knowing |publisher=W. W. Norton & Company |year=1973 |isbn=978-0-393-09363-6}} *{{cite book |title=On Knowing: Essays for the Left Hand |year=1979 |isbn=978-0-674-63525-8}} *{{cite book |title=Child's Talk: Learning to Use Language |year=1983}} *{{cite book |title=In Search of Mind: Essays in Autobiography |year=1983}} *{{cite book |title=Actual Minds, Possible Worlds |year=1985 |isbn=978-0-674-00366-8}} *{{cite book |title=The Mind of a Mnemonist: A Little Book about a Vast Memory |chapter=Foreword |year=1987 |isbn=978-0-674-57622-3}} *{{cite book |title=Acts of Meaning |year=1990 |isbn=978-0-674-00361-3}} *{{cite book |title=The Culture of Education |year=1996 |isbn=978-0-674-17953-0}} *{{cite book |title=Minding the Law |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-674-00816-8}} *{{cite book |title=Making Stories: Law, Literature, Life |year=2003 |isbn=978-0-674-01099-4}} {{div col end}} === Selected articles === {{div col|colwidth=35em}} *Bruner, J. S. & Goodman, C. C. (1947). "[http://psychclassics.yorku.ca/Bruner/Value/ Value and need as organizing factors in perception]". ''Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology'', 42, 33–44. *Bruner, J. S. & Postman, L. (1947). "Tension and tension-release as organizing factors in perception". ''Journal of Personality'', 15, 300–308. *Bruner, J. S. & Postman, L. (1949). "[http://psychclassics.yorku.ca/Bruner/Cards/ On the perception of incongruity: A paradigm]. ''Journal of Personality'', 18, 206–223. *Bruner, J. S. (1975). "The ontogenesis of speech acts". ''Journal of Child Language'', 2, 1–19. (The most cited article in the ''Journal of Child Language'') *[[Michael Scaife|Scaife, M.]], Bruner, J. S. (1975). "Capacity for joint visual attention in the infant". ''Nature'', 253, 265–266. *Bruner, J. S. (1975/76). "From communication to language: A psychological perspective". ''Cognition'', 3, 255–287. *Bruner, J. S. (1976). "Prelinguistic prerequisites of speech". In R. Campbell and P. Smith (Eds.), ''Recent Advances in the Psychology of Language'', 4a, 199–214. New York: Plenum Press. *Bruner, J. S., and Sherwood, V. (1976). "Early rule structure: The case of peekaboo". In J. S. Bruner, A. Jolly, and K. Sylva (Eds.), ''Play: Its Role in Evolution and Development''. London: Penguin Books. *Wood, D., Bruner, J., & Ross, G. (1976). "[http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1469-7610.1976.tb00381.x/pdf The role of tutoring in problem solving]". ''Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry and Allied Disciplines'', 17, 89–100. *Bruner, J. S. (1977). "Early social interaction and language acquisition". In H. R. Schaffer (Ed.), ''Studies in Mother-infant Interaction'' (pp. 271–289). London: Academic Press. *Bruner, J. S., Caudill, E. and Ninio, A. (1977). "Language and experience". In R. S. Peters (Ed.), ''John Dewey Reconsidered''. Routledge & Kegan Paul. *Ninio, A. and Bruner, J. S. (1978). "The achievement and antecedents of labelling". ''Journal of Child Language'', 5, 1–15. Reprinted in M. B. Franklin and S. S. Barten (eds.), "Child Language: A Reader" (pp. 36–49). New York: Oxford University Press (1988). *Ratner, N. and Bruner, J. S. (1978). "Games, social exchange and the acquisition of language". ''Journal of Child Language'', 5, 391–401. *Bruner, J. S. (1978). "On prelinguistic prerequisites of speech". In R. N. Campbell and P. T. Smith, (eds.), ''Recent Advances in the Psychology of Language'' (Vol. 4a. pp. 194–214). New York: Plenum Press. *Bruner, J. S. (1978). "Learning how to do things with words". In J. S. Bruner and R. A. Garton, (eds), ''Human Growth and Development'' (pp. 62–84). Oxford: Clarendon Press. *Bruner, J. S. (1978). "The role of dialogue in language acquisition". In A. Sinclair, R. J. Jarvella, and W. J. M. Levelt (Eds.), ''The Child's Conception of Language'' (pp. 241–256). New York: Springer-Verlag. *Bruner, J. S., Roy, C., and Ratner, N. (1982). "The beginnings of request". In K. E. Nelson, (Ed.), ''Children's Language'' (Vol. 3. pp. 91–138). Hillsdale, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum. *Bruner, J. S. (1983). "The acquisition of pragmatic commitments". In R.
