''Current Sociology''. 43.2, 161–177. *{{cite journal|first=Bradd|last=Shore|journal=Ethos|publisher=Wiley|title=Keeping the Conversation Going: An Interview with Jerome Bruner|volume=25|issue=1|date=March 1997|pages=7–62|jstor=640457}} *{{Cite journal|pmc=2919784|year=2008|author1=Mattingly|first1=C|title=Bruner's Search for Meaning: A Conversation between Psychology and Anthropology|journal=Ethos|volume=36|issue=1|pages=1–28|last2=Lutkehaus|first2=N. C.|last3=Throop|first3=C. J.|doi=10.1111/j.1548-1352.2008.00001.x|pmid=20706551}} {{div col end}} == See also == {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Contextualism]] * [[Constructionism (learning theory)|Constructionism]] * [[Constructivism (learning theory)|Constructivism]] * [[Cognitivism (psychology)|Cognitivism]] * [[Cognitivism (learning theory)]] * [[Cognitive linguistics]] * [[Cognitive psychology]] * [[Cognitive revolution]] * [[Narrative therapy]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist|35em}} == External links == {{sisterlinks|d=Q114867|c=Category:Jerome Bruner|n=no|q=no|b=no|v=no|voy=no|s=no|wikt=no|m=no|mw=no|species=no}} * [http://insidetheacademy.asu.edu/jerome-jerry-bruner Video interview] * {{Internet Archive author |sname=Jerome Bruner |sopt=t}} * [http://www.law.nyu.edu/news/BRUNER_ANNIVERSARY_EVENT 50th anniversary event of Bruner's] [[The Process of Education]]. April 27, 2011. {{YouTube|id=6t9DTKW4kvw#t=7072|title=Bruner's talk at 1:54:00}} * [https://howardgardner01.files.wordpress.com/2018/04/american-philosophical-society_jerome-seymour-bruner.pdf Biographical Memoir by Howard Gardner for ''Proceedings of the American Philosophical Society''] {{APA Presidents}} {{E. L. Thorndike Award |state=autocollapse}} {{Psychology}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bruner, Jerome}} [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:Developmental psychologists]] [[Category:Educational psychologists]] [[Category:Cognitive scientists]] [[Category:20th-century psychologists]] [[Category:21st-century psychologists]] [[Category:Enactive cognition]] [[Category:Cognitive development researchers]] [[Category:Consciousness researchers and theorists]] [[Category:Jewish American social scientists]] [[Category:Presidents of the American Psychological Association]] [[Category:Harvard University faculty]] [[Category:New York University School of Law faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of Wolfson College, Oxford]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Writers from New York City]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:American people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:1915 births]] [[Category:2016 deaths]]

page.title: José Vasconcelos World Award of Education

revision.text:
'''Julia Ward''' (December 1900 – June, 18 1962) was the founder of the central reference division of [[National Security Agency|National Security Agency (NSA)]]. She was inducted into the [[NSA Hall of Honor|Cryptologic Hall of Honor]] in 2002.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsa.gov/about/cryptologic-heritage/historical-figures-publications/hall-of-honor/2002/jward.shtml|title=Dr. Julia Ward (1900 - 1962) 2002 Inductee|website=www.nsa.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2002-06-14/news/0206140255_1_tevis-silent-sentinels-hall-of-honor|title=NSA belatedly recognizes six `silent sentinels'|work=tribunedigital-baltimoresun|access-date=2018-08-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://cryptologicfoundation.org/file_download/inline/1f38f96a-5734-44d8-a1ce-922c1601488c|title=The Link|last=|first=|date=|website=Cryptologic Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
== Education == Ward received her A.B. from [[Bryn Mawr College]] in 1923 and her Ph.D from Bryn Mawr College in 1940.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.brynmawr.edu/cs/history|title=History {{!}} Bryn Mawr College|website=www.brynmawr.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}}</ref>
== [[World War II]] == Dr. Ward joined the cryptologic service during WWII and worked for the Signal Security Agency (the Army's cryptologic organization). She also worked as a librarian and eventually built a collection of classified and unclassified materials for use by analysts. In 1945 she became the deputy chief of the reference section. Within a few years, she turned the section into one that was known as poorly organized, into a section that was widely recognized and highly respected.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vFYRDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT430&lpg=PT430&dq=Julia+Ward+NSA&source=bl&ots=5XAGS2slBJ&sig=kKUze03HNpORwObn2MZbXMAUbls&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwjyxI6w3evcAhWPFXwKHa06BP84ChDoATAEegQIBhAB#v=onepage&q=Julia%20Ward%20&f=false|title=Code Girls: The Untold Story of the American Women Code Breakers of World War II|last=Mundy|first=Liza|date=2017-10-10|publisher=Hachette Books|isbn=9780316352550|language=en}}</ref>
In 1949, Dr. Ward was named head of the Collateral Branch, thereby becoming the only female branch head in the Office of Operations.
Later, in 1955 Dr. Ward, was promoted to deputy chief of NSA's Liaison and Foreign Operations Section.<ref name=":0" />
== Cryptologic Hall of Honor == Dr. Julia Ward was inducted into the NSA's Cryptologic Hall of Honor in June 2002 at the National Cryptologic Museum in Baltimore, MD. Bryn Mawr College has a plague in Dr. Ward's honor to commemorate her placement in the Hall of Honor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsa.gov/about/cryptologic-heritage/historical-figures-publications/hall-of-honor/2002/|title=Hall of Honor|last=|first=|date=|website=NSA|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/readingroom/search/site/warded?page=3|title=FOIA {{!}} CIA FOIA (foia.cia.gov)|website=www.cia.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-08-14}}</ref>
== References == <references /> [[Category:Spies]] [[Category:Cryptologic education]] [[Category:Cryptographers]]

revision.text:
[[File:President Obama, teachers.jpg|thumb|300px|U.S. [[President Obama]] meets with teachers on Teachers' Day, May 2, 2011]] '''Teachers' Day''' is a special day for the appreciation of [[teachers]], and may include celebrations to honor them for their special contributions in a particular field area, or the community in general.
The idea of celebrating Teachers' Day took root in many countries during the 19th century; in most cases, they celebrate a local educator or an important milestone in education. This is the primary reason why countries celebrate this day on different dates, unlike many other International Days. For example, Argentina has commemorated [[Domingo Faustino Sarmiento]]'s death on 11 September) since 1915;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jardindeinfantesdfs.com.ar/historia.htm#El%20Maestro%20Argentino:%20Domingo%20F.%20Sarmiento|title=Historia|publisher=Jardindeinfantesdfs.com.ar|accessdate=2 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110820105920/http://www.jardindeinfantesdfs.com.ar/historia.htm#El%20Maestro%20Argentino:%20Domingo%20F.%20Sarmiento|archivedate=20 August 2011|df=}}</ref> while in India [[Guru Purnima]] is traditionally observed as a day to venerate teachers, the birthday of the second president [[Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan]] (5 September) is also celebrated as Teacher's Day since 1962.
Many countries celebrate [[World Teachers' Day]], established by [[UNESCO]] in 1994, on 5 October as their Teachers' Day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://en.unesco.org/themes/teachers/world-teachers-day|title=World Teachers' Day - 5 October 2017|website=UNESCO|language=en|access-date=2018-09-05}}</ref>
== Date by country == {{refimprove section|date=September 2016}} <!--Note: date column is sorted with a preceding {{Hs|MM-DD}} template. Unknown or variable values have been set to 00 or 99 for an approx. sorting. --> {| class="wikitable sortable" !Country !Teachers' Day<ref>Not all of these days are official holidays. Some of them are not formally named "Teachers' Day" but serve a closely-related and analogous purpose.</ref> !class="unsortable"|Notes |- |[[Afghanistan]] |{{Hs|04-23}}3 Saur<ref>{{cite web|url=https://kabulperspective.wordpress.com/2009/05/23/teachers-day-in-afghanistan/|title=Teachers’ Day in Afghanistan|author=|date=23 May 2009|website=wordpress.com|accessdate=3 April 2018}}</ref> (3 [[Ordibehesht]]<ref>Barnett R. Rubin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=laG03iJF7t8C&lpg=PA290&dq=Mir%20Akbar%20Khyber&pg=PA105#v=onepage&q&f=false ''The Fragmentation of Afghanistan''] (Yale University Press, 2002), p. 105</ref>) |Schools won't have a holiday, but students and teachers gather to celebrate at schools with special traditional food, cookies, music and presents for the teachers. |- |[[Albania]] |{{Hs|03-07}}7 March | Celebrates the opening of the first school where lessons were taught in the Albanian language, on 7 March 1887. |- |[[Algeria]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- ||[[Argentina]] |{{Hs|09-11}}11 September |In memory of [[Domingo Faustino Sarmiento|Domingo F. Sarmiento]] (February 15, 1811 – September 11, 1888). Journalist, governor of San Juan, diplomat, senator, President of Argentina.<ref>[https://cdn.educ.ar/dinamico/UnidadHtml__get__aff03953-4b46-11e1-8157-ed15e3c494af/index.html Sarmiento, sus objetivos y acciones]; accessed 10 September 2018.</ref> Made primary education compulsory, established 800 educational and military institutions including teachers' schools, founded public libraries, developed infrastructure and fostered immigration. Inspired by [[Horace Mann]], whom he befriended, brought 32 American teachers to Argentina to develop the American model of universal education. The 1943 Interamerican Conference on Education, held in [[Panama]], established September 11 as [[Americas|Panamerican]] [[Teacher's Day]]. |- |[[Armenia]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |Armenia previously celebrated Teacher's Day on the first Sunday of October. Under a parliamentary decision {{When|date=September 2015}} to amend the law on the Republic of Armenia Holidays and Commemoration Days, the holiday was shifted to 5 October, which coincides with World Teachers' Day (est. 1994 by UNESCO).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tert.am/en/news/2011/10/05/teachersday|title=October 4 World Teacher's Day|publisher=Armenian News|accessdate=9 June 2014}}</ref> |- |[[Australia]] |{{Hs|10-99}}Last Friday in October |On Australia's celebration of World Teachers’ Day, the NEiTA Foundation and the Australian Scholarships Group (ASG) is proud to announce the national teaching recipients of the ASG Community Merit Awards. World Teachers’ Day was started by UNESCO and is celebrated in more than 100 countries around the world each year. On its 40th anniversary this year, it represents a significant token of the awareness, understanding and appreciation displayed for the contribution that teachers make to education. If it falls on 31 October, coinciding with [[Halloween]], it is postponed a week, to 7 November. |- |[[Azerbaijan]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |Between 1965 and 1994, the first Sunday of October. Since 1994, on 5 October, it has coincided with World Teachers' Day on 5 October (est. 1994 by UNESCO). |- |[[Bangladesh]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Belarus]] |{{Hs|10-00}}The first Sunday of October<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://research.bsu.by/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/ukaz-president-26_03_1998-N157-ed-30_08_2012.pdf|title=УКАЗ ПРЕЗИДЕНТА РЕСПУБЛИКИ БЕЛАРУСЬ "О государственных праздниках, праздничных днях и памятных датах в Республике Беларусь"|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> | |- |[[Brunei]] |{{Hs|09-23}}23 September |To commemorate the birth date of the 28th ruler of Brunei, Sultan [[Omar Ali Saifuddien III]], also known as the 'Architect of Modern Brunei', who amongst other things emphasized the importance of education to his subjects by introducing a policy of 'free' education whereby the citizens are charged very nominal fees for attending schools. This policy has been continued and extended by the current (29th) ruler. |- |[[Bhutan]] |{{Hs|05-02}}2 May |Established and marked on the birth anniversary of the third King of Bhutan, [[Jigme Dorji Wangchuck]], who introduced modern education to the country. |- |[[Bolivia]] |{{Hs|06-06}}6 June | |- |[[Brazil]] |{{Hs|10-15}}15 October |Established by a decree regulating elementary schools in Brazil. The celebration gained popularity throughout the country, and October 15 was officially designated Teachers' Day in 1963. |- |[[Bulgaria]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |On 29 September 2006, the date of 5 October was recognized as Teacher's Day by the government.<ref>{{cite web|author=Анонимен|url=http://education.actualno.com/news_79292.html|title=5 октомври е определен за Ден на учителя|publisher=Education.actualno.com|date=29 September 2006|accessdate=5 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130313080838/http://education.actualno.com/news_79292.html|archivedate=13 March 2013|df=}}</ref> |- |[[Cameroon]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |Teachers in Cameroon on Tuesday, 5 October 2010 joined their peers worldwide to celebrate the 17th World Teachers Day. With the theme "Nation building passes through teachers", the day served as an opportunity to pay homage to teachers who toil, sometimes under not-so-comfortable conditions, to build the capacities of human resources for the socio-economic development of the country. Commemorative activities in Yaounde began on 29 September with educative talks at the Lycée Général Leclerc, and were rounded off on World Teachers Day at the Wada multi-purpose sports complex. |- |[[Canada]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |On 5 October, along with over 100 countries around the world, the Canadian Teachers’ Federation and its member organizations across the country celebrate World Teachers’ Day through a public awareness campaign that highlights the contributions of the teaching profession. |- |[[Chile]] |{{Hs|10-16}}16 October |In 1967, 11 September was selected as "Día del Maestro" ("Teacher's Day"). The date was moved to December 10 in 1975, because on that day in 1945, the Chilean poet [[Gabriela Mistral]] received the [[Nobel Prize]]. In 1977, the date was renamed to "Día del Profesor" (also "Teacher's Day") and was moved again, to 16 October, to honour the founding of the Colegio de Profesores de Chile (Teachers' Association of Chile).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.feriadoschilenos.cl/DiasNacionales.html#DiaDelMaestro|title=Días Nacionales en Chile|accessdate=8 October 2010|date=19 September 2010|language=es}}</ref> |- |[[China]] |{{Hs|09-10}}10 September |In the [[People's Republic of China]], there are some activities for students to show their appreciation to teachers, such as presenting gifts, including cards and flowers. In addition, many former students will go back to their old primary schools, middle schools and high schools to give presents to their old teachers.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
The government first proclaimed Teachers' Day in 1985, but has never clearly explained why it should fall on 10 September. Some believe it is due to the similar pronunciation between the word "teacher" (教师 jiao shi) and the two digits 9 (九jiu), 10 (十shi) in the date. Some people believe it was an arbitrary choice and have proposed to change it to 28 September, believed to be the birthdate of [[Confucius]]. On 5 September 2013, the [[State Council of the People's Republic of China|State Council]] announced a legislative draft endorsing the change.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/china/2013-09/06/c_132697316.htm|title=China mulls changing Teachers' Day to birthday of Confucius|work=Xinhua News Agency|date=6 September 2013}}</ref> |- |[[Colombia]] |{{Hs|05-15}}15 May |This day marks the appointment of [[Jean-Baptiste de La Salle|San Juan Bautista de la Salle]] as the patron of teachers. In 1950, [[Pope Pius XII]] granted his approval of La Salle as patron of teachers for championing the causes of modern education. The holy founder understood the education of children as the obligation of all. Usually the schools of his time (1651–1719) only accepted young people studying towards politics or diplomacy. Juan Bautista outlined the principles of free and universal education. That same year in Colombia, the President of the Republic declared that date as Teachers' Day. |- |[[Costa Rica]] |{{Hs|12-22}}22 December |To commemorate the birth date of [[Mauro Fernández Acuña]] (22 December 1843){{citation needed|date=November 2018}}, a reformer of Costa Rican education. |- |[[Cuba]] |{{Hs|12-22}}22 December |On 22 December 1961, Cuba declared itself a Territory Free of [[Literacy|Illiteracy]] (''Territorio Libre de Analfabetismo'') (see [[Cuban Literacy Campaign]]). |- |[[Czech Republic]] |{{Hs|03-28}}28 March |The birthday of [[John Amos Comenius]]. Czech students nominate the teachers whose approach most motivates and inspires them to the ''Zlatý Ámos'' (Golden Amos) competition. The coronation of "Golden Amos" takes place yearly on 28 March.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.zlatyamos.cz|title=Zlatý Ámos — anketa o nejoblíbenějšího učitele České republiky|accessdate=23 November 2008|publisher=Zlatý Ámos|language=cs}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adam.cz/view.php?cisloclanku=2006100402|title=Mezinárodní den učitelů a Zlatý Ámos|accessdate=23 November 2008|publisher=adam.cz|date=4 October 2006|language=cs}}</ref> |- |[[Dominican Republic]] |{{Hs|06-30}}30 June | |- |[[Ecuador]] |{{Hs|04-13}}13 April | |- |[[Egypt]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- |[[El Salvador]] |{{Hs|06-22}}22 June |Teachers' Day in El Salvador is observed as a national holiday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nuevaalejandria.com/secciones/maestros-americanos/elsalvador.php|title=Nueva Alejandría — Secciones — Maestros Americanos — El Salvador|accessdate=22 June 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.teacher-appreciation.info/Teachers_Day/El-Salvador.asp|title=TEACHER APPRECIATION: teacher appreciation poem — Teachers Day — El Salvador|accessdate=22 June 2008}}</ref> |- |[[Estonia]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |In [[Estonia]] last class students grant leave to teachers by conducting lessons themselves. |- |[[Germany]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Greece]] |{{Hs|01-30}}30 January | Derived from the Eastern Orthodox faith when the [[Three Holy Hierarchs]] and Ecumenical Teachers ([[Basil the Great]], [[Gregory the Theologian]] and [[John Chrysostom]]) are commemorated. |- |[[Guatemala]] |{{Hs|06-25}}25 June | A celebration in honour of the teacher [[María Chinchilla]] who died during a violent riot in protest against the government. |- |[[Honduras]] |{{Hs|09-17}}17 September | Celebration in honour of the life of [[José Trinidad Reyes]] |- |[[Hong Kong]] |{{Hs|09-10}}10 September |Before the [[transfer of sovereignty of Hong Kong]] in 1997, Teachers' Day was on 28 September. After the handover to the [[People's Republic of China]], the day was changed to 10 September, which is when the PRC celebrates the holiday. |- |[[Hungary]] |{{Hs|06-00}}First Sunday of June | |- |[[India]] |{{Hs|09-05}}[[Full moon]] day of ''[[Ashadha]]'' (June–July),
and
5 September |'''[[Guru Purnima]]''' is an [[India|Indian]] and [[Nepal|Nepalese]] festival dedicated to spiritual and academic teachers. This festival is traditionally celebrated by [[Hindus]], [[Jainism|Jains]] and [[Buddhists]], to pay their respects to their teachers and express their gratitude. The festival is celebrated on the [[full moon]] day (''Purnima'') in the Hindu month of ''[[Ashadha]]'' (June–July) in the [[Hindu calendar]] of [[India]] and [[Nepal]].<ref name="Sanatan">Article [http://www.sanatan.org/en/a/28_Guru poornima.html "Guru Poornima (Vyas Puja)"] As on 22 July 2013 on www.Sanatan.org</ref> This day marks the first peak of the [[lunar cycle]] after the [[Summer solstice|peak]] of the [[Season|solar cycle]].The celebration is marked by ritualistic respect to the [[Guru]], ''Guru Puja''.<ref name="Guru principle">Article [http://www.sanatan.org/en/a/34_Guru-principle.html "The Guru Principle"] As on 22 July 2013 on www.Sanatan.org</ref>
The birth date of the second President of India, Dr. [[Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan]], 5 September 1888, has been celebrated as Teacher's Day since 1962. On this day, teachers and students report to school as usual but the usual activities and classes are replaced by activities of celebration, thanks and remembrance. In some schools, senior students take the responsibility of teaching in order to show their appreciation for the teachers. |- |[[Indonesia]] |{{Hs|11-25}}25 November |National Teachers' Day is commemorated on the same day as the formation of the Indonesian Teachers' Association, the PGRI. National Teachers' Day is not a holiday, but it is celebrated by having a ceremonial activity in recognition of certain teachers, headmasters and other school staff.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} |- |[[Iran]] |{{Hs|05-02}}2 May (12 Ordibehesht) |In memory of [[Morteza Motahhari]] (January 31, 1919 – May 2, 1979). |- |[[Iraq]] |{{Hs|03-01}}1 March |National Teachers' Day in Iraq is celebrated by the students showing appreciation to their teachers by giving them presents, also it is celebrated by bringing traditional food into school and just having an open day in general. |- |[[Israel]] |{{Hs|12-01}}23 [[Kislev]] | |- |[[Jamaica]] |{{Hs|05-06}}6 May |Teachers' Day is normally celebrated on May 7 or the first Wednesday in May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/gleaner/20090506/news/news1.html|title=Gleaner gives teachers a break!|accessdate=6 May 2009}}</ref> In celebration of Teachers' Day, it is common for students and parents to bring teachers gifts. Most schools close early. |- |[[Jordan]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- |[[Kazakhstan]] |{{Hs|10-00}}The first Sunday of October | |- |[[Kosovo]] |{{Hs|03-07}}7 March | |- |[[Laos]] |{{Hs|10-07}}7 October | |- |[[Latvia]] |{{Hs|10-00}}The first Sunday of October<ref>{{cite web|url=http://likumi.lv/doc.php?id=72608|title=Par svētku, atceres un atzīmējamām dienām|work=Saeimas un Ministru Kabineta Ziņotājs|language=Latvian|accessdate=December 27, 2015}}</ref> |Teacher's Day is celebrated in schools on the 1st Sunday of October. Usually, some classes that day are canceled or conducted by elder grade pupils, while teachers are greeted. |- |[[Lebanon]] |{{Hs|03-09}}9 March | |- |[[Libya]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- |[[Lithuania]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |Between 1965 and 1994, it was celebrated on the first Sunday of October. Since 1994, it has been celebrated on 5 October to coincide with the World Teachers' Day (est. 1994 by UNESCO). |- |[[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Malaysia]] |{{Hs|05-16}}16 May |This date was chosen because on the same day in 1956, the Federal Legislative Council of the Federation of Malaya endorsed the [[Razak Report]], one of four reports of the Education Committee regarding education in Malaysia. The document, known as the Razak Report after [[Tun Abdul Razak]] who was Education Minister at the time, has been the basis of education in Malaysia ever since. Although it is not an official school holiday, celebrations are usually held on 16 May, or earlier if it falls on a Saturday or Sunday. |- |[[Maldives]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |On 5 October, schools in the Maldives celebrate Teachers' Day with many activities. Children and students give parcels and gifts to teachers. |- |[[Mauritius]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Mexico]] |{{Hs|05-15}}15 May |On 15 May (known as "Día del Maestro") schools in Mexico are supposed to stop normal activities and organize cultural events that promote the importance and dignity of the teachers’ role in society{{citation needed|date=October 2015}}. In reality some schools operate as usual and others take the day off. The first Teacher's Day was celebrated on 15 May 1918. The date of 15 May was proposed at the Mexican Congress on 27 September 1917, approved on 29 October 1917 and published on 5 December 1917. There are several possible origins for choosing this date. The first one mentions that in the city of [[San Luis Potosí]] every 15 May, a group of students gathered to celebrate the birthday of their old teacher Isidore, named after Saint [[Isidore the Laborer]], following the Mexican tradition of naming children according to the Saint celebrated the day they were born. The second origin considers the celebration of a historic event in the city of [[Querétaro]] on 15 May 1867.<ref name="Portes1994">{{cite book|author=Luis Tinajero Portes|title=Días conmemorativos en la historia de México|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FnxIVh-A60YC&pg=PA90|date=1 January 1994|publisher=UASLP|language=es|isbn=978-968-6194-65-4|page=90|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref> |- |[[Moldova]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Mongolia]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20170924225501/http://www.montsame.gov.mn/en/index.php/politics/item/3275-mongolian-teacher-s-day-to-be-celebrated-on-world-day-s MONGOLIAN TEACHER’S DAY MOVED TO SIMILAR WORLD EVENT] Sunday, Dec 15 2013 Written by B.Khuder</ref> | |- |[[Morocco]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- |[[Myanmar]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Nepal]] |{{Hs|06-00}}[[Full moon]] day of ''[[Ashadha]]'' (June–July) |The full moon day is also called ''Ashad sukla purnima''; the date usually falls in mid-July. Teacher's Day is called "[[Guru Purnima]]" in Nepali, where "Guru" means teacher and "Purnima" means "Full Moon". |- |[[Netherlands]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dagvandeleraar.nl|title=Welkom – Dag van de leraar|publisher=Dagvandeleraar.nl|language=nl|accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref> | |- |[[New Zealand]] |{{Hs|10-29}}29 October | |- |[[Nigeria]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | Teachers' day in Nigeria is usually a work-free day for all rural and urban teachers. |- |[[Oman]] |{{Hs|02-24}}24 February | |- |[[State of Palestine|Palestine]] |{{Hs|12-14}}14 December | |- |[[Panama]] |{{Hs|12-01}}1 December |To commemorate the birth date of [[Manuel José Hurtado]], who is known as the father of Panamanian education because of his promotion of modern universal education through the establishment of the first public schools and teachers' colleges in what is now known as [[Panama]] — then part of [[Colombia]] – aiming to break the vicious cycle of ignorance and poverty that afflicted the vast majority of the population. He went on to be named Director-General of Public Instruction of the State of the Isthmus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.educapanama.edu.pa/aritculos/biograf%C3%AD-de-manuel-jos%C3%A9-hurtado|title=Biografía de Manuel José Hurtado – Educa Panamá, Mi Portal Educativo|language=es|publisher=Educapanama.edu.pa|date=7 October 2009|accessdate=2 October 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425013955/http://www.educapanama.edu.pa/aritculos/biograf%C3%AD-de-manuel-jos%C3%A9-hurtado|archivedate=25 April 2012|df=}}</ref> |- |[[Pakistan]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Papua New Guinea]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |Papua New Guinea celebrates both National Teachers' Day and International Teachers' Day on this same day. Each school under the National Department of Education (NDOE) and higher institutions of learning and universities under the Department of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (DHERST) celebrates the occasion by staging programs and activities dedicated to the teachers. Children (pupils) and adults (students) are actively involved in acknowledging the teachers contribution to their well being and intellectual development and growth. The PNG government has a Tuition Fee Free policy that provides free education for grade school children through the NDOE. DHERST implements TVET SSP (Technical Vocational Education and Training Skills Scholarship Program)in support of the government's policy on education and PNG Vision 2050.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} |- |[[Paraguay]] |{{Hs|04-30}}30 April | |- |[[Peru]] |{{Hs|07-06}}6 July |During the [[Peruvian War of Independence|independence of Peru]], the [[Libertadores|Liberator]] [[José de San Martín]] founded the first [[Normal school|Normal School for Men]] by means of a [[Resolution (law)|resolution]] passed by the [[José Bernardo de Tagle|Marquis of Torre-Tagle]] on 6 July 1822.
Many years later, in 1953, the then president [[Manuel A. Odría]] decided that Teachers' Day would be commemorated every 6 July.<ref>[http://www.huascaran.edu.pe/web/visitante/comunidad/articulos/dia_del_maestro Portal Educativo del Perú – Día del Maestro] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912115456/http://www.huascaran.edu.pe/web/visitante/comunidad/articulos/dia_del_maestro |date=2007-09-12 }}, huascaran.edu.pe; accessed 5 September 2015. {{es icon}}</ref> |- |[[Philippines]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October<ref>{{cite web|url=http://laws.chanrobles.com/republicacts/108_republicacts.php?id=10529 |title=Republic Act No. 10743 - An Act Declaring the Fifth Day of October of Every Year as the National Teachers’ Day |work=Official Gazette (Philippines)|publisher=ChanRobles Virtual Law Library|date=2016-01-29}}</ref> |By virtue of Presidential Proclamation No. 242, s. 2011,<ref name="gov">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialgazette.gov.ph/2011/08/24/proclamation-no-242-s-2011/ |title=Proclamation No. 242, s. 2011 | National Teachers' Month |publisher=Official Gazette (Philippines)|accessdate=4 November 2015}}</ref> the National Teacher's Month is celebrated starting September 5 through the World Teachers' Day celebration in October 5, making it the longest celebration to honor more than 500,000 teachers nationwide.<br>Before 2011, Teachers' Day was celebrated in schools between the months of September and October (mainly elementary and secondary levels). Teachers are presented with orchid corsages by students. Groups of students representing various grade levels perform short skits or song and dance numbers, or read poetry for their teachers in front of fellow schoolmates in school-wide activities. These activities are planned by senior students in the Student Council who coordinate the activities well in advance.<br>For [[Chinese Filipino|Filipino-Chinese]] schools, a program is usually organized by students for teachers on 27 September while 28 September, considered as the actual Teachers' Day, is a school holiday where both teachers and students are allowed to rest. 28 September was selected as it is thought to be the birthdate of [[Confucius]]. |- |[[Poland]] |{{Hs|10-14}}14 October |This day is the anniversary of the creation of the [[Commission of National Education]], created in 1773 through the initiative of King [[Stanisław August Poniatowski]]. Normally, flowers and sweets will be given to teachers by kids. School play and activities can be also scheduled by student body. |- |[[Portugal]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Puerto Rico]] |{{Hs|05-20}}20 May |In 2016, it was celebrated on the 20th of May.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://aldia.microjuris.com/2015/08/03/calendario-escolar-de-puerto-rico-para-el-ano-2015-2016/|title=Calendario escolar de Puerto Rico para el año 2015–2016|last=Rico|first=Ed Microjuris com Puerto|date=2015-08-03|website=Microjuris – Puerto Rico|access-date=2016-05-20}}</ref> Usually, it is the Friday before [[Mother's Day]].† In some cases, it has been celebrated on the first Friday of May.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cuandoo.com/dia-del-maestro-en-puerto-rico-1935.html|title=Día del Maestro en Puerto Rico 2017|website=cuandoo.com|language=es-ES|access-date=2016-05-20}}</ref> |- |[[Kuwait]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Qatar]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Romania]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October<ref>[http://www.nineoclock.ro/world-teachers-day-celebrated-in-romania/ World Teacher’s Day celebrated in Romania - Nine O' Clock<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> | |- |[[Russia]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October |Between 1965 and 1994, the first Sunday of October, since 1994, 5 October, coinciding with World Teachers' Day (est. 1994 by [[UNESCO]]). |- |[[Saudi Arabia]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- |[[Serbia]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[Singapore]] |{{Hs|09-00}}First Friday of September |An official school holiday. Celebrations are normally conducted the day before, where students usually get half a day off. In some schools, students will put on performances to entertain and honour their teachers. |- |[[Slovakia]] |{{Hs|03-28}}28 March |Commemorates the birthdate of [[John Amos Comenius]]. |- |[[Somalia]] |{{Hs|11-21}}21 November | Since 1974, Teachers' Day has been a public holiday celebrated in every school. |- |[[South Korea]] |{{Hs|05-15}}15 May |Originally it was started by a group of Red Cross youth team members who visited their sick ex-teachers in hospitals. Originally its date was May 26. But since 1965, its date has been 15 May, [[Sejong the Great]]'s birthday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://terms.naver.com/entry.nhn?cid=1595&docId=559459&mobile&categoryId=1595|script-title=ko:스승의날: 지식백과|publisher=terms.naver.com|language=ko|accessdate=15 May 2013}}</ref> The national celebration ceremony was stopped between 1973 and 1982, but it resumed after that. <ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://terms.naver.com/entry.nhn?docId=559459&cid=46625&categoryId=46625|title=Teachers' day in South Korea|last=|first=|date=|website=Encyclopedia of Korean Culture|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In 1982, it was revived again to create a climate that honors its mentor. <ref name=":0" />On the day, teachers are usually presented with [[Dianthus caryophyllus|carnations]] by their students and ex-students. It is illegal to present carnations to public school teachers under the anti-graft law. <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/common/newsprint.php?ud=20170514000242|title=Anti-graft law causes confusion ahead of Teachers’ Day|last=Bak|first=Se-Hwan|date=2017-05-14|website=Korea Herald|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180512011118/http://www.koreaherald.com/common/newsprint.php?ud=20170514000242|archive-date=2018-05-12|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> |- |[[South Sudan]] |{{Hs|12-01}}1 December |The president of South Sudan proclaimed Teacher's Day for December 1, one month before the country's first Teacher's Day. On 1 September, one month before the country's third Teacher's Day, it was publicly announced that they changed the date to 1 October.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- |[[Sri Lanka]] |{{Hs|10-06}}6 October |Officially Teachers' Day is celebrated in every school on 6 October. |- |[[Spain]] |{{Hs|11-27}}27 November<ref>{{cite web|url=https://anydayguide.com/calendar/3123|title=Teachers' Day in Spain / November 27, 2016|author=AnydayGuide|work=AnydayGuide}}</ref> | |- |[[Syria]] |{{Hs|03-18}}18 March<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.cntv.cn/program/asiatoday/20130321/107175.shtml|title=Assad pays tribute on Syria's Teachers' Day|publisher=english.cntv.com|accessdate=5 September 2014|date=March 21, 2013}}</ref> | |- |[[Taiwan]] |{{Hs|09-28}}28 September |Taiwan uses this day to honor teachers' contributions to their own students and to society in general. People often make use of the day to express their gratitude to their teachers, such as paying them a visit or sending them a card. This date was chosen to commemorate the birth of [[Confucius]], believed to be the model master educator. In 1939, the Ministry of Education established the national holiday as 27 August, the attributed birthday of [[Confucius]].{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}
In 1952, the [[Executive Yuan]] changed it to September, stating that it was calculated to be the precise date in the [[Gregorian calendar]]. The festival celebration occurs in the temples of Confucius around the island, known as the "Grand Ceremony Dedicated to Confucius" (祭孔大典). The ceremony begins at 6am with drum beats. 54 musicians are dressed in robes with blue belts, and 36 (or 64) dancers dressed in yellow with green belts. They are led by Confucius's chief descendant (currently [[Kung Tsui-chang]]) and followed by ceremonial officers. Three animals are sacrificed: a cow, a goat, and a pig. The hairs plucked from these sacrificed animals are called the Hairs of Wisdom. In addition, local education institutes and civil offices award certain teachers for their excellence and positive influence.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- |[[Thailand]] |{{Hs|01-16}}16 January |Adopted as Teachers' Day by a resolution of the government on 21 November 1956. The first Teachers' Day was held in 1957. 16 January marks the enactment of the Teachers Act, Buddhist Era 2488 (1945), which was published in the ''[[Royal Thai Government Gazette|Government Gazette]]'' on 16 January 1945, and came into force 60 days later. Most Thai schools close for the day to give their teachers a break during the long second term. Many international schools do not, although they may hold celebrations to honour their teaching staff. There are very few public or official commemorations.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- |[[Tunisia]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |- |[[Turkey]] |{{Hs|11-24}}24 November |[[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]] stated that "The new generation will be created by teachers" and as founding President adopted a [[Turkish alphabet|new alphabet]] for the newly founded [[Turkish Republic]] in 1923. On November 24, 1928 Mustafa Kemal officially accepted the title of head teacher of the nation's schools, granted by the cabinet of ministers. It has been celebrated since 1981 (after the 1980 Coup d'État) as The Teachers’ Day. |- |[[Ukraine]] |{{Hs|10-00}}The first Sunday of October |At schools across the country, Teachers' Day is celebrated the Friday before the holiday with concerts and gatherings, while students usually give their teachers gifts such as flowers and sweets. At some schools exists tradition with organising pupils of senior classes to conduct lesson for minors. The ceremony of issuing the appreciation certificates may be conducted for notable teachers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://styler.rbc.ua/ukr/dosug/den-uchitelya-traditsii-prazdnovaniya-ukraine-1475211331.html|website=styler.rbc.ua|title=День вчителя: традиції святкування в Україні|language=uk}}</ref> |- |[[United Arab Emirates]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[United Kingdom]] |{{Hs|10-05}}5 October | |- |[[United States]] |{{Hs|05-00}}National Teacher Day is on Tuesday during Teacher Appreciation Week, which takes place in the first full week of May. |The [[National Education Association]] (NEA) describes National Teacher Day as "a day for honoring teachers and recognizing the lasting contributions they make to our lives".<ref name="nea">{{cite web|url=http://www.nea.org/teacherday|title=National Teacher Day|publisher=NEA.org|accessdate=2 October 2011}}</ref>
The NEA gives a history of National Teacher Day:<ref name="nea" /> The origins of Teacher Day are murky. Around 1944, a Wisconsin teacher named Ryan Krug began corresponding with political and education leaders about the need for a national day to honor teachers. Woodbridge wrote to [[Eleanor Roosevelt]], who in 1953 persuaded the [[Eighty-first United States Congress|81st Congress]] to proclaim a National Teacher Day. NEA along with its Kansas and Indiana state affiliates and the [[Dodge City, Kansas]] local NEA branch lobbied Congress to create a national day celebrating teachers. Congress declared 7 March 1980 as National Teacher Day for that year only. The NEA and its affiliates continued to observe Teacher Day on the first Tuesday in March until 1985, when the National PTA established Teacher Appreciation Week in the first full week of May. The NEA Representative Assembly then voted to make the Tuesday of that week National Teacher Day. As of 4 November 1976, 6 November was adopted as Teachers' Day in the [[U.S. state]] of [[Massachusetts]]. Currently, Massachusetts sets the first Sunday of June as its own Teachers' Day annually.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- |[[Uruguay]] |{{Hs|09-22}}22 September | |- |[[Uzbekistan]] |{{Hs|10-01}}1 October |Uzbekistan is one of the countries where Teachers' Day is on October 1, and there is a day off throughout the country. Teachers' Day has been celebrated here since 1997. |- |[[Venezuela]] |{{Hs|01-15}}15 January | |- |[[Vietnam]] |{{Hs|11-20}}20 November |This holiday allows students to express their respect to their teacher. Students begin preparing a week in advance. Many classes prepare literature and art to welcome Teachers' Day, while other students prepare foods and flowers for the parties held at their schools. Students usually visit their teachers at their homes to offer flowers and small gifts, or organize trips with their teachers and classmates. Former students also pay respect to their former teachers on this day. The holiday has its origins in a meeting between educators in [[communist bloc]] nations in [[Warsaw]] in 1957. It was first celebrated in 1958 as the Day of the International Manifest of Educators; in 1982 the day was renamed Vietnamese Educators' Day.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- |[[Yemen]] |{{Hs|02-28}}28 February | |}
A day for [[homeschool]] teacher appreciation has been suggested,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.home-school.com/Articles/HS-teacher-apprec-day.php|title=It’s Time for Homeschool Teacher Appreciation Day!|author=Bill Pride|publisher=Homeschool World|accessdate=2017-05-09}}</ref> which several homeschooling groups subsequently organized.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://homeschoolteacherappreciationday.com/|title=Homeschool Teacher Appreciation Day|accessdate=2017-05-09}}</ref> A United States "parents as teachers day" has existed on November 8 since the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaldaycalendar.com/national-parents-as-teachers-day-november-8/|title=National Parents as Teachers Day|accessdate=2017-05-09}}</ref> While this initially focussed on the role of parents in [[early childhood education|early-childhood learning]], some homeschoolers use it to acknowledge the primacy of the parental role in education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.beyondmommying.com/blog/2014/11/07/national-parents-teachers-day/|title=Beyond Mommying: National Parents as Teachers Day|accessdate=2017-05-09|date=2014-11-07}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Teacher's Oath]] *[[World Teachers' Day]] – established by UNESCO

page.title: List of commencement speakers at Rice University

revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Lists|date=August 2012}} {{primary sources|date=August 2012}} {{self-published|date=August 2012}} }} In 2013, [[Rice University]] held its 100th commencement. Since 1986, commencements have been held in the Academic Quadrangle (weather permitting). Every commencement at Rice has included the hymns ''[[Veni Creator Spiritus]]'' and ''[http://www.hymnary.org/text/lord_of_all_being_throned_afar Lord of All Being, Throned Afar]''.
* 2017: [[Mae Jemison]] * 2016: [[Sheryl WuDunn]] * 2015: [[Colin Powell]] * 2014: [[Helene D. Gayle]] * 2013: [[Neil deGrasse Tyson]] * 2012: [[Salman Khan (educator)|Salman Khan]] – [https://web.archive.org/web/20160304125950/https://mediacore.rice.edu/media/20120512_commencementmp4 (video)] * 2011: [[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]] – [http://wmdp.rice.edu/Rice/Commencement/11/Commencement-14May11.mp4 (video)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2010: [[Muhammad Yunus]] – [http://wmdp.rice.edu/Commencement/2010/2010Commencement-15May10.mp4 (video)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2009: [[Zainab Salbi]] – [http://wmdp.rice.edu/Commencement/09/Commence2009rndr.mp4 (video)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2008: [[George Rupp]] – [http://wmdp.rice.edu/Rice/Commencement/08/CommencementCeremony-10May08.mp4 (video)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2007: [[John Doerr]] – [http://wmdp.rice.edu/Rice/Commencement/07/Commencement_05122007.mp3 (audio)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2006: [[Bill White (Texas politician)|Bill White]] – [http://wmdp.rice.edu/Rice/Commencement/%2006/2006commencemeniPod_Hi.mp4 (audio)]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} * 2005: [http://www.ruf.rice.edu/~hebl/ Michelle Hebl] * 2004: [[Alberto Gonzales]] * 2003: [[Shannon Lucid]] * 2002: [[Bill Cosby]] * 2001: [[Morris Dees]] * 2000: [[George H. W. Bush]] * 1999: [[Helmut Schmidt]] – [http://webcast.rice.edu/speeches/19990515commencement.html (text)] * 1998: [[Kurt Vonnegut]] * 1997: [[Alan Dershowitz]] * 1996: [[Anita K. Jones]] * 1995: [[Bill Bradley]] * 1994: [[Elizabeth Dole]] * 1993: [[Jimmy Carter]] * 1992: [[Richard von Weizsäcker]] * 1991: [[James Baker|James A. Baker III]]
From 1971 to 1990, Rice did not invite speakers to address graduates at commencement. During that time, addresses were given by university presidents [[Norman Hackerman]] (1971–1985) and [[George Rupp]] (1986–1990).
From 1952 to 1985, commencements were held on the east side (lawn) of Lovett Hall.
* 1970: [[T. Harry Williams]], Professor of History, L.S.U. * 1969: [[Harry Ransom|Harry H. Ransom]], Chancellor, Univ. of Texas * 1968: [[William H. Masterson]], President, Univ. of Tennessee at Chattanooga * 1967: Robert A. Charpie, President, Electronics Division, Union Carbide * 1966: Jack K. Williams, V.P. for Academic Affairs and Dean, Clemson Univ. * 1965: [[Henry Allen Moe]], President, American Philosophical Society * 1964: [[Charles Hard Townes]], Provost, M.I.T. * 1963: [[John Connally]], Governor, Texas * 1962: [[Merrimon Cuninggim]], Executive Director, Danforth Foundation * 1961: [[Herbert E. Longenecker]], President, Tulane Univ. * 1960: [[Harvie Branscomb]], Chancellor, Vanderbilt Univ. * 1959: [[George R. Harrison]], Dean of the School of Science, M.I.T. * 1958: [[John W. Gardner]], President, Carnegie Foundation * 1957: [[Julius Adams Stratton]], Chancellor, M.I.T. * 1956: [[John Hasbrouck Van Vleck]], Dean of Engineering, Harvard Univ. * 1955: [[J. William Fulbright]], Senator, Arkansas * 1954: [[Wallace Sterling|J. E. Wallace Sterling]], President, Stanford Univ. * 1953: Roger Philip McCutcheon, Dean of the Graduate School, Tulane Univ. * 1952: [[Douglas Southall Freeman]], Scholar from Richmond, Virginia
In 1951, commencement was held in [[Autry Court]].
* 1951: [[Lewis Webster Jones]], President, Univ. of Arkansas
From 1935 to 1950, commencements were held in courtyard of the Chemistry Laboratories (now Keck Hall).
* 1950: [[Robert Andrews Millikan]], V.P. of the Board, California Institute of Technology * 1949: [[Detlev Bronk|Detlev W. Bronk]], President, Johns Hopkins Univ.
From 1916 to 1948, commencements were held on Monday, preceded by a Baccalaureate sermon on Sunday.
* 1948: [[Blake Ragsdale Van Leer]], President, Georgia School of Technology * 1947: [[Frederick Hard]], President, Scripps College
From 1942 to 1946, addresses were delivered by [[William Vermillion Houston]], President of Rice Institute. In 1944 and 1946, Rice held two commencement ceremonies each year as part of a “wartime speed-up educational program.”<ref>{{cite web|title=Rice Institute Class of 1946 Commencement programs|url=http://scholarship.rice.edu/handle/1911/61396|publisher=Rice University Digital Scholarship Archive|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref>
* 1941: [[Isaiah Bowman]], President, Johns Hopkins Univ. * 1940: [[James Rowland Angell]], President Emeritus, Yale Univ. * 1939: [[George Edgar Vincent]], Former President, Rockefeller Foundation * 1938: [[George Norlin]], President, Univ. of Colorado * 1937: [[Frank Pierrepont Graves]], President, State Univ. of New York * 1936: [[Harold Willis Dodds]], President, Princeton Univ. * 1935: [[Ralph Budd]], President, Burlington Lines
From 1916 to 1934, commencements were held in the Academic Quadrangle.
* 1934: [[John Campbell Merriam]], President, Carnegie Institution of Washington * 1933: [[Edwin Grant Conklin]], Professor of Biology, Princeton Univ. * 1932: [[Roscoe Pound]], Dean of the Law School, Harvard Univ. * 1931: [[James A. Baker (born 1857)|Captain James A. Baker]], Chairman of the Board, Rice Institute * 1930: [[Ralph Adams Cram]], Supervising Architect, Rice Institute * 1929: [[William Dodd (ambassador)|William Edward Dodd]], Professor of American History, Univ. of Chicago * 1928: [[John Huston Finley]], Editor, ''New York Times'' * 1927: [[Emile de Cartier de Marchienne|Baron de Cartier de Marchienne]], Belgian Ambassador to the U.S. * 1926: [[Joseph Sweetman Ames]], Professor of Physics, Johns Hopkins Univ. * 1925: Stockton Axson, Professor of English, Rice Institute * 1924: [[Charles William Dabney]], Former President, Univ. of Cincinnati * 1923: [[Edgar Fahs Smith]], Emeritus Professor of Chemistry, Univ. of Pennsylvania * 1922: [[Frank Thilly]], Professor of Philosophy, Cornell Univ. * 1921: [[Charles William Eliot]], President Emeritus, Harvard Univ. * 1920: [[Joseph Chappell Hutcheson, Jr.|J. C. Hutcheson]], Judge of the Federal Court * 1919: William M. Thornton, Dean of the Department of Engineering, Univ. of Virginia * 1918: [[Nelson Phillips]], Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Texas * 1917: [[William Henry Carpenter (philologist)|William H. Carpenter]], Provost, Columbia Univ. * 1916: [[David Starr Jordan]], Chancellor Emeritus, Stanford Univ.
==References== {{Reflist}}

page.title: List of organizations engaged in STEM education across Africa

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=May 2016}}
Education in [[Science, technology, engineering, and mathematics]] (STEM) fields has been identified as a development goal in the [[North–South divide|global South]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://en.unesco.org/unesco_science_report|title=UNESCO Science Report|website=UNESCO|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scidev.net/global/r-d/news/basic-science-linked-to-faster-economic-growth.html|title=Basic science linked to faster economic growth|last=SciDev.Net|website=SciDev.Net|access-date=2016-03-12}}</ref> STEM oriented economies perform strongly on a number of economic indicators.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.brookings.edu/research/reports/2013/06/10-stem-economy-rothwell|title=The Hidden STEM Economy|website=The Brookings Institution|language=en|access-date=2016-03-16}}</ref> Currently, there is a shortage of trained scientists in Africa.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Muindi|first = Fanuel|last2 = Guha|first2 = Moytrayee|date = 2013-12-12|title = Training: African database for education schemes|url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v504/n7479/full/504218d.html|journal = Nature|language = en|volume = 504|issue = 7479|pages = 218–218|doi = 10.1038/504218d|issn = 0028-0836|pmid=24336275}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.scidev.net/global/education/opinion/the-case-for-a-global-fund-for-science-education.html|title = The case for a global fund for science education|last = SciDev.Net|website = SciDev.Net|access-date = 2016-03-12}}</ref> Many African countries are investing in STEM research and education, with the [[African Union]] encouraging its members to spend 1% of their GDP on STEM.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Irikefe|first = Vivienne|last2 = Vaidyanathan|first2 = Gayathri|last3 = Nordling|first3 = Linda|last4 = Twahirwa|first4 = Aimable|last5 = Nakkazi|first5 = Esther|last6 = Monastersky|first6 = Richard|date = 2011-06-29|title = Science in Africa: The view from the front line|url = http://www.nature.com/news/2011/110629/full/474556a.html|journal = Nature News|language = en|volume = 474|issue = 7353|pages = 556–559|doi = 10.1038/474556a}}</ref>
This is a list of [[organization]]s that are currently engaged in STEM Education activities and outreach across [[Sub-Saharan Africa|Sub-Saharan]] Africa. The organizations range in size, scope, funding mechanisms, and mission statements.{{Expand list|Expand list = |date=April 2016}} [[File:Stem Programs in Africa Jan 2017 Update.jpg|thumb|Visualization of STEM Programs in Africa. This was visualized with RAW Platform which is a project by DensityDesign Lab<nowiki/>http://raw.densitydesign.org/]]
== By name == * A-MAN, Inc. STEM International Science Discovery & Learning Center: International Technology Education Programs * South African mathematics * Africa ICT Right * Africa STEM and Video Game Research * Africa Teen Geeks * STEM Nigeria - [http://www.stem.ng] * African Institute for Mathematical Sciences (AIMS) * African University of Science and Technology * African Research Academies for Women * Audax Solutions Ltd. * Bunengi STEM * Burundi American International Academy (BAIA) * Carisma4U Educational Foundation [http://www.Carisma4U.com ] * [http://www.center4tech.com Center4Tech] (www.center4tech.com) * [http://www.ckf.org.ng Christopher Kolade Foundation] * [http://www.coderina.org *Coderina Education & Technology Foundation] * [[COSAT]] * Cosmos Education Kenya * Crawford College Sandton * [http://www.developersinvogue.org Developers in Vogue] * [https://dhackinstitute.com/ Dhack Institute] * [http://www.elevatetrust.com Elevate Trust Zimbabwe] * Esso Angolan Scholars Program * Fundi Bots * [http://www.computergeeky.org *Geek Girls Collaborative] Nigeria * Her2Voice * [http://www.ghanascienceproject.net/ Ghana Planetarium Science Project] * Hive Colab * iNERDE <ref name="inerde.org">{{cite web|url=http://inerde.org/|title=iNERDE - Empowering Youth with Opportunity|website=My CMS}}</ref> * [http://www.innovategh.com Innovate Ghana] (GREMKAY) * [http://www.iamthecode.org iamtheCODE] * JJiguene Tech Senegal * [http://leversinheels.com Levers in Heels] * [http://www.learnlab.co.za Learning Innovation Design Lab] * Little Einsteins East Africa http://littleeinsteinsea.com/ * MATHAFRICA * Meta Economic Development Organisation (Medo) Young Women in STEM * [http://dotconnectafrica.org/miss.africa/ Miss.Africa] * NAIROBITS * New Education for Radical Development * Nutty Scientists * Oysters & Pearls * [https://www.playafrica.org.za Play Africa] (children's museum in Johannesburg, South Africa) * The P-STEM Foundation * People's economic development foundation * Pamusha STEM Village Zimbabwe (digital literacy program for women in marginalized communities) * [http://projektinspire.co.tz/ Projekt Inspire] * Regional Science Expos in South Africa * re:learn by CcHUB * Robofest Zimbabwe * SASOL INZALO Foundation * STEM-Ed Enterprises * STEM Synergy * STEM4Africa * Science and Technology Education Post_basic Project * Science Circus Africa * STEM Africa * [http://www.stembees.org/ STEMbees] * STEM Girl (Education) * [http://stemusso.org/ STEMusso](Malian association of women and girls in STEM) * STEM Innovation Camps in South Africa * Teaching and Research in Natural Sciences for Development in Africa (TReNDs) * TEAM4TECH * Technovation For Girls; Rainbow Gate Foundation * The Cabo Verde Tenth Island Project * The Nelson Mandela African Institution of Science and Technology * The Zimbabwe Science Fair STEM Education Symposium * [http://www.visiolafoundation.org/ The Visiola Foundation] * Youth for Technology Foundation Nigeria * WAAW FOUNDATION (Working to Advance Stem Education for African Women) [http://waawfoundation.org/ WAAW Foundation] * WiSci: Girls STEAM Camp] * World Digital Exhibition (Worldex), www.worldex.com.ng
== By country == '''Angola''' * Esso Angolan Scholars Program '''Benin'''

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Lloyd Loar | honorific_suffix = | image = Lloyd Loar in 1911.png | image_upright = | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lloyd Loar, with Gibson F2 mandolin c. 1911, from the brochure of the Fisher Shipp Concert Company. The caption read in part, "Mr. Lloyd A. Loar mandolin soloist and pianist is a thorough-going musician. He studied harmony and counterpoint at Oberlin Conservatory of Music and for two years was leader of the Oberlin Mandolin Club. He is not only a performer but a composer." He is better known today as a designer of musical instruments for Gibson. | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = Lloyd Allayre Loar | alias = | birth_date =January 9, 1886{{cite web|url=http://www.siminoff.net/pages/loar_background.html|title=Lloyd Allayre Loar – Background|last= Siminoff|first=Roger|website=siminoff.net |accessdate=2006-11-04}} | birth_place = [[Cropsey, Illinois|Cropsey]], Illinois | death_date = September 14, 1943 {{cite news |author= |title= Lloyd Allayre Loar|url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20015626/lloyd_loar_funeral_services/ |work=Chicago Tribune |location= Chicago, Illinois|date= 16 September 1943|access-date=12 May 2018 |page=32 |quote=pianist, composer, instructor in the physics of music at Northwestern University...died Chicago}} | death_place = [[Chicago]] | education = *[[Chicago Musical College]] *[[American Conservatory of Music]] *[[Oberlin Conservatory of Music]], -final year 1906 *[[Opéra-Comique]], Paris | occupation = musician, composer, luthier, sound engineer, educator Known for *music on [[mandolin]], mandoviola, [[piano]] *musical instruments invented or perfected Notable work *[[Gibson F-5|F-5 mandolin]] *[[Gibson L5|L-5 guitar]] *H-5 mandola *K-5 mandocello *A-5 mandolin. |Style =[[Classical music|classical]] | years_active = c. 1906-1943 *Fisher Shipp Concert Company c.1906 - c. 1920{{cite news |author= |title= Columbian Entertainers|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20274781/lloyd_loar_with_shipp_oct_1_1906/ |work= The Mapleton Press|location= Mapleton, Kansas|date= 19 October 1906 |access-date= 22 May 2018|quote=Fisher Shipp, reader...Etta Goode Heacock...Lloyd A Loar, mandolin soloist}} *Gibson 1919-1924 *Gulbranson Piano Company, Chicago{{cite news |author= |title= Innovation in program promised|url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20242064/many_aspects_of_lloyd_loars_life/|work=The Austin American |location= Austin, Texas|date= 12 November 1933 |access-date=20 May 2018 |page= 20}} *Northwestern University c. 1931-1943 | label_name = | spouse = *Fisher Shipp (1916-c.1935){{cite news |author= |title= Afternoon performance|url= https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20115418/gibsonian_orchestra_fisher_ship/ |work=The Pantagraph |location=Bloomington, Illinois |date= 8 July 1922|access-date= 20 May 2018|page =7}} *Bertha Snyder (1939-1943) }} '''Lloyd Allayre Loar''' (1886 – 1943) was a designer for the [[Gibson Guitar Corporation|Gibson Mandolin-Guitar Mfg. Co. Ltd.]] and sound engineer in the early part of the 20th century.{{cite news |author= |title=In Memoriam, Lloyd A. Loar |url= https://www.mandolincafe.com/forum/showthread.php?133382-Lloyd-Loar-s-Obituary-from-Fretted-Instrument-News|work=Fretted Instrument News |publisher= The Rhode Island Music Company|location=Providence, Rhode Island |date=November–December 1943|access-date=May 17, 2018 }} He is most famous for his [[Gibson F-5|F-5 model]] [[mandolin]] and [[Gibson L-5|L-5]] [[guitar]]. In his later years he worked on [[Instrument amplifier|electric amplification]] of stringed instruments, and demonstrated them around the country.{{cite news |author= |title= There's No Back On This Viola, But It's Got Power |url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20009876/lloyd_loar_electric_cello |work=The Courier |location=Waterloo, Iowa |date=10 January 1938 |access-date=17 May 2018 }} One example, played in public in 1938 was an electric viola that used electric coils beneath the [[Bridge (instrument)|bridge]], with no back, able to "drown out the loudest trumpet." In 1898 [[Orville Gibson]] had patented a new kind of mandolin that followed violin design, with its curved top and bottom carved into shape, rather than pressed.{{harvnb|Sparks|2003|page=129–130}} The sides too were carved out of a single block of wood, rather than being made of bent wood strips. The instruments were already unique before Lloyd Loar came to work for Gibson. However, it is the Loar-designed instruments that became especially desirable. First made famous by [[Bill Monroe]], Loar's signed mandolins today can cost as much as 200,000 dollars. The L-5 guitar owned by [[Maybelle Carter]], which was made after he left Gibson, sold for 575,000 dollars.{{cite web |url= http://www.prewargibsonl-5.com/85558/4578092585|title= 85558- Gibson L-5|last= Alcantara |first= Paul|date= |website= prewargibsonl-5.com |publisher= |access-date= 20 May 2018 |quote=Joe Span...Spain's Guide to Gibson...I conclude that Maybelle's guitar was shipped in January of 1930.}} Among the changes that Loar introduced was the [[f-hole]] instead of a round or oval [[sound-hole]], another violin-family feature imported to the mandolin. He also "tuned" the tops of the instrument and the sound chamber (by removing bits of wood from sound bars and from the edges of the sound holes) so that the instrument's sound chamber was resonant to a particular note. Another change that Loar introduced to the Gibson line was a tone-producer, a circle of wood inside the instrument on the underside of the [[Sound board (music)|sound board]] that produced "overtones." His idea was to have a more complete set of these overtones with the carved top instruments. The result was an instrument that, like [[Stradivarius]]’ violins, has presented challenges to duplicate. [[Luthier]]-researchers such as Roger Siminoff have worked to understand the fine details. Gibsons' and Loar's mandolins were instrumental in displacing the round-backed instrument from the American market and influenced mandolins worldwide. He also developed keyboard-stringed instruments. According to Roger Siminoff, he developed unique mechanisms to create sound. One plucked strings, the other struck metal reeds. Loar was also a well-regarded musician on mandolin, viola, and [[musical saw]]. He traveled the United States and Europe in several musical groups. In one group, he performed with his future wife, Fisher Shipp.{{cite web|url=http://digital.lib.uiowa.edu/cdm4/results.php?CISOOP1=exact&CISOFIELD1=corpor&CISOROOT=all&CISOBOX1=Fisher+Shipp+Concert+Company|title=University of Iowa Digital Library|last=digital.lib.uiowa.edu|accessdate=2010-01-05}} A surviving playbill shows that Loar performed in a [[chatauqua]] that also included a speech by [[William Jennings Bryan]].{{cite web|url=http://digital.lib.uiowa.edu/cdm4/document.php?CISOROOT=/tc&CISOPTR=57050&REC=5|title=University of Iowa Digital Libraries|last=digital.lib.uiowa.edu|accessdate=2010-01-05}} Loar performed in many other groups that promoted the Gibson company, whose products Loar endorses in early Gibson catalogs. Lloyd also taught at [[Northwestern University]] from 1930 to 1943, teaching vocal composition, advanced [[music theory]] and "''The Physics of Music''".{{cite web |url=http://siminoff.net/loar-at-northwestern/ |title=Loar’s Classes at Northwestern |last=Siminoff |first=Roger |date= |website=siminoff.net |publisher= |access-date=20 May 2018 |quote=}} == History == Loar worked for Gibson from 1919 to 1924. His contributions include building the instrument top with F-shaped holes, like a violin; introducing a longer [[Neck (music)|neck]], thus moving the [[Bridge (instrument)|bridge]] closer to the center of the body; and floating the [[fingerboard]] over the top, a change from prior Gibson instruments that had fingerboards fused to the top. He also pioneered the use of the Virzi Tone Producer, a spruce disc suspended from the instrument top that acts as a supplemental soundboard. According to [[A. R. Duchossoir]], Loar designed experimental electric instruments while at Gibson. Loar's views on the importance of the development of electric instruments were supported by Lewis A Williams, one of the founders and major stockholders of Gibson as well as its secretary and general manager. None of Loar's original electric instruments appear to have been preserved—but Walter A Fuller, who joined Gibson in 1933 and later became Gibson's chief electronic engineer, found some of Loar's original devices when he first set up his R&D lab in the mid-1930s. He claimed that Loar's electrics had electrostatic pickups, but because they exhibited very high impedance they were extremely susceptible to humidity. According to Fuller, the pickups were round, about the size of a silver dollar and had a piece of cork on the back, by which they were glued to the underside of the top of the instrument. Duchossior's book, ''Gibson Electrics, The Classic Years'', features a photo of a Gibson L5, serial number 88258 of 1929 (after Loar left Gibson), one of the original Loar-designed L5s, with fitted electrostatic pickup and factory-fitted jack socket in the tailpiece. Duchossoir also claims that Loar spent time at Gibson working on a 'quasi-solid body' electric double bass, and that according to this instrument and several patents filed by Loar between the mid-1920s and the mid-1930s, he worked on pickups that were electromagnetic in nature. According to Duchossoir, Lewis Williams was replaced as general manager, and a lack of amicable relations with the new manager—an accountant named Guy Hart—led to the termination of Loar's contract. After leaving Gibson, Loar created and patented an electric instrument with a coil pickup, and co-founded the Acousti-Lectric company with Lewis Williams in 1934. The company was renamed the [[Vivi-Tone]] company in 1936. Loar died in 1943. {{clear left}} == Famous Loar mandolins == {{multiple image |align=left|direction=horizontal | image1 = Bill Monroe F5 mandolin low resolution.jpg | width1 = 150 | caption1 = {{nowrap|1923 [[Gibson F-5]] mandolin}} {{smaller|(played by [[Bill Monroe]])}} | image2 = 1924 Lloyd Loar F-5 (SN75846), Virzi (SN10002) (2010-09-18 00.27.59 by Joseph Brent) clip1.jpg | width2 = 116 | caption2 = 1924 [[Gibson F-5]]
{{smaller|(serial #75846)}} }} The F5 model was made famous by the founder of [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]], [[Bill Monroe]]. Monroe played a [http://www.mandolinarchive.com/gibson/serial/73987 Gibson F5 model serial number 73987]{{cite web|url=http://www.mandolinarchive.com/gibson/serial/73987|title=F5 Journal record for Gibson F5 #73987|last=www.mandolinarchive.com|accessdate=2010-01-05}} signed by Loar on July 9, 1923 for most of his career. This mandolin can be viewed in the Country Music Hall of Fame in Nashville, Tennessee, where it now resides in their collections. Loar also signed a rare subset of F5 mandolins called ''Ferns'', of which approximately twenty are known to exist. The name refers to the distinctive fern inlay design of the peghead. The earliest documented Fern bears the serial number 73755, dated July 9, 1923, the same signing date as Bill Monroe's famous Loar [http://www.mandolinarchive.com/gibson/serial/73755]. This is the only known Fern built without the ''"Virzi" Tone Producer'', a secondary sound board suspended underneath the mandolin's top inside the sound chamber. This particular instrument is the only known Fern dated on 9 July. In 2007, mandolinist [[Chris Thile]] acquired [http://www.mandolinarchive.com/perl/show_mando.pl?3630 1924 Loar-signed F5] serial # 75316 that was an exceedingly rare find, as it was in virtually new condition. It reportedly cost him around $200,000. Other well-known musicians who have owned Loar-signed F5's include [[John Paul Jones (musician)|John Paul Jones]] serial # 75317, [[Mike Marshall (musician)|Mike Marshall]], David McLaughlin, Herschel Sizemore, Alan Bibey, Tony Williamson, [[David Grisman]], John Reischman, [[Tom Rozum]], [[Frank Wakefield]], and the late [[Joe Val]] serial #72207. Only one A-style mandolin, a Gibson A5, is known to have been signed by Loar. It has been widely copied, originally by mandolin maker Bob Givens. The [http://www.mandolinarchive.com/perl/show_mando.pl?51 Loar A5] was found by [https://web.archive.org/web/20100108045341/http://www.mandozine.com/resources/CGOW/tuttaylor.php Tut Taylor] and sold to a Southern California bluegrass musician in 1974. === Collectability === As of January 2010, Loar-signed mandolins in fine condition are valued in the $175,000 to $200,000 range, and are highly sought after by musicians and collectors. The average value reached a 2008 peak of around $225,000, then backed off somewhat from 2008 to 2010. Loar expert Darryl Wolfe maintains an F5 historical journal. As of January, 2010 he has documented 228 Loar-signed F5 mandolins of the 326 that are believed to have been made.{{cite web|url=http://www.mandolinarchive.com/signature_dates.html|title=Loar Signed Instruments|last=www.mandolinarchive.com|accessdate=2010-01-05}} ==L-5 Guitar== {{multiple image |align=left |direction=horizontal | image1 = Gibson L-5 (1928), Maybelle Carter, CMHF clip1.jpg | width1 = 150 | caption1 = [[Gibson L-5]] guitar {{smaller|(played by [[Maybelle Carter]])}}, "the most important single guitar in the entire history of country music," according to [[George Gruhn]]. There is controversy about its date. Commonly said to be a 1928 instrument, but researcher Joe Span concluded, it couldn't have left the factory earlier than April 1929, and was shipped January, 1930.}} The [[Gibson L-5]] [[guitar]] was first produced in 1922 by the [[Gibson Guitar Corporation]], then of [[Kalamazoo, Michigan]], under the direction of master [[luthier]] Lloyd Loar, and has been in production ever since. It was considered the premier guitar of the company during the [[big band]] era. It was originally offered as an [[acoustic guitar|acoustic]] instrument, with [[electric guitar|electric]] models not made available until the 1940s. ===Design and construction=== Worldwide, the L-5 was the first guitar to feature [[f-hole]]s. Then as well as today, the construction of the L-5 is similar in construction, carving, bracing and tap-tuning, to building a cello. This guitar as well as the cello are similarly designed in order to amplify and project the acoustic vibration of strings throughout carved and tuned woods, using f-holes as the projection points. From 1922 to 1934 the L-5 was produced with a 16" lower bout width. In 1934 the lower bout was increased to 17" - and this width is still used today. Also released in 1934 was the one-inch larger 18" archtop guitar named the "L5 Super" which a couple of years later was renamed the [[Gibson Super 400]]. These two master-built acoustic guitars are Gibson's top-of-the-line carved wood and highly ornate archtop instruments. These guitars cannot be constructed quickly and require unusual attention to detail, resulting in a higher price. The time, skilled workmanship and materials used in these builds has been delivered non-stop for the past 90+ years. Since the 1930s there have been several other 17" archtops designed by Gibson, including variations introduced as more affordable, less ornately decorated models - these were introduced to consider the budgets of musicians.''Gruhn's Guide To Vintage Guitars'', 2nd Edition, pg. 140 ==References== * {{cite book |last= Sparks|first=Paul|date= 2003|title= The Classical Mandolin|url=|location= Oxford|publisher= Oxford University Press|page= |isbn=9780195173376}} == External links == * [http://www.siminoff.net/pages/loar_background.html Biography of Lloyd Loar] by mandolin builder and author Roger Siminoff * [http://www.f5journal.com/ The F5 Journal] A project to document all Loar F5 mandolins * [http://www.mandolinarchive.com/signature_dates.html Loar-signed instruments documented at The Mandolin Archive] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051101004137/http://www.gibson.com/folks/history/early/early2.html short Gibson history of Lloyd Loar era] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060115102212/http://www.frets.com/FRETSPages/Museum/Mandolin/Gibson/23Loar72052/23loar72052.html FRETS.COM Museum F5 page] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060514141237/http://www.mandozine.com/index.php/instruments/instrumentinfo/gibson_f_5_1924/ Mandozine F5 page] * [http://www.vintagemandolin.com/mandohistory.html VintageMandolin.com] Gibson history *[https://www.newspapers.com/clip/20009876/lloyd_loar_electric_cello/ News photo of Loar playing electric viola.] {{Gibson Guitar Corporation}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Loar, Lloyd}} [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1943 deaths]] [[Category:Luthiers]] [[Category:Physics educators]] [[Category:American composers]] [[Category:American classical mandolinists]] [[Category:Viol players]]

revision.comment: removed link to video of magic sand because video link was broken
revision.text:
'''Magic sand''' or '''hydrophobic sand''' is a [[toy]] made from [[sand]] coated with a [[hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] compound. The presence of this hydrophobic compound causes the grains of sand to adhere to one another and form [[cylinder (geometry)|cylinder]]s (to minimize [[surface area]]) when exposed to water.<ref>{{cite web|title=How to make Magic Sand|url=http://www.thegeekpub.com/1382/how-to-make-magic-water-proof-sand/|website=The Geek Pub|accessdate=3 September 2015}}</ref> When the sand is removed from water, it is completely dry and free flowing. Magic sand is also known as Aqua Sand.
[[File:Trimethylsilanol-3D-balls.png|thumb|right|[[Trimethylsilanol]]]] These properties are achieved with ordinary beach sand, which contains tiny particles of pure [[silica]], and exposing it to vapors of [[trimethylsilanol]] ([[Methyl|CH<sub>3</sub>]])<sub>3</sub>[[silicon|Si]][[hydroxyl|OH]], an [[organosilicon]] compound. Upon exposure, the trimethylsilane compound bonds to the silica particles while forming water. The exteriors of the sand grains are thus coated with [[hydrophobe|hydrophobic]] groups.
Magic sand was originally developed to trap ocean [[oil spill]]s near the shore. This would be done by sprinkling magic sand on floating petroleum, which would then mix with the oil and make it heavy enough to sink. Due to the expense of production, it is not being used for this purpose. It has also been tested by utility companies in Arctic regions as a foundation for [[junction box]]es, as it never freezes. It can be also used as an aerating medium for potted plants.
Magic sand is made in blue, green, or red in colors but appears silvery in water because of a layer of air that forms around the sand, making it unable to get wet.
The earliest reference to waterproof sand is in the 1915 book ''The Boy Mechanic Book 2'' published by ''[[Popular Mechanics]]''. The Boy Mechanic states waterproof sand was invented by East Indian [[magic (illusion)|magicians]]. The sand was made by mixing heated sand with melted [[wax]]. The wax would repel water when the sand was exposed to water.<ref>{{citation | author = G. Lee, Leonard (Publisher) | title = The Boy Mechanic Book 2, 1000 Things For A Boy To Do. Algrove Publishing - Classic Reprint Series originally published in 1915. | year = 1999}}</ref>''

page.title: Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut

revision.comment: replace [[Category:Cultural heritage]] with [[Category:Cultural heritage of Germany]] to assist with the tidy up of the former category
revision.text:
{{Infobox building | name = Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut | image = Neuenburg castle and town.jpg | caption = The cultural landscape around Naumburg Cathedral | map_type = Germany | building_type = Cultural Landscape | location = [[Saxony-Anhalt]] | location_country = Germany | coordinates = {{coord|51|9|17|N|11|48|14|E|type:landmark_region:DE-ST|display=inline,title}} | website = [http://www.naumburg-cathedral.de/ naumburg-cathedral.de] }} '''The Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut''' is situated at the heart of the [[Federal Republic of Germany]] in the State of [[Saxony-Anhalt]]. [[Naumburg Cathedral]] and the landscpae has been proposed by Germany for inscription in the [[World Heritage List|List of World Heritage]]. On July 1, 2018, only Naumburg Cathedral was listed as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage site]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.dw.com/en/germanys-naumburg-cathedral-wins-world-heritage-designation/a-44481701|title=Germany's Naumburg Cathedral wins World Heritage designation|work=[[DW-TV|DW]]|language=en|access-date=2018-07-01}} The landscape arount the World Heritage nomination "Naumburg Cathedral" is representative for processes at the [[High Middle Ages]] that shaped the whole continent: [[Christianization]], settlement and [[Cultivation (agriculture)|cultivation]] processes, the so-called [[Landesausbau]], that took place between 1000 and 1300. This borderland region also bears witness of the intercultural exchange of different cultures in the [[High Middle Ages]]. The highest-ranking buildings and works of art, most of all Naumburg Cathedral with its globally unique artistic and iconographic founder figures, provides testimony to the claims to power and the self-confidence of the worldly and spiritual rulers as well as to the region’s crucial role as a place of interchange between Western and Eastern realms. == Nomination as World Heritage == [[File:Steinmeister vineyard.jpg|thumb|Steinmeister vineyard]] In 1998, Naumburg Cathedral was inscribed into the Tentative List for World Heritage nominations and extended seven years later by its surrounding cultural [[landscape]].Tentative Lists are prepared by States Parties to the Convention on the Protection of Cultural and Natural World Heritage. They contain a number of nominiation proposals to be submitted in the future. For further information on the selection of potential World Heritage sites, please see [http://whc.unesco.org/en/criteria/ selection criteria]. ″The ′Naumburg Cathedral and the surrounding cultural landscape along the rivers [[Saale]] and [[Unstrut]]′ are outstanding and representative examples of the High Middle Ages (1000-1300). Nowhere else in the world has such a high density of monuments and cultural landscape elements from the High Middle Ages been preserved in such a small space in such a level of authenticity in its original spatial setting.″.Prof. Dr. Jeffrey Hamburger, Harvard University, Prof. Dr. Dany Sandron, Université de Paris-Sorbonne, Prof. Dr. Stefan Tebruck, Justus-Liebig-Universität Gießen a.o.(2017).{{cite book|title=The outstanding significance of the Naumburg Cathedral and the cultural landscape on the rivers Saale and Unstrut.|publisher= Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut|pages=1–2|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com/|accessdate=5 May 2017}}
{{cite web|title=Tentative List of properties for inscription in the World Heritage List|url=https://whc.unesco.org/en/tentativelists|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=5 May 2017}} In 2008, the Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V. was founded as the Sponsoring Association of the World Heritage Site by the Saale and Unstrut.{{cite web|title=Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut|url=hthttp://www.naumburg-cathedral.de|publisher=Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut|accessdate=5 May 2017}}
