The nomination was discussed on the 39th meeting of [[World Heritage Committee]].UNESCO (2015): WHC-15/39.COM/INF.19.{{cite book|title=Summary Records of the 39th session of the World Heritage Committee (Bonn, 2015).|publisher= UNESCO press|pages=206–207|url=http://whc.unesco.org/fr/sessions/39COM/documents/|accessdate=5 May 2017}} The World Heritage Committee decided to defer the nomination in order to allow for a revision and renewed submission taking into account the recommendations of the [[International Council on Monuments and Sites|ICOMOS]]-evaluation and seeking the guidance and advice by ICOMOS in the process.UNESCO (2015): WHC-15/39.COM/19.{{cite book|title=Decisions adopted at the 39th session of the World Heritage Committee (Bonn, 2015).|publisher= UNESCO press|pages=206–207|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/39COM/documents/|accessdate=5 May 2017}}
On 1 February 2016, Germany submitted a renewed submission to the [[World Heritage Centre]] in [[Paris]], [[UNESCO]].UNESCO (2017): WHC/17/41.COM/INF.8B1.{{cite book|title=Nominations to the World Heritage List (Krakow, 2017).|publisher= UNESCO press|page=54|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com/|accessdate=5 May 2017}} This nomination was discussed at the 41st meeting of the World Heritage Committee in [[Kraków]], [[Poland]], from 2 until 12 July 2017 where the Committee decided upon the Outstanding Universal Value of the Naumburg Cathedral.{{cite web|title=41st session of the World Heritage Committee in Krakow|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com|publisher=UNESCO World Heritage Centre|accessdate=5 May 2017}} Germany submitted the revised nomination "Naumburg Cathedral" on 1 February 2018. However, only [[Naumburg Cathedral]] was listed as a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage site]] on July 1, 2018. The German officials were indifferent about the decision of excluding the surrounding landscape. === Cultural landscape === The cultural landscape around the Naumburg Cathedral is a [[cultural landscape]] that illustrates the "evolution of human society and settlement over time".UNESCO (2016): WHC.16/01. {{cite book|title=Operational Guidelines for the Implementation of the World Heritage Convention.|page=11|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/guidelines|accessdate=8 May 2017}} This landscape was created intentionally by man.{{cite book|editor1-last=World Heritage Centre|title=Cultural landscapes: The challenges of conservation|chapter-url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/publications|last=Rössler|first=Mechtild|chapter=Linking Nature and Culture: World Heritage Cultural Landscapes.|year=2002|publisher=UNESCO press|page=11}}
The Naumburg Cathedral and the High Medieval Cultural Landscape of the Rivers Saale and Unstrut displays the rise of the [[Central Middle Ages]] in Europe.{{cite book|editor1-last=Haverkamp|editor-first=Alfred|editor2-last=Schieder|editor2-first=Wolfgang|title=Aufbruch und Gestaltung, Deutschland 1056-1273, Volume 1.|chapter-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Cz3bPMw_7h4C&pg=PA407|last=Le Goff|first=Jacques|chapter=The High Middle Ages.|year=1992|publisher=C.H. Beck|isbn=3406302653|page=17}} This was a time of rise, a ″take off″ due to an [[Population growth|increase in population]], [[Christianization]] and major transformation in [[agriculture]].{{cite book|editor1-last=Classen|editor-first=Albrecht|title=Handbook of Medieval Studies: Terms –Methods-Trends.|last=Newmann|first=Jonathan M.|chapter=Narratology and Literary Theory in Medieval Studies.|year=1992|publisher=De Gruyter|isbn=3110267306|page=982}} The ″Landesausbau″, [[Urban planning|urban development]], internal [[colonization]] and territorialisation, took place all across [[Europe]]. ″Never again has Europe seen such cultural and institutional uniformity as at that time″.{{cite book|editor1-last=Smyth|editor-first=William J.|editor2-last=Wehlan|editor2-first=Kevin|title=Common Ground: Essays on the Historical Geography of Ireland presented to T. Jones Huges.|last=Newmann|first=Jonathan M.|chapter=Core and Periphery in Medieval Europe: the Irish experience in a Wider Context.|year=1988|publisher=Cork|page=30}}
The nominated area serves as an extraordinary model region due to the density and quality of elements displaying mediaeval land development and land exploitation. It was a melting pot of populations of different origins, [[Franks|Frankish]], [[Thuringian]], [[Saxon]], [[Flemish]], and [[Slavs|Slavonic]]. Furthermore, as a sensitive border region, it was shaped by [[Ecclesiology|ecclesiastical]] and secular powers seeking the rights of possession, representation and defense.
In the nominated landscape, 720 elements from the period of the [[Central Middle Ages]] are still in use, establish the [[Identity (social science)|identity]] of the region and give testimony of the shaping of border lands during a period of no more than 200 years in the [[High Middle Ages]], which has in this instance been tangibly preserved to present day.{{cite book|editor1-last=Taylor|editor-first=Ken|editor2-last=Clair|editor2-first=Archer S.|editor3-last=Mitchell|editor3-first=Nora J.|title=Conserving Cultural Landscapes: Challenges and New Directions.|last=Newmann|first=Jonathan M.|chapter=Sustaining the Outstanding Universal Value of World Heritage Cultural Landscapes.|year=2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415744058|page=59}} == Description of the cultural landscape == The [[landscape]] is characterized by authentic [[monument]]s, intact [[urban morphology]] and unchanged rural landscape from the [[High Middle Ages]] visible in Naumburg and Freyburg, around the villages of Ebersroda, Schleberoda, Gross-Wilsdorf and Flemmingen, as well as the vineyards of Dechantenberg, Schweigenberg, Köppelberg, and Saalhäuser. In total, four castles and four [[Monastery|monastic complexes]], two cities as well as villages, vineyards, fertile fields and pastures constitute this nomination.UNESCO (2017): WHC/17/41.COM/INF.8B1.{{cite book|title=Nominations to the World Heritage List (Krakow, 2017).|publisher= UNESCO press|page=54|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com/|accessdate=5 May 2017}} They form a serial nomination with a total of 11 components parts : [[File:Lanscape around Neuenburg.jpg|thumb|Landscape around Neuenburg]] # [[Naumburg]] # [[Burg Schönburg|Schönburg]] # [[Goseck]] # [[Freyburg, Germany|Freyburg]] # [[Schleberoda]] # [[Ebersroda]] # [[Großwilsdorf|Rödel]] # [[Kleinjena]] # [[Pforta monastery|Pforta]] # [[Saaleck (Naumburg)|Saaleck]] # [[Flemmingen]] The nominated property is surrounded by a [[buffer zone]] ensuring the protection of relevant view axes and topographical characteristics as well as the integrity of the property. === Component: Naumburg === ==== Naumburg Cathedral ==== Naumburg Cathedral is known for its [[architecture]], [[sculpture]]s and images: ″The harmonic connection between architecture, sculpture and stained glass windows in the west choir of the cathedral counts among the most impressive creations of human creativity in the Middle Ages at large.″Prof. Dr. Jeffrey Hamburger, Harvard University, Prof. Dr. Dany Sandron, Université de Paris-Sorbonne, Prof. Dr. Stefan Tebruck, Justus-Liebig-Universität Gießen a.o.(2017).{{cite book|title=The outstanding significance of the Naumburg Cathedral and the cultural landscape on the rivers Saale and Unstrut.|publisher= Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut|pages=1–2|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/sessions/41com/|accessdate=5 May 2017}}
The [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] core structure is flanked by two [[Gothic art|Gothic]] [[Rood screen|choirs]] in the east and in the west, built in the transitional style between [[Romanesque architecture|Late Romanesque]] and [[Gothic architecture|Early Gothic]].{{cite book|editor1-last=The Metropolitan Museum of Art Bulletin v. 46, no. 3|title=Medieval Sculpture at the Cloisters.|last=Wixom|first=William D.|chapter=Medieval Sculpture.|year=1988|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|page=59}} ===== The Naumburg Masters ===== [[File:Naumburg Masters.jpg|thumb|Naumburg Masters]] The worldwide known workshop of [[Sculpture|sculptors]] and [[Stonemasonry|stonemasons]], which was likely established in the early [[13th century]], known as the [[Naumburg Master]]s, was headed by a sculptor-architect, who has been described by scholars as ″an artist of real genius″.{{cite book|editor1-last=Janson|editor-first=Horst W.|editor2-last=Janson|editor2-first=Anthony F.|title=History of Art: The Western Tradition.|date=2003|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415929356|page=407}} The quality of the work of the Naumburg Masters, marked by an extraordinary realism and individualism of sculptures and a detailed representation of the environment such as plants or ornaments, has justified Naumburg’s reputation beyond its region. The Naumburg Masters were conveyors and pioneers of the innovations in architecture and sculpture of the Late [[Hohenstaufen]] period in the [[13th century]].{{cite book|last=Williamson|first=Paul|title=Gothic Sculpture, 1140—1300.|date=October 1995|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300074522|page=185}} Their building workshop has left traces of its work all the way from Northern [[France]] over the Middle [[Rhine]] area up to the eastern boundaries of the [[Holy Roman Empire|German Empire]] and further on the southwestern [[Europe]].{{cite book|title=Skulptur, Architektur und Bautechnik des Naumburger Westchors|trans-title=Sculpture, Architecture and Building Techniques of the West Choir of Naumburg.|page=383|author=Dominik Jelschewski|publisher=Pustet, Friedrich GmbH|date=2015|language=German|isbn=3791726005}} It reflects the cultural artistic exchange during the [[High Middle Ages]].{{cite book|title=Der Naumburger Dom St. Peter and Paul - Ein Kleinod der europäischen Kulturgete. ''In: Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V.:''Macht.Glaube.Glanz: Auf dem Weg zum Welterbe.|trans-title=The cathedral of Naumburg St. Peter and Paul - A jewel of European Art history. ''In:'' Power. Glory. Faith: On the way to World Heritage.|pages=84–112|author=Kunde, Holger; Ludwig, Matthias|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783899233049}} ===== Choir screens – Passion of Christ ===== [[File:West choir.jpg|thumb|West choir]] One feature of the Naumburg Cathedral is its two almost completely preserved [[Choir (architecture)|choir]] screen structures from the 13th century.{{cite book|last=Reeve|first=Matthew M.|title=Reading Gothic Architecture|date=2008|publisher=l'Université du Michigan|isbn=9782503525365|page=31}} In the east choir, the only late [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] hall choir screen has survived. In the west choir, there is a [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] partition-type screen: ″Even within the tiny corpus of medieval churches whose original configurations of architecture and sculpture remain intact, the arrangement at Naumburg is unique.″{{cite book|last=Jung|first=Jacqueline E.|title=The gothic screen. Space, sculpture, and community in the cathedrals of France and Germany ca. 1200-1400|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=EW31mRyo8acC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Jacqueline+E.+Jung:+The+gothic+screen.&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJyJ7P_OLTAhUG0xoKHVLwBzcQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Jacqueline%20E.%20Jung%3A%20The%20gothic%20screen|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107022959|page=91}}
The western mural choir screen shows artistic quality in terms of architecture, ornamentation and figural sculptures: ″The mid-thirteenth-century west choir of Naumburg Cathedral has long been admired both for its unified architectural design″.″{{cite book|last=Jung|first=Jacqueline E.|title=The gothic screen. Space, sculpture, and community in the cathedrals of France and Germany ca. 1200-1400|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=EW31mRyo8acC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Jacqueline+E.+Jung:+The+gothic+screen.&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjJyJ7P_OLTAhUG0xoKHVLwBzcQ6AEIKTAA#v=onepage&q=Jacqueline%20E.%20Jung%3A%20The%20gothic%20screen|date=2013|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9781107022959|page=1}} The architecture has an organic character and provides information details such as historic local plants. The conceptually sophisticated arrangement of the [[Passion of Jesus|passion of Christ]] is one of the most outstanding among the preserved sculptural ensembles from the 13th century, providing i.a. detailed information on contemporary clothing. The [[Naumburg Master]] achieved a degree of dramatic expressiveness and natural vibrancy that conveys the suffering of [[Christ]] and the deep grief of [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]] and St. John.{{cite book|title=L´Arte Medievale nel contesto 300-1300. Funzioni, Iconografia, Techniche.|trans-title=The Medieval Arts from 300 until 1300. Function, iconography, technics.|page=159|author=Piva, Paolo|publisher=Editoriale Jaca Book|date=2015|language=Italian|isbn=9788816406353}} The statues of the mourning Mary and St. John catch the viewers attention and draw them close to Christ.{{cite web|url=http://www.wga.hu/html_m/zgothic/gothic/2/14g_1250.html|author=Urmee Khan|title=Medieval sculptur, German |work=Web gallery of Art|date=2008|accessdate=1 May 2017}} ===== Founder statues – Uta ===== [[File:Uta from Naumburg.jpg|thumb|[[Uta von Ballenstedt]] statue, located in the west choir of the Naumburg Cathedral]] [[File:Founder figures Hermann und Reglindis.jpg|thumb|left|Founder figures Hermann und Reglindis]] The Early Gothic west choir was built with an elevated gallery portraying the founders. The life-sized representation of a group of 12 people of the high nobility that were neither emperor neither king is unique in [[History of art|art history]] : ″The twelve founder statues […] are extraordinary in many aspects. A series of monumental representations of secular male and female founders of the cathedral of Naumburg, the statues are characterized by startling vividness and by theatrical interaction″.{{cite book|editor1-last=Hispanic Research Journal|title=Iberian and Latin American Studies |last=Karge|first=Henrik|chapter=From Naumburg to Burgos. European sculpture and dynastic politics in the thirteenth century|year=2012|publisher=Hispanic Research Journal|pages=432–444}} The statues are considered ″sculptural ensemble of the major arts″{{cite book|editor1-last=Colum|editor-first=Huriane|title=From Minor To Major. The Minor Arts in Medieval Art History|last=Wolter|first=Harald|chapter=Secular Arts: Their Order and Importance|year=2012|publisher=Princeton University|pages=66–81}} due to their expressiveness and to the individualized portraits. {{cite book|editor1-last=Krohm|editor-first=Hartmut|editor2-last=Kunde|editor2-first=Holger|title=Der Naumburger Meister, Band 3 History|last=Wolter|first=Harald|chapter=Gothic Symulachra: the “Naumburger Stifterfiguren”|year=2012|publisher=Imhof, Petersberg|isbn=9783865687425 |pages=204–2017}} There cannot be found comparable examples from the same period.
[[File:Founder figures Ekkehard und Uta.jpg|thumb|Founder figures Ekkehard und Uta]] One founder couple, [[Ekkehard II]], [[List of margraves of Meissen|Margrave of Meissen]], with his wife [[Uta von Ballenstedt]], stands in the north. Margravess Uta is presented like a queen with a fleur-de-lis crown.{{cite web|url=http://dallafinedelmondo.blogspot.de/2015/06/maestro-di-naumburg-uta-von-ballenstedt.html|title=Master of Naumburg|publisher=Daniel di Schüler|accessdate=2 May 2017}} The sculpture of Uta has experienced an unparalleled cult, due considerably to photographs taken by the Naumburger photographer Walter Hege in the 1920s.{{cite book|title=Uta von Naumburg. Eine deutsche Ikone.|trans-title=Uta from Naumburg. A German icon.|pages=84–112|author=Ulrich, Wolfgang|publisher=Wagenbach|date=2009|language=German|isbn=978-3803125231}} [[Umberto Eco]] wrote in his ″History of Beauty″ that from all women of art history, the one he would like most have dinner with was in first place, ahead of all others, Uta von Naumburg.{{cite book|last=Eco|first=Umberto|title=History of Beauty|date=2010|publisher=Rizzoli|isbn=9780847835300|page=42}} The founder figure of Uta also found her way in the [[UFA GmbH|UFA motion pictures]] and as the Queen of [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney's]] ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White]]'', causing a huge wave of enthusiasm for this icon of [[gothic art]].{{cite book|last=Pinkus|first=Assaf|title=Sculpting Simulacra in Medieval Germany, 1250-1380|date=2015|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=9781472422651|page=17}} ===== Glass painting ===== [[File:West choir Naumburg.jpg|thumb|West choir Naumburg]] The window paintings of the west choir were created from an unknown glass painting workshop in close consultation with the building workshop of the [[Naumburg Master]], together creating unity and harmony. This becomes evident by the designs of the images of the saints that correspond with the founders’ sculptures in many aspects like positions, gestures and weapons. The portrayal of ten [[Bishopric of Naumburg-Zeitz|bishops of Naumburg]] at the bottom of the window rows creates the impression as if the statues of the founders were standing on the same level as the medals. The glass paintings count among the most significant glass paintings of their style from the [[13th century]].{{cite book|title=Der Naumburger Dom St. Peter and Paul - Ein Kleinod der europäischen Kulturgeschichte. ''In: Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V.:''Macht.Glaube.Glanz: Auf dem Weg zum Welterbe.|trans-title=The cathedral of Naumburg St. Peter and Paul - A jewel of European Art history. ''In:'' Power. Glory. Faith: On the way to World Heritage.|pages=84–112|author=Kunde, Holger; Ludwig, Matthias|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783899233049}} ===== Old Town of Naumburg ===== [[File:Old city of Naumburg.jpg|thumb|Old city of Naumburg]] Naumburg was a [[Episcopal see|bishop’s seat]] and an important [[Market (place)|market place]] founded at the beginning of the [[11th century]] on the place of the former [[Slavs|Slav]] fortress of [[Wethau]]. The development of the town is closely connected with one of the most powerful and noble Ekkehardine dynasty of that time, [[Emperor Conrad II]] and [[Bishop of Zeitz|Bishop Hildeward of Zeitz]]. With the consent of the [[pope John XIX]] and the [[Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor|emperor Konrad II]], as well as citing the danger of Slav incursions, [[margrave]] Ekkerhard I relocated the [[Episcopal see|Episcopal See]] of Zeitz to Naumburg. Along with the bishop’s seat he transferred his own family seat from Kleinjena to their own estate at the new castle ″Nuwemburch″ in Naumburg around 1028. Furthermore, he assigned the protection of the See to the ″new castle″, an event hitherto unparalleled in the history of the empire.{{cite web|url=http://www.vereinigte-domstifter.de/en/foundation/the-combined-cathedral-chapters/domstift-naumburg|title= Naumburg Cathedral Chapter: Outcome of an Unprecedented Relocation of an Episcopal See |publisher=Combined Chapters of the Cathedrals of Merseburg and Naumburg and the Collegiate Church of Zeitz|accessdate=7 May 2017}} This bold move enabled the construction of the first early [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] cathedral in Naumburg.
[[File:Certificate Naumburg.jpg|thumb|left|Certificate Naumburg]] In 1033, another highly unusual event for this time took place: On the initiative of the bishop Kadeloh of Memleben, Emperor Conrad II granted the merchants of Kleinjena, who moved to Naumburg free trade and the heritable, interest-free ownership of their enclosed domicile.{{cite book|last=Reuter|first=Timothy|title=Germany in the Early Middle Ages c.800 – 1056 (Longman History of Germany)|date= 2013|publisher=Lucent Books|isbn=9780582081567|pages=42–50}} It is the earliest dated written document from 13 July 1033, that marked the Nuvemburg to the powerful market and merchant settlement in Naumburg.{{cite book|title=Urkundenbuch des Hochstifts Naumburg: Teil 1 (967-1207)|trans-title=The book of documents of the Bishopric Naumburg: Part1 |page=26|author=Rosenfeld, Felix|publisher=Magdeburg|date=1925|language=German}}
Margraves Ekkehard II and Hermann also established two monasteries, the [[Benedictine monastery|Benedictine Monastery]] of St. George and the St Moritz Monastery. When the Ekkehardine dynasty died out by 1046, the bishops became the rulers of the town. By that time, Naumburg had already developed into a political, economic and religious center for the entirety of this border region. The trade routes in the region were relocated to Naumburg, which was strategically situated at the crossing of the [[Via Regia]] and the Regensburg Road.{{cite book|last=Jeep|first=John M.|title=Medieval Germany: An Encyclopedia|date=October 2001|publisher=Garland|isbn=9781135575069|page=558}} Nowadays, the roads as well as parcel structures reflect the structure of the medieval civil town. The earliest stone buildings in Naumburg are situated in the cathedral precincts with the oldest residential tower of Naumburg with two Romanesque floors constructed probably in the mid-12th century at the cathedral precincts. === Component: Freyburg === [[File:Church of Freyburg.jpg|thumb|Church of Freyburg]] The old town of Freyburg is situated 9 kilometers north of Naumburg on the left bank of the Unstrut River. This component contains Neuenburg Castle above the river valley. {{cite web|url=http://www.schloss-neuenburg.de/|title= Freyburg Palace|publisher=Neuenburg|accessdate=2 May 2017}} The Schweigenberg vineyard stretches along the slopes towards Zscheiplitz Monastery. ==== Neuenburg Castle ==== [[File:Neuenburg Chapel.jpg|thumb|left|Neuenburg Chapel]] Around 1090, it was most probably [[Louis the Springer]] who built the vast and impressive complex of Neuenburg Castle. Situated in the border region, this fortified castle served military purposes and reflected ambitions, self-confidence and sophistication of the [[Ludovingians|Ludowingians]]. Already in 1100, Neuenburg Castle was the largest and most important fortification in central Germany and remained of outstanding political and military significance until the [[13th century]]. It was designed as a border castle for the powerful Ludowinger dynasty and was part of a network of the landgraves’ castles, which also included [[Wartburg Castle]].{{cite book|title=Die romanische Neuenburg bei Freyburg (Unstrut) und ihre Stellung im hochmittelalterlichen Burgenbau. ''In: Boje E. H.Schmuhl, Konrad Breitenborn (Ed): Schloss Neuenburg.|trans-title=The romanic Neuenburg close to Freyburg (Unstrut) and its role in the medieval castle-building. ''In:''Neuenburg Palace.|pages=67–69|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Wettin-Löbejün OT Dößel|date=2012|language=German}}
[[File:Neuenburg Castle.jpg|thumb|Neuenburg at night]] Built around 1090, Neuenburg Castle was extended and modernized on a large scale several times. With its 30 000 square meters, the [[castle]] was amongst the strongest architectural representations of military power in all of the empire. It has survived to a remarkable extend: Major sections of the curtain walls in the north and east, part of the gate, the bottom part of the cattle, the castle keep, trenches in the east and in the south are conserved until today. The [[landmark]] big William (Dicker Wilhelm) is situated in the north-eastern part of the complex and visible from far away as a symbol of power. The castle keep III is classified as an independent development next to the French residential towers (donjons) which produced similar examples in the [[Rhineland]] region. Around 1225, a residential tower (residential tower II) was built probably for the landgrave’s family outside the southern curtain wall.{{cite book|title=Schloß Neuenburg bei Freyburg/Unstrut. Anmerkungen zur Baugeschichte der Vorburg. ''In: Sachsen Anhalt:''Burgen und Schlösser in Sachsen Anhalt 12.|trans-title=Neuenburg Palace near Freyburg/Unstrut. Comments on the history of the Castle. ''In:'' Castles and Palaces in Saxony-Anhalt.|pages=150–152|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Saxony-Anhalt|date=2003|language=German}} 1172 Emperor [[Friedrich I Barbarossa]] visited Neuenburg Castle – the legend of the “living wall” of soldiers providing the best military defense has its roots in this legendary visit.{{cite book|title=Sagenbuch von Eisenach und der Wartburg: 44 Sagen von Eisenach und der Wartburg.|trans-title=The book of Legends of Eisenach and Wartburg Castle: 44 legends from Eisenach and Wartburg Castle.|pages=150–152|author=Bechstein, Ludwig|publisher=Rockstuhl|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783936030884}}
[[File:Residence building at Neuenburg.jpg|thumb|Residence building at Neuenburg]] The court culture of the [[Count palatine|Count Palatine]] at Neuenburg Castle was an extremely important center of literary activities in the Empire at the end of the [[12th century in Germany|12th]] and beginning of the [[13th century]]. The most important poets of the 13th century, namely [[Wolfram von Eschenbach]] and [[Walther von der Vogelweide]] stayed at Neuenburg Castle. Heinrich von Weldecke completed here the [[Eneas]] novel which was the foundation of the [[German language]] secular epic. ″When Veldeke was called to the court of Thuringia [..], he joined the entourage of a great patron and became the esteemed center of the most important literary circle that existed in Germany at the time″.{{cite book|last=Bunke|first=Joachim|title=Courtly Culture: Literature and Society in the High Middle Ages|date=1991|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=9780520066342|page=492}}
[[File:Neuenburg view.jpg|thumb|left|Neuenburg view]] The Double Chapel of Neuenburg was developed around 1220 and is one of the best preserved [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque buildings]] of Neuenburg Castle.{{cite book|title=Handbuch der deutschen Kunstdenkmäler.Band I. Mitteldeutschland|trans-title=Handbook of German documents. Part I. Middle Germany|page=115|author=Dehio, Georg; Gall, Ernst|publisher=Deutscher Kunstverlag|date=1924|language=German|isbn=9783422030237}}
In terms of its architectural shapes and structural ornamentation, it is a unique achievement by combining the Saxon tradition with the then latest developments in art which emerged in the Rhineland region.{{cite book|title=Ueber Schloßcapellen als Ausdruck des Einflusses der weltlichen Macht auf die geistliche. Ein Vortrag.|trans-title=About cathedrals as expression of secular power over religious power. An Essay|page=115|author=Quast, Ferdinand |publisher=Schultze|date=1852|language=German}}
The upper floor of the Double Chapel is a landmark of art because of the play of colors of the black column shafts made of carboniferous limestone, which came from the Northern [[France|French]] and [[Belgium|Belgian region]] of the [[Ardennes]], 500 kilometers away with the multi-coloured structural ornamentation.{{cite book|title=Schloss Neuenburg. Die größte Burg der Landgrafen von Thürigen.''In: Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V.:''Macht.Glaube.Glanz: Auf dem Weg zum Welterbe.|trans-title=Neuenburg Castle. The biggest castle of the margraves of Thuringia.''In:''Power. Glory. Faith: On the way to World Heritage.|pages=147–177|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783899233049}} The polyglobed arches on the underside of the transverse arches are an example for the influences from the Morish part of [[Spain]] transmitted by Rhenanian Art. They are the only example of this form of ornament to the east of the [[Rhine]] and thus represent a unique item in [[History of architecture|architectural history]]. ==== Old town of Freyburg ==== [[File:Neuenburg view from Freyburg.jpg|thumb|Neuenburg view from Freyburg]] In the last quarter of the 12th, [[Hermann I, Landgrave of Thuringia|Herman I]] from the [[Ludowinger]] dynasty founded the town of Freyburg. The town was built at the food of Neuenburg Castle around a rectangular market place to meet the demands of the increased population, to provide the Neuenburg Castle with merchandise and to secure the passage and revenues of the [[Unstrut|Unstrut River]]. The [[Landgrave of Thuringia|landgraves of Thuringia]] controlled the road in the valley by erecting this fortified town. The determinative ″frey″ (free) referred to the royal freedom granted to it when it was founded and to the baronial privilege of a nearly royal rank, which primarily reveals the self-image of its rulers.{{cite book|title=Freyburg an der Unstrut – Ein Beispiel landesherrlicher Städtepolitik. ''In: Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V.:''Macht.Glaube.Glanz: Auf dem Weg zum Welterbe.|trans-title=Freyburg at Unstrut - an example of urban policies.''In:''Power. Glory. Faith: On the way to World Heritage.|pages=147–177|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783899233049}} The unity of Neuenburg castle and the town of Freyburg is a typical feature of the policy of power of the Ludowingers.{{cite book|title=Landgräfliche Städte in Thüringen: die Städtepolitik der Ludowinger im 12. und 13. Jahrhundert.|trans-title=Towns of landgroves in Thuringia. The politics of the Ludowingers in the 12th and 13th century.|pages=65–74|author=Müller, Christine|publisher=Böhlau|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783412116026}} The landgraves were not directly present in the town but resided in Neuenburg Castle. [[Louis IV, Landgrave of Thuringia|Landgrove Ludwig IV]] and his wife, the later Saint [[Elizabeth of Hungary]], built the town parish church of St Mary’s to emphasize the baronial need for representation.{{cite book|editor1-last=Brekle|editor-first=Herbert E.|editor2-last=Dobnig-Jiilich|editor2-first=Edeltraud a.o.|title=New German Biography (NDB)|last=Barrera|first=Magdalena|chapter=Ludwig IV the Saint, Landgrave of Thuringia and Count Palatine of Saxony. |year=1987|publisher=Duncker & Humblot|isbn= 3428001826|page=422}} The capital ornamentation in the entrance area with its diamond-shaped net and the Romanesque sculpting of the compact [[Tympanum (architecture)|tympanum]] is of outstanding quality in the way of the curves of the bodies and the graphic lines of the figures were sculptured. Freyburg’s regular layout is a grid of roads crossing each other in right angles, a distinct transverse axis and its nearly exact subdivision in blocks. After the extinction of the [[Ludovingians|Ludowinger dynasty]] in 1247, the city lost its significance but continued its [[viticulture]] for which it is still known in the [[Saale-Unstrut|Saale-Unstrut region]] today.{{cite book|title=Beziehungen zwischen Kulturlandschaften und Tourismus. Dargestellt am Beispiel der Saale-Unstrut-Region im Bundesland Sachsen-Anhalt.|trans-title=Relationship between cultural landscapes and tourism. Presented on the example of the region Saale-Unstrut.|author=Friedel, Juliane|publisher=Diplomica Verlag|date=2002|language=German.|isbn=9783838666389}} ==== Zscheiplitz Monastery ==== [[File:Church in Zscheiplitz.jpg|thumb|Church in Zscheiplitz]] The [[Benedictine]] convent of nuns, the Zscheiplitz Monastery, was first mentioned in 1203 and is situated two kilometers west of Freyburg. The name of Zscheiplitz has its roots in the Slavic name ″ciplic″ (small). Around 1085, after the murder of [[Friedrich III, Landgraf of Thuringia|landgrave Friedrich III]], his widow Adelheid donated the estate of Zscheiplitz to the church. It was then turned into a Benedictine monastery.{{cite book|title= Zscheiplitz. Sühnekirche, Kloster, Rittergut, Dorfkirche, Weingut. ''In: Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V.:''Macht.Glaube.Glanz: Auf dem Weg zum Welterbe.|trans-title=Zscheiplitz. Church, monastery, manor house, village church, vineyard. ''In:'' Power. Glory. Faith: On the way to World Heritage.|pages=84–112|author=Schmitt, Reinhard|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783899233049}} [[File:Zscheiplitz view.jpg|thumb|Zscheiplitz view]] The church of Zscheiplitz was built as a one-nave church in the 12th century and extended by a gallery to the west and in the north during the 13th century.{{cite web|url=https://zscheiplitz.com/history/|title=Official Website of the Zscheiplitz Monastery|publisher=zscheiplitz monastery|accessdate=7 May 2017}} ==== Vineyard of Schweigenberg ==== The [[vineyard]] of Schweigenberg is located west of Freyburg and was probably created by citizens of Freyburg upon the initiative of the [[List of rulers of Thuringia|landgraves of Thuringia]] and / or the monasteries of Goseck and Zscheiplitz in the 13th century. It benefitted from favorable climatic conditions and agrarian innovations for a diversified subsistence economy in the region. This vineyard is still recognized in Germany as a prime example of [[Wine-growing in Germany|terraced winegrowing]] by way of hoe-farming as a monument of this traditional form of cultivation. === Component: Pforta === [[File:Pforta from air.jpg|thumb|left|Pforta from air]] The [[Pforta|monastery of Pforta]] was created by the [[Cistercian Order]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kloster-pforta.de/#/#4/|title=Official Website of Pforta Monastery|publisher=Pforta monastery|accessdate=7 May 2017}} The premises include functional buildings, the Romanesque House ([[Monastic grange|grange]]), the Kleine Saale [[canal]], as well as the vineyards of Köppelberg and Saalhäuser. The ensemble of Cistercian monuments attests to the order’s life and work and embodies the significant influence exerted in the wider [[Saale-Unstrut|Saale-Unstrut region]] and beyond the boundaries of the region. ==== History ==== [[File:Monastery Pforta.jpg|thumb|Monastery Pforta]] Pforta Monastery was founded around 1132 on the initiative of [[Bishopric of Naumburg-Zeitz|bishop Udo I of Naumburg]].{{cite book|title=Das Zisterzienserkloster Sankt Marien zur Pforte.''In: Förderverein Welterbe an Saale und Unstrut e.V.:''Macht.Glaube.Glanz: Auf dem Weg zum Welterbe.|trans-title= The Cistercian monastery Sankt Marien to Pforta. ''In:'' Power. Glory. Faith: On the way to World Heritage.|pages=236–249|author=Kunde, Holger; Ludwig, Matthias|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2015|language=German|isbn=9783899233049}} It received only a very modest endowment of the order In order to be self-sufficient, it was located in the flood plain on the right bank of the Saale River to ensure sufficient water supply.{{cite book|title=Wirtschaft und Kulturlandschaft. Gesammelte Beiträge 1977 – 1999 zur Geschichte der Zisterzienser und der ″Germania Slavica″.|trans-title=Economy and cultural landscape. Essays 1977 - 1999 on the history of the Cistercians and the ″Germania Slavica″.|author=Schich, Winfried|publisher=Berliner Wissenschafts-Verlag|date=2007|language=German.|isbn=9783830503781}}
The monks cultivated previous wetland areas and the monastery became soon one of the wealthiest and most influential monasteries throughout Central Germany for 400 years before it was closed in the course of the Reformation.A saying of the 12th century states the immense cultivation and colonization capacity of the Cistercians ''″Give the monks a moor or a wild forest, let some years pass by, and you will find not only beautiful churches but also human settlements at this place″''.
The name of Porta, meaning Porta Coeli – i.e. Pearly Gates – , refers to the architecture of the richly ornamented western façade of the minster with its Roman triumphal arch portal and a gallery underneath the crucifixion group that did not at all correspond to the strict stipulations of the order. ==== Architecture ==== [[File:Facade of Monastery Pforta.jpg|thumb|left|Facade of Monastery Pforta]] The [[minster (church)|minster]] was built in the 1130s in the plain character of the [[Cistercian architecture|Cistercians monasteries]].{{cite book|last=Jeep|first=John M.|title=Germany. An Encyclopedia.|date=2001|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9780203801765|page=127}} In 1251, the Cistercians decided on an ambitious building project. Even though the new church building with its west façade was still ascetic in the interior decor, it clearly reflected the significant economic and political power of the monastery. The Gothic [[Choir (architecture)|choir]] of the minster is the architectural example of the regional [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] reception with French roots, transferring the latest shapes and forms inspired by French Gothic design and adapting them to local conditions. The glass paintings of the church, including in Europe’s oldest Cistercian tracery rose window preserved almost completely together with its glazing, are an extraordinary treasure of medieval paintings. [[File:Chapel of Monastery Pforta.jpg|thumb|Chapel of Monastery Pforta]] The so-called Abbot’s Chapel (Abtskapelle) is considered to be an outstanding architectural example of the medieval infirmaries and nursing wards of the [[Cistercians|Cistercian monks]]. Before its conversion into an [[abbot]]’s home, it had been part of the infirmary wing, allowing people to participate in the mass from there. Rare elements were found in the structure such as the latrine and the chamber of the [[Hospital|infirmary]]. ==== Hydraulic system ==== In 1180, the [[Cistercians|Cistercian monks]] created the [[Romanesque art|Romanesque]] mill race called ″Kleine Saale″ (Little Saale), a [[canal]] of 10 kilometers length.{{cite book|title=Die Kulturlandschaft um Schulpforta. ''In: Forschungen zum Kloster Schulpforta. Ergebnisse eines Arbeitsprojekts im Rahmen des Graduiertenkollegs Kunstwissenschaft, Bauforschung, Denkmalpflege.|trans-title= The cultural landscape around Pforta.''In:'' Research on the monastery Pforta. Results of a project in the framework of a graduate programme Arts sciences, monument preservation, historical building research.|pages=94–95|author=Fechter, Sabine|publisher=University Bamberg|date=2003|language=German}} The mill inside the monastery is one of the most significant and oldest preserved functional buildings in [[Central Germany (cultural area)|Central Germany]]. The Benedictine monks of St George, the canons of St Moritz in Naumburg, and the Naumburg cathedral chapter participated in the costs and maintenance of the Kleine Saale in return for rights of utilization. Maintenance work was managed by a water expert from Pforta Monastery and the highest-ranking fisherman from the Naumburg. The Kleine Saale shows the Cistercian [[hydraulic engineering]] at that time.{{cite book|title=Die Wirtschaftstätigkeit der Zisterzienser im Mittelalter, Agrarwirtschaft.''In:'' Wirtschaft und Kulturlandschaft.|pages=84–112|trans-title=The economy of the Cisterciansin the Middle-Ages. ''In'' Economy and cultural landscape. Essays 1977 - 1999 on the history of the Cistercians and the ″Germania Slavica″.|author=Ribbe, Wolfgang|publisher=Berliner Wissenschafts-Verlag|date=2007|language=German.|isbn=9783830503781}} ==== Grange ==== The Romanesque House is an impressive piece of evidence of a former [[Monastic grange|grange]] of Pforta Monastery that was constructed to ensure economic independence. They were run by bearded lay brothers (conversi). The foundation of those granges was made possible because many rulers assigned possessions in return for burial rights for family members on the monastery grounds. The Cistercians successfully sold agricultural and craft products on the markets in [[Halle (Saale)|Halle]], Naumburg, [[Jena]] and [[Erfurt]]. With even greater success, they managed to enlist parts of the peasant population into their service, offering the liege lords compensation payments for their release from personal bondage. As a result of its aggressive economic policy of establishing granges, Pforta acquired a charter in 1215 to transport carts and loads through the [[Margravate of Meissen|margraviates of Meissen]] and [[Lower Lusatia]] – and thus to [[Silesia]] – without being charged [[tax]]es or dues.{{cite book|title=Das Zisterzienserkloster Pforte: die Urkundenfälschungen und die frühe Geschichte bis 1236.|trans-title=The Cistercian monastery Pforta: Document fraud and early history until 1236.|author=Kunde, Holger|publisher=Böhlau Verlag|date=2003|language=German.|isbn=9783412146016}} ==== Winemaking ==== The Cistercian monks set about profitably using the land they had bought in a single-minded, well-planned and versatile way. Economic activities of the Cistercians included quarrying, the planting of vines on the slopes of the Saale and other suitable areas, the planting of [[orchard]]s, the establishment of smithies, workshops for weaving, fur production and shoe-making, the setting-up of bakeries and cheese dairies as well as intense sheep rearing, grain growing, timber rafting and fishing. The Cistercians expanded their property from the Köppelberg vineyard, and created nine steep [[Vineyard|slope vineyards]] between 1195 and 1208. At the end of the [[Middle Ages]], the monastery owned 58 vineyards between Bad Kösen and Roßbach. Cellar and wine masters at Pforta ensured high quality in wine making, measuring it according to vinum bonum (1226), vinum melius (1289) or vinum terrestre (country wine, around 1340).{{cite book|title=Die Zisterzienser und ihre Weinberge in Brandenburg.Studien zur Geschichte, Kunst und Kultur der Zisterzienser.|trans-title=The Cistercians and their vineyards in Brandenburg. Studies on history, arts and culture of the Cistercians.|author=Fröhlich, Johann|publisher=Lukas Verlag|date=2002|language=German.|isbn=9783867320894}} == History == [[File:Sandstone, Saale-Unstrut.jpg|thumb|Sandstone, Saale-Unstrut]] The area provided moderate climate, fertile soils, rich water sources and wood supply through forests and was populated by [[Stone Age]] hunters 380 000 years ago . From the [[Neolithic Age]] onwards throughout all [[Prehistory|prehistoric times]], the area was settled.{{cite book|last=Bogucki|first=Peter|title=Forest Farmers and Stockherders. Early Agriculture and its consequences in North-Central Europe.|date=1988|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521329590|pages=93–96}} === The Early Middle Ages === [[File:Ebersorda.jpg|thumb|Ebersorda]] The [[Migration Period]] brought decisive changes from 375 AD onwards and also had an influence on the [[Saale-Unstrut|Saale-Unstrut region]]. The local population, consisting of migrating [[Germanic peoples|Germanic Varini]] and Angles, merged to form the [[Thuringians]]. Following the defeat of the Thuringian army by Frankish troops in 531, the [[Merovingians]] as Frankish rulers settled groups of [[Frisians]], [[Angles]], [[Saxons]] and probably also [[Hessian (soldier)|Hessians]] to the south and north of the Unstrut in exchange for payment of [[Lay Tithes|tithes]].{{cite book|editor1-last=Fries-Knoblach|editor-first=Janine|editor2-last=Steuer|editor2-first=Heiko|title=The Baiuvarii and Thuring|last=Steuer|first=Heiko|chapter=Thuringians and Bavarians – Location in Space and Time and Social Relations|year=2014|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn= 9781843839156|pages=111–114}}{{cite book|editor1-last=Wood|editor-first=Ian|title=Franks and Alamanni in the Merovingian Period: An Ethnographic Perspective|last=Dumminger|first=Areas F.|chapter=Dwellings, settlements and settlement patterns of the sixth and seventh centuries in southwest Germany and adjacent areas.|year=2014|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|isbn= 9781843830351|pages=33–36}}
These settlers were met by [[Sorbs (tribe)|Slav Sorb tribes]] originating from the region of the [[Dnieper]], who came westward as far as the [[Saale|River Saale]], crossed it repeatedly and beginning to settle on its western banks. The [[Sorbs]] had more than 50 civitates, meaning central strongholds with relating settlements. Such a fortified district or “Gau” developed on the site of today’s town of Naumburg and was called “Wethau”; the centre was a Sorb castle complex in Wettaburg (now an urban district of Naumburg) . The region by the Saale and Unstrut rivers had thus become a sensitive border area because it marked the border between the peoples of Germanic and [[Slavs|Slav]] origin and also the north-eastern border of [[Christianity]] in continental [[Europe]]. {{cite book|last=Stone|first=Gerald|title=The smallest slavonic nation. The sorbs of Lusatia.|date=2015|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|isbn=9781474241540|pages=8–12}}{{cite book|last=Gwynn|first=David M.|title=Christianity in the Later Roman Empire. A sourcebook.|date=2014|publisher=Bloomsbury Academic|isbn=9781441106261|page=277}}
In 766, a successful Frankish attack was launched against Wettaburg Castle, that was the headquarters of the [[Sorbs]] in the Saale-Unstrut region. The [[Frankish empire|Frankish Empire]] was at its largest during the reign of [[Pepin the Short|Pippin]]’s son [[Charlemagne]] (768 – 814). {{cite book|last=Story|first=Johanna|title=Charlemagne: Empire and Society.|date=2005|publisher=Manchester University Press|isbn=9780719070891|page=183}} In a very bloody war lasting almost thirty years (772 – 804), the pagan [[Saxons]] were conquered and their territory was fully integrated into the [[Frankish empire|Frankish Empire]]. As elsewhere, Christianization ran parallel to military subjugation in the Saxon area.{{cite book|last=Fletcher|first=Richard A.|title=The Barbarian Conversion: From Paganism to Christianity.|date=1999|publisher=University of California Press|page=194}} The [[Saale]] remained the lasting natural border with the Slavic territories. In conjunction with the hinterland, the Saale was protected from possible attacks from the east by a chain of closely neighboring strongholds and fortifications,including the ″[[Limes Sorabicus]]″.
The territory of the [[Frankish Empire]] extended in the first quarter of the [[9th century]] from the [[Iberian Peninsula]] in the west to the Elbe and Saale in the east, from the [[North Sea]] in the north to [[Central Italy]] in the south.{{cite book|last=Moore|first=Michael E.|title=A Sacred Kingdom: Bishops and the Rise of Frankish Kingship|date=2011|publisher=Catholic University of America Press|isbn=9780813218779|page=286}} Thus most of Christian Europe was united in [[Charlemagne]]’s hands. However, Charlemagne’s successors were not able to maintain Imperial unity.{{cite book|last=Collins|first=Roger|title=Charlemagne.|date=1998|publisher=University of Toronto Press|isbn=9780333650554|page=160}}
In 919, Heinrich, the duke of Saxony, also known as [[Henry the Fowler]], became king of the Franks and the Saxons. As a result, the Saale-Unstrut region moved from a peripheral position in the Frankish empire to the focus of political interest. Heinrich expanded his power along the eastern border of the Empire by conquering the Slav tribes (928/929) and defeating the [[Hungarians]] by the Unstrut in 933.{{cite book|last=Emmerson|first=Richard K.|title=Key Figures in Medieval Europe: An Encyclopedi.|date=2013|publisher=Routeledge|isbn=9780415973854|page=314}} As a result of Heinrich I’s expansion policy and the conquest of the Slav tribes, the character of the area east of the Saale and Unstrut changed from a direct border area to a connecting region between the old settlement land to the west and the newly conquered regions by the Elbe.{{cite book|last=Leyser|first=Karl|title=Medieval Germany and its Neighbours, 900-1250.|date=1982|publisher=A&C Black|page=12}}
With the consent of the Pope and the German Imperial bishops, the Emperor arranged for [[diocese]]s and bishop’s churches to be established in [[Merseburg Cathedral|Merseburg]], [[Zeitz]] and [[Meissen]] in 968, forming a new church province for the eastern part of the Empire within the equally newly founded [[archbishopric of Magdeburg]]. ==== The High Middle Ages ==== [[File:Schleberoda.jpg|thumb|Schleberoda]] From the [[10th century]] onwards, the Ekkehardine dynasty gained influence in the Empire. Contemporaneous Bishop [[Thietmar of Merseburg]] described the first prominent representative of this house, [[Ekkehard I]], as a person with an outstanding lack of humility ″He was an ornament to the Empire, a treasure of the land, a hope for his subjects and a terror to his enemies and he would have been completely perfect if he had only been able to remain humble″.{{cite book|last=Merseburg|first=Thietmar of|title=Chronicles V.}}
After the murder of the margrave Ekkehard I on 30 April 1002, Ekkehard’s sons, Margrave Hermann (1009 – 1038) and [[Eckard II, Margrave of Meissen|Margrave Ekkehard II]] (1009 – 1046), assumed power in 1009. They became the most powerful rulers in the eastern part of the Empire and moved their family seat from Kleinjena to the ″Neue Burg″ (New Castle, Naumburg). The rise of Naumburg as ecclesiastical, political, cultural and economic centre of the Saale-Unstrut region had begun.{{cite book|last=Bagge|first=Sverre|title=Kings, Politics, and the Right Order of the World in German Historiography: C. 950-1150.|date=2002|publisher=Brill|isbn=9780415973854|page=117}} In this context, it has to be emphasized that Sorb ″Smurds″ and German residents lived largely peacefully alongside each other.{{cite book|title= Slaven und Deutsche. Ethnische Wahrnehmungen und Deutungsmuster in der hoch- uns spätmittelalterlichen Germania Slavica. ''In: Ostsiedlung und Landesausbau in Sachsen. Die Kührener Urkunde von 1154 und ihr historisches Umfeld.|trans-title=Slav and Germans. Ethnic reception in High Middle Ages and Late Middle Ages. ''In:'' Eastern settlement and Landesausbau in Saxony.|page=46|author=Weigel, Petra|publisher=Leipziger Universitätsverlag|date=2008|language=German|isbn=9783886801411}}
[[File:Certificate Emperor Conrad.tif|thumb|Certificate Emperor Conrad]] The [[bishops of Naumburg]], the [[Landgrave of Thuringia|landgraves of Thuringia]] and the [[margraves of Meissen]] as lords of the town of Naumburg promoted a systematic development of the city into the most important town in the Saale-Unstrut region. In March 1131, Bishop Udo I met the Cistercian abbot [[Bernard of Clairvaux]] at the Imperial Diet in Liège in March 1131, a meeting of central significance for the propagation of the [[Cistercians|Cistercian order]] in the Empire. As a result, a delegation of monks from the Walkenried Cistercian monastery moved to a location next to Naumburg in 1137/1138. The founding of the Cistercian Pforta Monastery contributed to the propagation of the Order on to Eastern Europe. One of the greatest achievements of Pforta Monastery was furthermore the settlement of peasants in these regions.{{cite book|title= Mittelalter.|trans-title=Middle Ages. |author=Müller, Harald|publisher=Walter de Gruyter GmbH & Co|date=2008|language=German|isbn=9783050043661}} This so-called ″Landesausbau″ in the High Middle Ages was supplemented by military protection of the positions already achieved.Due to increase of population, new public assignments of protection and administration for the diocese of Naumburg led to crucial changes in social structure. The prestige attained by the Naumburg bishop’s seat is expressed by the construction of a new cathedral around 1210 during the period of office of Bishop Engelhard (1206 – 1242).
For the Saale-Unstrut region, the Ludowingers were, together with the Wettin dynasty, the most influential aristocratic dynasty during the 12th and the 13th century. The Ludowingers created a princely court culture modeled to equal royal forms. The magnificent court of Count Palatine Hermann of Saxony (1181 – 1217) at Neuenburg Castle was an extremely important center of literary activities in the Empire.{{cite book|title= Im Schatten der Landgrafen: Studien zur adeligen Herrschaftsbildung im hochmittelalterlichen Thüringen.|trans-title=In the shadow of the margraves. Studies on the nobility in medieval Thuringia |author=Wittmann, Helge.|page=175|publisher=Böhlau|date=2008|language=German|isbn=9783412223052}}
The [[Wettin, Saxony-Anhalt|Wettins]], with Margrave Heinrich the Illustrious (1221 – 1288), were appointed as margraves to the east of the Saale. They were able to expand their territories and achieved political dominance in the whole Central German region during the [[13th century in Germany|13th century]], creating most favorable conditions for their homelands in the Saale-Unstrut region. The cooperation of the Cistercians with the Wettin and [[Ludovingians|Ludowinger]] dynasties contributed to the transfer of spiritual, cultural and technological knowledge into the areas intended for colonization. Nevertheless, the economic emphasis moved gradually towards the east during the [[Late Middle Ages]], when the importance of the relatively young [[Leipzig|town of Leipzig]] outdid that of the old trade fair town of Naumburg.{{cite book|title=Die Bedeutung der Zisterzienser für die Ostsiedlung, besonders in Ostschlesien.|trans-title=The importance of the Cistercians for the Eastern Settlement|page=68|author=Gottschalck, Joseph|publisher=Zeitschrift für Ostforschung|date=1966|language=German}} === From the late Middle Ages to the Present === Following the [[Reformation]] instigated by [[Martin Luther]](1485 – 1546) in nearby [[Wittenberg]], the Wettins and the region’s nobility turned to [[Protestantism]], promoting and funding the reformers. As a result of the alliance of Protestant rulers and spiritual leaders, the monasteries and religious establishments in Naumburg, Goseck, Zscheiplitz and Pforta were closed between 1533 and 1540 and their endowments and properties confiscated. Only the property rights held by the Naumburg Cathedral chapter remained untouched.{{cite book|last=Ocker|first=Christopher|title=Church Robbers and Reformers in Germany, 1525-1547: Confiscation and Religious Purpose in the Holy Roman Empire.|date=2006|publisher=University of Michigan|isbn=9789004152069|pages=50–60}}
[[File:Vineyard Steinmeister.jpg|thumb|Vineyard Steinmeister]] From the [[18th century]] on, the castles along the Saale and Unstrut amidst their cultural landscape became prime subjects of [[Romanticism|romantic]] admiration. As a result of the [[First Congress of Vienna|Congress of Vienna]], the [[kingdom of Saxony]] was forced to cede territories to the Prussian king in 1815. The landscape by the [[Saale]] and [[Unstrut]] now became part of the [[Prussian state]] until the end of the [[Second World War]]. Unlike many other regions, no drastic changes due to [[Industrialisation|industrialization]] altered this landscape. It was due to Walter Hege’s photographs published in 1925, that the founder figure of [[Uta of Schauenburg|Uta]] became enormously popular but was exploited during the [[National Socialists]]’ regime. The regime turned Neuenburg Castle into a training centre for senior leaders of the German Girls’ Association (BDM) and the school at Pforta Monastery into a National Political Education Centre (NAPOLA) until the end of the regime.{{cite book|title= Forschungen zum Kloster Schulpforta: Ergebnisse eines Arbeitsprojektes im Rahmen des Graduiertenkollegs "Kunstwissenschaft-Bauforschung-Denkmalpflege" der Otto-Friedrich-Universität Bamberg und der Technischen Universität Berlin.|trans-title=Research on Monastery Pforta: Results of a working project and the Technical University Berlin. |author=Hubel, Achim; Cramer, Johannes|publisher=Janos Stekovics|date=2003|language=German|isbn=9783899230253}}
The Saale-Unstrut region was spared destruction during the [[Second World War]]. The liberation by American troops in the spring of 1945 was followed in the summer of the same year by hand-over of the area to the [[Red Army]] and the Saale-Unstrut region thus became part of [[East Germany]] (GDR). There was no attempt in the Saale-Unstrut area to demolish old town quarters. After the [[Reunification of Germany|reunification of the two German states]] in 1990 the well-preserved cultural landscape of the Saale-Unstrut region became part of the [[Saxony-Anhalt|Federal State of Saxony-Anhalt]]. ==See also== * [[World Heritage Convention]] * [[World Heritage site]] * [[World Heritage Committee]] * [[High Middle Ages]] * [[Cultural landscape|Cultural Landscape]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Notes== {{reflist|30em|group=note}} ==External links== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6FPjj5cWWCg Video of the cultural landscape of Naumburg] [[Category:Cultural heritage of Germany]] [[Category:Cultural studies]] [[Category:High Middle Ages]] [[Category:Landscape]] [[Category:Saxony-Anhalt]]

revision.comment: Updating URL format for [[The New York Times]] archives
revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist <!--(Template:Infobox scientist/doc)--> |name = Otto Frederick Hunziker |image = OFHunziker_1909.jpg |image_size = |caption = Swiss-American Dairy Pioneer |birth_date = 25 December 1873 |birth_place = [[Zürich]], Switzerland |death_date = 16 November 1959 |death_place = [[La Grange, Illinois]], United States |residence = United States |citizenship = United States |nationality = Swiss |fields = [[Dairy]], [[Dairy product]] |workplaces = [[Purdue University]] |alma_mater = [[Cornell University]] |doctoral_advisor = |academic_advisors = |doctoral_students = |notable_students = |known_for = Work on [[butter]] processing and [[condensed milk]] |influences = |influenced = |awards = |signature = <!--(filename only)--> |footnotes = }} '''Otto Frederick Hunziker''' (25 December 1873 – 16 November 1959) was a pioneer in the American and international [[dairy]] industry, as both an educator and a technical innovator. Hunziker was born and raised in Switzerland, emigrated to the U.S., and studied at [[Cornell University]]. He started and developed the dairy program at [[Purdue University]] when such programs were at their infancy. At this same time, Hunziker was heavily involved with the development of the [[American Dairy Science Association]] (ADSA) and the standardization and improvement of many dairy tests and processes. Hunziker wrote several of the leading dairy processing texts, which continue to be cited. After leaving Purdue University, Hunziker managed research and operations at a large, national condensary, continued to drive ADSA's standardization and publishing efforts, represented the U.S. at international dairy congresses, and facilitated dairy industry improvements across the globe.
==Early years== Otto Frederick Hunziker was born in [[Zürich]], Switzerland, on 25 December 1873 to [[Karl Otto Hunziker|Karl Otto]] and Luise (Pupikofer) Hunziker.<ref name="People">{{cite journal | doi = 10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(54)91238-2 | title = People and Events in the Dairy Science World | journal = Journal of Dairy Science | volume = 37 | issue = 1 | pages = 107–108 | publisher = American Dairy Science Association | url = http://jds.fass.org/cgi/reprint/37/1/107.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-23 | year = 1954}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(56)91183-3 | title = The Remaining Charter Members of A.D.S.A. | journal = Journal of Dairy Science | volume = 39 | issue = 6 | pages = 621 | publisher = American Dairy Science Association | url = http://jds.fass.org/cgi/reprint/39/6/621.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-23 | year = 1956}}</ref><ref name="memorial">{{cite journal | title = Otto Frederick Hunziker Memorial | journal = Journal of Dairy Science | volume = 43 | issue = 4 | pages = 3–4 | publisher = American Dairy Science Association | url = http://jds.fass.org/cgi/reprint/43/4/3.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-05-23 | doi = 10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(60)90184-3 }}</ref> Otto's siblings were Karl Rudolf (born 5 February 1870, Zürich), Barbara Luise (17 June 1871 – 16 October 1871), and Marie Julie (23 July 1872 – 30 June 1938). Hunziker spent many early years in [[Goldbach, Zurich|Goldbach]], Switzerland, where his father was a pastor, professor, and member of the canton parliament.<ref name="matrikel">{{cite web |url= http://www.matrikel.uzh.ch/pages/597.htm#2247 |title= Matrikeledition der Universität Zürich |accessdate= 2008-05-28 |publisher= Universität Zürich |date= 2007-11-07 |language= German |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110707004720/http://www.matrikel.uzh.ch/pages/597.htm#2247 |archivedate= 2011-07-07 |df= }}</ref> Otto attended the two-year course of studies at Strickhof Agricultural College in Zürich, graduating at age 19. In 1893, Otto Frederick Hunziker [[Emigration|emigrated]] to the United States.<ref name="mastermind">{{cite book | last = Fitch | first = J. B. |editor1-first= E. M. |editor1-last= Harmon | title = The Ten Master Minds of Dairying | series = Successful Farming | publisher = [[Meredith Corporation|Meredith Publishing Co]] | location = Des Moines, Iowa | year = 1930 |chapter=10, Otto Frederick Hunziker |chapterurl=http://drinc.ucdavis.edu/hunziker.htm}}</ref>
During this time period, significant new development in dairy processing technology was occurring on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean. In 1890, [[Stephen Babcock]] published specifications for the [[Babcock test]] for milk fat content. In 1892, Dr. [[Niklaus Gerber]] acquired a Swiss [[patent]] on the [[Gerber method]] for analyzing fat content in milk.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gerber-instruments.ch/en/geschichte.htm |title=Gerber Instruments History |accessdate=2008-08-28 |publisher=Gerber Instruments AG |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314152713/http://www.gerber-instruments.ch/en/geschichte.htm |archivedate=2008-03-14 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Dr. Gerber was based in Zürich, had studied at the [[University of Zurich|University of Zürich]], and worked for two years at the Swiss-American Milk Company in [[Little Falls (town), New York|Little Falls, New York]]. Hunziker would spend a substantial amount of time studying and improving these analytic methods.
In the United States, Hunziker worked for two years as a laborer on a dairy farm near [[Attleboro, Massachusetts]]. To improve his English and commercial skills, he studied at [[Bryant & Stratton College|Bryant and Stratton]] Business College (now [[Bryant University]]), [[Providence, Rhode Island]] in 1896. He returned to Switzerland briefly in 1898 before returning to receive a [[B.S.]] Agriculture in 1900<ref>{{Cite news | title = Bachelors of the Science of Agriculture | newspaper = Cornell Alumni News Vol. 02, No. 36 | pages = 248 | date = 1900-06-23 | url = http://ecommons.library.cornell.edu/bitstream/1813/3164/36/002_36.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref> and [[Master of Science|M.S.A.]] in 1901 from Cornell University.<ref name="memorial" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Bailey |first=Liberty Hyde |authorlink=Liberty_Hyde_Bailey |title=A Register of the Rural Leadership in the United States and Canada |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jLgaAAAAMAAJ |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-05-29 |date=September 1920 |location=Ithaca, New York |oclc=7696533 |pages=234–235 |quote=Hunziker, Otto Frederick, manag. manufacturing dept. and dir. research lab., Blue Valley Creamery Co., Chicago, Ill. Asst. path. bact. and chg. dairy bact., Cornell Univ., 1901–1902; milk expert, Scranton Condensed Milk Co., Ellicottville and Springville, N. Y., 1902–1905; instr. dairying, Purdue Univ., 1905–1906; assoc. prof., 1906–1907; prof. and chief dairy dept., 1907–1917; present position, 1917–. Pres. Amer. Assoc. Dairy Sci., 1910–1912; mem. exec. com., Ind. State Dairy Assoc., Ind Manufacturers of Dairy Products; dir. Nat. Dairy Council. Adv. to condensed milk factories in Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Germany, Japan, 1909–1917. Del. from Amer. Assoc. Dairy Sci. and U. S. Dept. Agr. to Intern. Dairy Congress, Stockholm, Sweden, 1911. Auth.: Manufacture of Condensed Milk and Milk Powder, 1914, rev. ed., 1918 and 1920; The Butter Industry, 1920. Assoc. ed., Dairy License [sic] Journal.--b. Zurich, Switzerland, Dec. 25, 1873 (naturalized 1904); s. Otto Carl [sic] and Louise (Pupikofer) H.; reared in country; m. Florence Belle Burne, 1905; c. Thelma Belle, [*235] Florence Louise, Karl Otto, Walter Burne, Isabelle Mary, Otto F. Jr. Grad. Agr. Coll., Zurich, 1892; Bryant and Stratton Business Coll., Providence, R. I. 1896; B.S., Cornell Univ., 1900; M.S., 1901. [[Sigma Xi]]; [[Alpha Zeta (professional)|Alpha Zeta]]; [[Gamma Alpha]].}}</ref> He served as an assistant in charge of dairy bacteriology at Cornell University until 1902,<ref>{{cite book |last=Bandler |first=David K |authorlink= |author2=Robert F Holland |title=Food Science at Cornell University: A Century of Excellence, 1902–2002 |url=http://hdl.handle.net/1813/35 |format=PDF |accessdate=2008-05-30|year=2002 |publisher=Cornell University |location=Ithaca, New York |pages=10 |quote=A number of other individuals, some of who became well known in the dairy industry in subsequent years were associated with the department in teaching, research or extension during this period. * * * Otto F. Hunziker, (Cornell 1900) was Experiment Station Bacteriologist for about two years after his graduation. During that time he assisted in the teaching of dairy bacteriology and published ''Bulletin 203, The Care and Handling of Milk''. Hunziker later joined the staff of Purdue University and became well known through his books on the manufacture of dairy products.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Turk |first=Kenneth |title=Animal Husbandry at Cornell: A History and Record of Development from 1868 to 1963 |url=http://ecommons.library.cornell.edu/bitstream/1813/1519/1/Animal%20Husbandry%20at%20Cornell%2016Jun05.pdf |format=PDF|accessdate=2008-05-30|year=1987|publisher=Cornell University |location=Ithaca, New York|pages=18–19 |quote=Otto F. Hunziker graduated from Cornell in 1900 and joined the staff as a dairy bacteriologist for a period of about 2 years. He wrote Bulletin 197, "Investigations Concerning the Germicidal Action in Cow's Milk", and Bulletin 203, "The Care and Handling of Milk." Hunziker then joined the faculty of Purdue University and became widely known as a teacher and an author of two textbooks, ''The Butter Industry'', and ''Condensed Milk and Milk Powder''. Later, the major part of his career was in private industry.}}</ref> when he equipped and operated a dairy manufacturing research laboratory for the Scranton Condensed Milk Company in [[Ellicottville (town), New York|Ellicottville]], New York.<ref name="memorial" /> Otto Frederick married Florence Belle Burne on 10 April 1905 in [[Portville (town), New York|Portville]], [[Cattaraugus County, New York]].<ref>Cornell Alumni News, [http://ecommons.library.cornell.edu/bitstream/1813/3170/20/008_20.pdf Vol VII, No. 20], (21 Feb 1906), p. 237</ref>
==Professorship at Purdue== In 1905 Hunziker accepted a position at Purdue University in [[West Lafayette, Indiana]] as head of Purdue's Dairy Department.<ref>Cornell Alumni News, [http://ecommons.library.cornell.edu/bitstream/1813/3527/34/012_07.pdf Vol XII, No. 7], (10 Nov 1909), p. 82</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://adsa.asas.org/meetings/2006/abstracts/458.pdf |format=PDF |title=Highlights of Dairy Production at Purdue University |accessdate=2010-04-29 |work=ADSA Centennial Posters |author=M. M. Schutz |publisher=[[American Dairy Science Association|ADSA]] |quote=The first Head of the Dairy Husbandry Department and a charter member of ADSA was O.F. Hunziker (1905–1917). |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q58qkbQM?url=http://adsa.asas.org/meetings/2006/abstracts/458.pdf |archivedate=2010-05-29 |df= }}</ref> Dairy departments were relatively new at American colleges. (The first dairy school in the U.S. was created at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin]] in 1890.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wisc.edu/dysci/images/DairyScienceHistoryPoster.pdf |format=PDF |title=A Century of Excellence in Education and Discovery |accessdate=2008-08-27 |author=L.H. Schultz |author2=D.A. Wieckert |author3=C.C. Olson |author4=W.T. Howard |author5=D.P. Dickson |publisher=UW–Wisconsin |quote=Stephen Babcock established the first 'Dairy School' in the nation in 1890. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629212333/http://www.wisc.edu/dysci/images/DairyScienceHistoryPoster.pdf |archivedate=2008-06-29 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>) Hunziker led Purdue's dairy department through significant growth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adsa.org/centennial/posters/17684_purdue.pdf|title=A Century of Dairy Science at Purdue University|accessdate=2008-05-29|last=Chambers|first=James V|format=PDF|publisher=American Dairy Science Association|quote=With the vision and leadership of Otto F. Hunziker, dairy science and technology evolved at Purdue University. In 1905 Purdue experienced a sharp growth in its agricultural programs. Hunziker seized upon the opportunities to serve this growing agricultural sector. He identified needs for developing educational programs to better educate dairymen and needs for instituting adequate dairy laws for the protection of the dairy industry. His scientific treatises dealt with the solution of problems on dairy farms and in dairy plants. His research established accuracy of glassware and provided standard methods for the Babcock fat test of milk and cream. He planned Smith Hall and adjacent creamery which was built in 1913. A champion for the dairy industry, he won recognition in the fields of butter making, condensed milk and dried milk. He incorporated scientific principles into every step of the butter-making process. His textbooks were used by agricultural universities in dairy courses throughout the United States and in other dairy countries.|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327074129/http://www.adsa.org/centennial/posters/17684_purdue.pdf|archivedate=2009-03-27|df=}} From the abstract: "During the organizational year of the American Dairy Science Association, Otto F. Hunziker led the dairy program at Purdue University. A charter member of ADSA and its third president, Dr. Hunziker's brilliant career as a scientist, teacher and author is recognized throughout the world. At Purdue he provided leadership in developing educational programs to better educate dairymen. His research programs established the accuracy of glassware and provided standard methods for the Babcock fat test of milk and cream. He planned Smith Hall, which was built in 1913 to provide facilities for teaching, research and extension work."</ref><ref>The 1906 Purdue yearbook (the ''Debris'' Vol 18) lists: "Otto Fred Hunziker, Instructor in Dairying; B.S.A., Cornell University, 1900; M.S.A., 1901; Sigma Xi".{{cite book |title=Debris |url=http://earchives.lib.purdue.edu/u?/debris,9107 |format=JP2 |accessdate=2008-06-20 |volume=18 |year=1906 |publisher=Purdue University |location=West Lafayette, Indiana |pages=54}} The only other "dairying" faculty listed is one Hubert Everett Van Norman who is listed as "Resigned". The 1907 ''Debris'' indicates Hunziker was promoted to associate professor; the only other "dairying" faculty is one John deMoss Jarvis, assistant in dairying. The following year, Hunziker is listed as a full professor. In 1910, Hunziker's position is listed as professor of dairy husbandry and as a member of the Official Dairy Instructors' Association (ODIA). John deMoss Jarvis remains the only other dairy faculty, but became an instructor in 1909. In the 1911–1914 yearbooks, Hunziker is listed as president of ODIA as well as a member of the Indiana Academy of Science, Indiana State Dairy Association, and Indiana Jersey Cattle Club. The 1911 ''Debris'' also lists two dairy instructors and one assistant. In the new "Experiment Station" section, Hunziker is listed "Chief of Dairy Husbandry". The 1914 ''Debris'' lists Alpha Zeta and the Purdue Dairy Club for the first time; apart from Hunziker, two associates and an assistant are listed as faculty members of the dairy club.</ref>
In the summer of 1906, Hunziker was among 18 teachers and investigators meeting at the University of Illinois, Urbana, to found what was then known as National Association of Dairy Instructors and Investigators. (The following year, this association changed its name to "Official Dairy Instructors' Association" and, in 1916, changed its name to "American Dairy Science Association" (ADSA).<ref>{{cite journal | doi = 10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(17)94367-X | last1 = Harding | first1 = H.A. | title = Report of Committee on Change of Name | journal = Journal of Dairy Science | volume = 1 | issue = 2 | pages = 148–149 | publisher = [[American Dairy Science Association]] | url = http://jds.fass.org/cgi/reprint/1/2/148.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-06-19 | year = 1917}}</ref>) From 1910 to 1926, Hunziker chaired ADSA's Committee on Official Methods of Testing Milk and Cream for [[Butterfat]]. In 1911, this committee met in Washington, D.C. with the [[United States Department of Agriculture|U.S. Bureau of Dairying]], the [[American National Standards Institute|U.S. Bureau of Standards]] and manufacturers of glassware.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Herreid | first=Ernest O | title = The Babcock Test; A Review of the Literature | journal = Journal of Dairy Science | volume = 25 | issue = 4 | pages = 342–343 | publisher = American Dairy Science Association | url =http://jds.fass.org/cgi/reprint/25/4/335.pdf |format=PDF| accessdate = 2008-06-19 | doi = 10.3168/jds.s0022-0302(42)95301-3 }}</ref> Standard specifications for [[Babcock test|Babcock glassware]] were published as a result of this meeting. Hunziker actively pursued numerous improvements to the testing methodology, which improved the quality and safety of dairy products. Hunziker was the third president of [[American Dairy Science Association|ADSA]] from 1910 through 1911. During Hunziker's presidency, ADSA also: created a national score card for scoring dairies; standardized dairy judging contests; secured scholarships for student contests; improved national milk standards; developed ties with breed associations; and, provided fora for industry discussions on dairy instruction and extension services.<ref name=Trout>{{cite journal | last = Trout | first = G. Malcolm | authorlink=G. Malcolm Trout | title = Four Outstanding Early Presidents | journal = Journal of Dairy Science | volume = 64 | issue = 6 | pages = 880 | publisher = American Dairy Science Association | year = 1981 | doi = 10.3168/jds.S0022-0302(81)82666-5 }}: "The contributions of Otto F. Hunziker, Purdue University, to the Association extended far beyond his early 2-year presidency, 1910 and 1911. For many years he was the dedicated member of the Journal Management Committee, nurturing the newly founded journal as if it were his very own. As an administrator, author, and researcher, his presence at a meeting assured its success. There was authority in his deliberate, well-chosen words. He represented the dairy manufacturers of America five times at the world's dairy congresses—London, 1928; Copenhagen, 1931; Berlin, 1937; Stockholm, 1949; den Hague, 1953—a record that stood for many years. For his sustained enthusiasm for the American Dairy Science Association at home or abroad, he might well have been named 'Mr. ADSA'. He too, was listed among the 'Ten Master Minds of Dairying'."</ref>
[[File:Smith Hall 3.jpg|right|thumb|300px|Smith Hall, [[Purdue University]], 1913]]Apart from application of improved [[pedagogy]] and scientific methodology, Hunziker oversaw planning and construction of Smith Hall, the building which thereafter housed Purdue's dairy manufacturing group, [[Cooperative extension service|extension service]], and creamery. While at Purdue, he published over 50 bulletins, leaflets, and scientific treatises addressing dairy farm and plant problems.<ref name="memorial" /> In 1917, Hunziker left Purdue to manage manufacturing and research at the [[Blue Valley Creamery Company]] in [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Kansas Farmer Dairy Club | url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/210106319/ | newspaper=Kansas Farmer | location=Topeka, KS | date=30 Jun 1917 | page=6 |format=jpg | via=[[Newspapers.com]] |subscription=yes | accessdate =22 Apr 2017 | quote=Prof. O. F. Hunziker, one of the leading dairy authorities of the country, has resigned his position as chief of the dairy department of Purdue University, Indiana, to take up work with the Blue Valley Creamery Company. He was granted a year's leave of absence beginning last October to study commercial butter making and in connection with this work because [sic] associated with this company. He will be manager of the manufacturing department of all their factories and will superintend the investigations made in the dairy laboratory. Professor Hunziker is the author of a number of dairy book and bulletins and is now preparing the manuscript for a text book on creamery butter making. His previous experience and training will be of great value to him in his new work.}} {{Open access}}</ref>
==Professional life== [[File:OF Hunziker.jpg|left|thumb|O. F. Hunziker]]Hunziker wrote dairy articles and textbooks used throughout the world, developed dairy curricula, advocated for dairy laws, and developed standard testing methodology.<ref>{{cite news |title=Condensed Milk Standards |format=PDF |newspaper=The Ranch |publisher= |location=Seattle |date=15 Aug 1908 |page=10 |quote=During the past few months, Prof. O. F. Hunziker, of the Dairy Department of the Purdue School of Agriculture has been investigating the national and state standards of condensed milk. As a result of his study of the subject, he finds the present standards are not practical, as no milk condensary can, under all conditions and at all seasons of the year, put into its product the per cent of solids called for in the requirements for unsweetened condensed milk. These findings are the outcome of Prof. Hunziker's professional and business experiences, and therefore have great weight. Reports from every reputable milk condensing company in the country have been thoroughly examined and careful experiments carried on by Professor Hunziker in Indiana at the plant of the Condensed Milk Company of Sheridan before any announcement as to this unsatisfactory standard was made. The question of revising the present standard for condensed milk was taken up by the committee on food standards of the National Association of Dairy Instructors and Investigators, at its meeting at Mackinac Island, Mich., Aug. 4-7, and it is hoped that every effort will be put forth, through the proper channels, to induce the government to modify the standard now in use. This standard calls for not less than 28 per cent of milk solids of which not less than 27.5 per cent must be fat. There is no doubt but that a more specific attainable requirement than this will be welcomed by both producer and consumer. Pacific Coast milk producers are especially interested in this question, and a government expert has given it a thorough investigation. |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn98047754/1908-08-15/ed-1/seq-10.pdf }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article21827319 |title=Visit of Professor Hunziker |department=DAIRY PRODUCTS. |newspaper=[[The Brisbane Courier]] |date=16 May 1927 |accessdate=2 April 2012 |page=11 |publisher=National Library of Australia |quote=His visit is looked forward to by those interested in dairying with very much interest as the professor is the recognised leading dairy scientist of to-day, and his text books are read and used by all those engaged in the manufacture of dairy products throughout the world, and the knowledge that he has been able to impart has been responsible for many of the improvement in the quality of those products.}}</ref> In particular, Hunziker authored ''The Butter Industry, Prepared for Factory, School and Laboratory'', a well-known text in the industry that enjoyed at least three editions (1920, 1927, 1940).<ref>{{cite web | url=
